choices.text: It is associated with posterior dislocation of the hip
Sciatic nerve may be involved leading to foot drop
Avascular necrosis of the hip could be a late complication
The point of impact is on the greater trochanter

questions.text: All of the following is true about dashboard injury except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The point of impact is on the greater trochanter

 

Option D:

 

DASHBOARD INJURY

 

  • Dashboard injuries occurs to an occupant inside a vehicle when there is an impact with the dashboard during a collision or sudden break.
  • In a dashboard injury, the point of impact is the femur leading to bruise and contusion.
  • It causes knee ligament injury (more commonly Posterior cruciate ligament tear) and posterior dislocation of the Hip.

 

 

(ADD IMAGE)

 

  • Posterior dislocation of hip may injure the Sciatic nerve which may, in turn, result in Foot drop and loss of sensation along the distribution of branches of Sciatic Nerve.
  • Moreover, femoral artery pulsation which is felt around the head of femur, is absent. This is called Vascular Sign of Narath (positive in this case).
  • Early reduction has proved to be the most effective means of preventing osteonecrosis by shortening the time that the circulation of the femoral head is compromised.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: It is associated with posterior dislocation of the hip. True. Posterior hip dislocation is classically associated with dashboard injury. The direction of impact is along the long axis of femur, forcing the femoral head out of the acetabulum and moves backwards.

 

 

Option B: Sciatic nerve may be involved leading to foot drop. True. In posterior dislocation of hip, the sciatic nerve gets commonly injured. It has two terminal branches – Tibial nerve and Common Peroneal Nerve. It is the common peroneal nerve which controls the muscles for dorsiflexion of foot. Injury to these fibers lead to foot drop.

 

Option C: Avascular necrosis of the hip could be a late complication. True. Due to the damage to the network of reticular vessels in the femoral head, there may be ischemia leading to Avascular necrosis of hip.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Dashboard injury is associated with posterior dislocation of hip.
  • Sciatic nerve is commonly involved that leads to foot drop.
  • Avascular necrosis is the common late complication of the injury.
  • The point of impact in this injury is the femur.

questions.text: A patient presents with hip dislocation with limitation of Abduction at hip, and flexion and internal rotation deformity at hip and shortening. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior dislocation

 

Option C:

 

POSTERIOR HIP DISLOCATION

 

  • Since the question mentions limitation of abduction, hence there is adduction deformity along with flexion and internal rotation deformity. Thus, this is a case of Posterior dislocation of hip.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Central dislocation. In central fracture dislocation of hip, femoral head is forced medially through the floor of acetabulum and can be palpated on per rectal examination. There is shortening of limb. This is an extremely rare variety of dislocation.

 

Option B: Anterior dislocation. Anterior dislocations occur with the hip externally rotated and abducted. The degree of flexion at the time of injury determines the eventual position of the femoral head. They are associated with lengthening.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In posterior dislocation of the hip, the hip is in the FADIR deformity i.e., flexion, adduction and internal rotation, along with shortening of the limb.

questions.text: Thomas splint is used for immobilizing fractures of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Femur

 

Option A)

 

THOMAS SPLINT

 

  • The Thomas' splint is a long leg splint extending from a ring at the hip/groin area to beyond the foot.
  • It aims to immobilise the limb and consists of a padded metal ring covered with soft leather which is attached to an angled bar that extends down the length and both sides of the leg.
  • The bar is usually angled over the hip at the greater trochanter and the two side bars join in a “W” shape at the foot.

 

 

  • Thomas' splint is most commonly used with either skin or skeletal traction to provide immobilisation for proximal third and mid shaft femoral fractures, especially for children and adults whose injuries cannot be managed by other means. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Thomas splint is used for the femoral fractures and immobilization of the knee.

questions.text: Functional cast bracing is not used in fracture of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thoracolumbar spine

 

Option D)

 

FUNCTIONAL BRACING

 

  • Also called as sarmiento brace, it is a type of bracing where the limb is allowed to do restricted function with the brace in.
  • Principle:
    • Continuing function while a fracture is uniting
    • Encourages osteogenesis
    • Promotes the healing of tissues
    • Prevents the development of joint stiffness
    • Accelerates rehabilitation
  • Functional bracing has become the preferred approach in the non-operative management of certain fractures due to its advantages in promoting early mobility and reducing the risk of complications.
  • Functional bracing is an effective therapeutic modality in the management of selected fractures of the tibia, humerus, and ulna, particularly low-energy injuries.
  • In the case of tibial fractures, it is applicable only to reduced transverse fractures and to axially unstable fractures with an acceptable degree of shortening.
  • Thoracolumbar fracture is not an indication for functional bracing.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Functional bracing is used for the management of fractures of the long bones like tibia, humerus, femur and ulna.
  • It is not indicated to manage the thoracolumbar fractures.

choices.text: Avulsion of femoral attachment of MCL
Avulsion of tibial attachment of MCL
Avulsion of femoral attachment of LCL
Avulsion of tibial attachment of LCL

questions.text: Pellegrini-Stieda Disease is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Avulsion of femoral attachment of MCL

 

Option A)

 

PELLEGRINI-STIEDA DISEASE

 

  • It is defined as ossification of the medial collateral ligament (MCL) at or near its proximal insertion on the medial femoral condyle.
  • The etiology of Pellegrini-Stieda is thought to be an insult to the medial collateral ligament causing damage and acute inflammation that sets in delayed ossification. 
  • This insult has been classically described as a macrotrauma, whether direct or indirect, causing valgus stress with disruption of the MCL fibers. 
  • Most patients are asymptomatic while a small proportion will have medial knee pain.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Pellegrini-stieda disease is the ossified post-traumatic lesion at/near the medial femoral collateral ligament adjacent to the margin of the medial femoral condyle.
  • The calcification begins to form few weeks after the avulsion injury of the MCL at the medial femoral condyle.

questions.text: Which of the following is ideal site for harvesting bone graft?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iliac crest

 

Option A:

 

BONE GRAFT

 

  • Iliac crest is the ideal and most common site for harvesting bone graft.
  • This is an ideal source of primary 1st order bone graft because it is relatively subcutaneous, has natural curvatures that are useful in fashioning grafts, has ample cancellous bone and has cortical bone of varying thickness.
  • Removal of bone carries minimal risk and usually has no significant residual disability.
  • Posterior superior iliac spine is the best source of cancellous bone graft.
  • Anterior iliac crest is the best source of bicortical and cortico-cancellous graft.
  • Ideal characteristics of a bone graft: 
  • Nontoxic
  • Non antigenic
  • Resistant to infection
  • Strong and resilient
  • Easily adaptable
  • Readily and sufficiently available
  • Minimal surgical procedure
  • Stimulates new attachment

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Iliac crest is the most common and readily available bone graft substitute with least graft-related complications.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came with hip flexor contracture. What is the most likely test to be done in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thomas test

 

Option B:

 

THOMAS TEST

 

  • It is done to measure fixed flexion deformity of hip by neutralizing lumbar lordosis.
  • Up to 30-degree flexion deformity of hip can be compensated by lumbar lordosis.
  • Steps of Thomas test: 
    • Ask the patient to lie down with their legs hanging off the edge.
    • Look for exaggerated lumbar lordosis.
    • Bring one knee towards the chest of the patient, keeping the other leg flat on the table.
    • Pelvis' stabilization is done by placing one hand on the ASIS of the leg being tested.
    • Observe the opposite leg for any lifting of the lower back (overcorrection of the normal side.) Avoid it by ensuring that ischial tuberosity touches the flat surface.
    • Slowly extend the opposite hip by lowering the patient's leg towards the table while maintaining the knee-to-chest posture.
    • Look for any compensatory movements.

 

 

 

  • The result of the test is as follows:                                                                                                                    

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Allis test. Also known as Galeazzi test, it is done in Developmental dysplasia of Hip to assess hip dislocation and leg length inequality. 

 

 

Option C: Ober Test. It is done for iliotibial band and TFL contracture.

 

 

Option D: Trendelenburg Test. It is done for the assessment of the hip abductors.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In a patient with hip flexor contracture, the test done is the Thomas test to test the contracture or tightness in the hip flexor muscles.

questions.text: Halopelvic traction is used for correcting which deformity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spine

 

Option A)

 

HALOPELVIC TRACTION

 

  • Halo-pelvic traction is ideal for the treatment of severe and rigid spinal deformities such as healed tuberculous kyphosis.
  • The pelvic ring is secured to the two halves of the pelvis by two threaded pins that traverse the whole length of the two halves of the pelvis.
  • Extension bars fitted to the halo and pelvic rings provide fixation and traction when the bars are gradually elongated.
  • The apparatus allows the patient to remain ambulant during treatment.
  • The strong fixation allows osteotomies of the rigid deformity to be staged and distraction forces to be gradually applied between stages of surgery without fear of instability or spinal cord compression.
  • The apparatus can also be used for corrective treatment of severe scoliosis such as that due to neurofibromatosis and poliomyelitis.
  • Spinal fusions are performed after correction of the deformities.

 

 

Halo-pelvic external fixator frame for a) thoracic deformity, b) lumbar deformity, and c) cervical deformity

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Pectus carinatum. Treatment of pectus carinatum falls into three categories: non-surgical bracing, surgical correction, or cosmetic concealment.  Orthotic braces are the first option for treatment as acceptable results are often achievable.

 

Option C. Spondyloptosis. Complete slip of a vertebral body anteriorly is known as spondyloptosis and is rarely seen outside of high-energy trauma. Irrespective of the neurological state of the patient the mainstay of management is reduction and stabilization of the fracture dislocation.

 

Option D. Coxa vara. The objective of interventions is to restore the neck-shaft angle and realigning the epiphysial plate to decrease shear forces and promote ossification of the femoral neck defect. This is achieved by performing a valgus osteotomy, with the valgus position of the femoral neck improving the action of the gluteus muscles, normalizing the femoral neck angle, increasing total limb length and improving the joint congruence.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Halopelvic traction is used for correcting the spinal deformities like healed tuberculous kyphosis, and severe scoliosis.

questions.text: Weight allowed in skeletal traction is up to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 20 kg

 

Option C)

 

SKELETAL TRACTION

 

  • Skeletal traction has the following purposes:
    • reduction of fractures or dislocations
    • immobilisation of fractures or joints
    • preventing muscle spasm
    • pain relief
    • keeping the patient comfortable until definitive treatment
  • Skeletal traction can be used for the treatment of any long bone fracture or major joint dislocation.
  • The most common indication for skeletal traction, is for the treatment of femur and acetabulum fractures.
  • For maintenance of traction:
    • Femur fractures: 10 to 15% of the patient’s body weight 
    • Pelvis fractures: 15 to 20% of body weight for longitudinal traction, 5-7 kg for lateral traction
    • Humerus fractures: 2.5 kg initially and then increase until scapula is just lifted off the bed
    • Tibia fractures: 3-5 kg 
  • Skin vs Skeletal traction:

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • For skeletal traction, the weight permitted is up to 20kgs.

questions.text: Maximum weight for skin traction:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4–5 kg

 

Option B)

 

SKIN TRACTION

 

  • Indications for skin traction:
    • Short term therapy for patients with femoral fractures, hip dislocations and /or septic joints waiting for definitive treatment
    • Post-reduction treatment for hip dislocation
    • Muscle spasm prevention/reduction
    • Limb pain
    • Risk of joint contractures
  • The weight permitted should be approximately 10% of the child’s weight up to a maximum of 2.2kg.
  • Skin vs Skeletal traction:

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The weight permitted for the skin traction in children is up to 10% of their body weight, up to 2.2 kgs.

questions.text: Brace used in scoliosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Milwaukee Brace

 

Option A)

 

MILWAUKEE BRACE

 

  • The Milwaukee brace is an active corrective spinal orthosis.
  • It consists of a neck ring with a throat mould and two occipital pads to avoid a high pressure in the neck.
  • A Milwaukee brace is used in the treatment of postural disorders like idiopathic scoliosis or Scheuerman disease.
  • The brace is normally prescribed for children who have not reached their growth spurt or who are in their fast growing period.
  • It is not used for adults or adolescents already beyond their growth spurt, as it will have no effect.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. LS belt: An LS Belt is used for providing support and stability to the lumbar spine and sacral region. It is commonly utilized in conditions such as low back pain, sacroiliac joint dysfunction, or mild cases of lumbar instability. It aims to alleviate discomfort and promote proper alignment in the lower back area.

 

Option C. Taylor’s brace: Taylor's brace is primarily used for the treatment of thoracolumbar junction fractures and injuries. It consists of a rigid frame that extends from the pelvis to the upper thoracic region, providing stabilization and support to the spine.

 

Option D. Four post collar: A four-post cervical collar is used for stabilizing and immobilizing the cervical spine following traumatic injuries or surgery. It consists of a rigid frame with support posts positioned around the neck to restrict movement and promote healing.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Brace used in scoliosis is Milwaukee brace.

choices.text: Hypoxemia with PaO2 < 60 mm Hg, FiO2 = 0.4
Central nervous system depression disproportionate to hypoxemia
Axillary or subconjunctival petechiae
All are Correct

questions.text: Gurd’s criteria for fat embolism includes:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All are Correct

 

Option D)

 

FAT EMBOLISM SYNDROME

 

  • Classically, the patient presents with a history of RTA with fracture of multiple long bones followed by petechial rash over axilla + Respiratory distress + CNS depression (Confusion, reduced level of consciousness) within 48-72 hours.

 

 

Fibrinous material and an empty space

 

 

Diffuse bilateral infiltrates (ARDS-like picture) in Fat Embolism syndrome

 

  • Fat embolism occurs due to release of fat globules from the bone marrow into the blood circulation following a severe trauma or orthopedic surgeries or fracture of multiple long bones or liposuction.
  • The diagnosis mainly is clinical for which Gurd criteria is used.

 

 

  • Treatment is mainly supportive with adequate oxygenation through supplemental oxygen or mechanical ventilation.
  • IV Fluids to maintain hydration and hemodynamic support.
  • Early immobilization and fixation of long bone fractures should be done to mitigate the risks of Fat Embolism.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Gurd’s criteria for fat embolism includes:

 

  • Hypoxemia (PaO2 < 60 mm Hg, FiO2 = 0.4)
  • Central nervous system depression disproportionate to hypoxemia;
  • Axillary or subconjunctival petechiae

choices.text: T1 – T2
T3 – T4

questions.text: A patient involved in a road traffic accident presents with quadriparesis, sphincter disturbance, decreased sensory level up to the upper border of sternum and respiratory rate of 35/minute. The likely level of lesion is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C4 – C5

 

Option B.

 

  • C2 dermatome – Occiput and top part of neck.
  • C3 dermatome – Lower part of neck up to the clavicle.
  • C4 dermatome – Area just below the clavicle (Area which coincide with upper border of sternum).
  • Motor supply of upper-limb is C5–C8, T1.
  • Motor supply of diaphragm (Phrenic nerve) is C3–C5.
  • Thus, C4–C5 prolapse will cause increased respiratory rate with all mentioned features.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Altered sensation at the upper border of sternum or below the clavicle is suggestive of affection of C4 dermatome.
  • Increased respiratory rate is caused by affection of C3-C5 nerve root as it supplies the diaphragm.
  • Thus, out of the given options, C4-C5 level of lesion is present.

choices.text: Fracture of spinous process of lower cervical and upper thoracic vertebra
Fracture of spinous process of mid thoracic vertebra
Fracture of spinous process of lumbar vertebra
Spinous process fractures of lower cervical vertebrae

questions.text: Clay-Shoveler’s fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture of spinous processes of lower cervical and upper thoracic vertebra

 

Option A.

 

CLAY-SHOVELER’S FRACTURE

 

  • Clay-shoveler Fractures are an avulsion-type spinous process fracture in the lower cervical or upper thoracic spine.
  • Incidence is rare.
  • Etiology:
    • Direct trauma to posterior spinous process
    • Indirect trauma by sudden muscular/ligamentous pull in flexion or extension
  • Most commonly seen at C7, but can affect C6 to T3.
  • It usually occurs midway between the spinous tip and lamina.
  • Risk factors:
    • Labourers
    • Racket or contact sports
    • Motor vehicle accidents

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Clay-Shoveler’s fracture is the fracture of the spinous process of the lower cervical and upper thoracic vertebra.
  • It is most commonly seen at C7 vertebra but can be seen anywhere from C6-T3.

questions.text: Cast syndrome is a complication of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hip spica

 

Option A)

 

CAST SYNDROME

 

  • Cast syndrome, commonly known as superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome is a rare cause of small bowel obstruction caused by compression of third part of duodenum from narrowing of the angle between superior mesenteric artery and abdominal aorta resulting in symptoms of duodenal outflow obstruction. 
  • Hip spica or scoliosis cast can press on superior mesenteric artery, further compressing 3rd part of duodenum and leading to cast syndrome.

 

 

Obstruction of the third part of the duodenum by the superior mesenteric artery following the use of a body plaster cast

 

  • Patients may present acutely, with chronic insidious symptomatology, or with an acute exacerbation of chronic symptoms.
  • Acute presentation is usually characterized by signs and symptoms of duodenal obstruction.
  • Chronic cases may present with long-standing vague abdominal symptoms, early satiety and anorexia, or recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, associated with vomiting.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The cast syndrome is a known complication of the hip spica cast as it puts pressure on the superior mesenteric artery that further compresses the third part of the duodenum, obstructing the small bowel.

choices.text: Sign of recovery from spinal shock
Partial lesion of spinal cord
Complete transection of spinal cord
Incomplete transection of spinal cord

questions.text: Return of Bulbocavernous reflex in spinal shock is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sign of recovery from spinal shock

 

Option A.

 

BULBOCAVERNOUS REFLEX IN SPINAL SHOCK

 

  • The first reflex to return in spinal shock is bulbocavernosus reflex (S2, S3, S4) i.e., contraction of the anal sphincter in response to the stimulation of glans or clitoris.
  • Its reappearance is the sign of recovery from the spinal shock.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C. Complete transection of spinal cord. Presence of bulbocavernous reflex in a complete spinal cord lesion is indicative of an intact S2-S4 spinal reflex arc.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Spinal shock is temporary state following injury.
  • Spinal shock can be ruled out if,
  1. Bulbocavernous reflex present
  2. 48 hours has elapsed from time of injury
  • Assessment of neurological deficit can only be done after spinal shock has phased off.
  • Deficit may be partial or complete injury.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with disc prolapse. Examination reveals paralysis of Extensor Hallucis Longus. Which nerve root is affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) L5

 

Option C.

 

 

Note:

 

  • Dermatome and myotome should be assessed separately for desired root value.
  • In disk prolapse, usually lower nerve root is compressed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. L3. When L3 nerve root is affected, quadriceps is affected, which causes weak knee extension and hip adduction.

 

Option B. L4. When L4 nerve root is affected, there is weakness of tibialis anterior and quadriceps muscles, leading to weak ankle dorsiflexion, hip adduction and knee extension.

 

Option D. S1. When S1 nerve root is affected, gastrocnemius and soleus or flexor hallucis longus; abductor hallucis and gluteus maximus are affected. This leads to weakening of ankle plantarflexion and hip extension.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Extensor hallucis longus is paralysed when L5 nerve root is affected.

choices.text: It is a burst fractures of the ring of atlas vertebra
It is the most common type of atlas fracture
Fracture definition is particularly clear on CT scan image
It is associated with injury elsewhere in spine in 25% of the cases

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Jefferson’s fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is associated elsewhere is spine in 25% of the cases

 

Option D)

 

  • Jefferson fracture is the eponymous name given to a burst fracture of the atlas, hence option D is incorrect.

 

JEFFERSON’S FRACTURE 

 

  • Jefferson’s fracture is burst fracture of ring of atlas (C1) vertebrae.
  • Burst fracture is a vertical compression fracture.
  • It is most common fracture of Atlas.
  • There is 50% association of concomitant injury in cervical spine elsewhere.

 

 

 

  • Associations:
    • 50% are associated with other C-spine injuries
    • 33% are associated with a C2 fracture
    • 25-50% of young children have a concurrent head injury
    • Vertebral artery injury 5 (blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI))
    • Extracranial cranial nerve injury 6
  • Investigation of choice for fracture morphology is CT scan.

 

Note: pseudo-Jefferson fracture, or pseudo spread of the atlas on the axis refers to the normal overhanging of the lateral edges of the lateral masses of C1 over the lateral edges of the body of C2. It is seen in children.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Jefferson’s fracture is a burst fracture of the ring of the atlas with 50% cases associated with other cervical spine injuries.
  • It is the most commonly seen atlas fracture and its clear image can be seen on the CT scan.

choices.text: Traumatic spondylolisthesis of C1 over C2
Spondylolisthesis of lower cervical spine with tearing of C6-C7 intervertebral disc
Burst fracture of C3
Spinous process fractures of lower cervical vertebrae

questions.text: Undertaker’s fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spondylolisthesis of lower cervical spine with tearing of C6-C7 intervertebral disc

 

Option B.

 

UNDERTAKER’S FRACTURE

 

  • Tearing of C6-C7 intervertebral disc causing subluxation of the cervical vertebrae.
  • It is caused by poor handling of the dead bodies by the mortuary attendants or during improper trasnportation.
  • It occurs due to sudden fall of the head over occipital region.
  • It may present as a complete separation of the cervical spine at the level of C6-C7.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Undertaker’s fracture is the spondylolisthesis of the lower cervical spine with tearing of the C6-C7 intervertebral disc.

choices.text: Most common axis fracture
Surgical treatment is necessary
Union almost always occurs

questions.text: Regarding Hangman’s fracture, true is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Union almost always occurs

 

Option D.

 

HANGMAN FRACTURE

 

  • Traumatic Spondylolisthesis of Axis, also known as a Hangman's Fracture, is a traumatic fracture of the bilateral pars interarticularis of C2.
  • Diagnosis is made with CT of the cervical spine.
  • Treatment may be cervical collar immobilization, halo immobilization, or surgical stabilization depending on displacement, angulation, and fracture stability. 
  • Successful healing of C2 traumatic spondylolisthesis is reported to approach 95%. This is most commonly achieved with non-operative measures, even in the presence of displacement of pars interarticularis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. High post-admission mortality. The mortality rate in patients with hangman's fracture due to any cause is 7% at the most.

 

Option B. Most common axis fracture. Hangman’s fracture is the second most common fracture of the C2 vertebrae following a fracture of the odontoid process.

 

Option C. Surgical treatment is necessary. Treatment options of hangman’s fracture include conservative management, cervical orthosis, halo-vest orthosis, and surgical procedures. Surgical fixation may be considered in case of severe angulation of C2 on C3 and disruption of the C2 to C3 disc space.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The hangman’s fracture successfully heals with non-operative treatment in almost 95% cases.

questions.text: The compression fracture is commonest in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lower thoracic spine

 

Option C.

 

COMPRESSION FRACTURE

 

  • In axial load injuries (Compression injuries), the most common site of trauma is at the thoracolumbar junction.
  • In normal standing position, body weight acts anterior to the spine, creating a forward bending load (moment) on the spine.

 

 

  • At thoracolumbar junction, being the most mobile and least stable joint, hence compression fracture are very common.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The compression fracture is commonest in the lower thoracic spine at the junction of the thoracic-lumbar spine due to its more mobility and less stability.

questions.text: Skeletal traction is given by:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D)

 

SKELETAL TRACTION

 

  • Skeletal Traction is given by:
    • Steinmann’s pin: non-threaded, used in non-osteoporotic cortical bone
    • Denham pin: threaded, preferred in osteoporotic and cancellous bone, e.g. calcaneal traction
    • Crutchfield’s tong: used for cervical traction
  • K-wires, Ilizarov wires can also be used for skeletal traction.
  • Rush nail is used for pediatric fracture shaft femur and not traction.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Skeletal traction is given by K-wires, Denham pins, and Steinmann’s pins.

questions.text: Contraindication for skin traction is/are:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D)

 

CONTRAINDICATION OF SKIN TRACTION

 

  • Unstable spine
  • Congenital malformation
  • Osteoporosis
  • Peripheral vascular diseases, diabetes, varicose veins, and prolonged use of steroid medications
  • Wound or lesion on the site
  • Paralysis on affect site
  • History of hypersensitive skin
  • Suspicion of impaired circulation

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Skin traction is contra-indicated in dermatitis, compromised limb vascularity, and skin abrasions.

questions.text: Spur sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acetabular fracture

 

Option D:

 

SPUR SIGN

 

  • The spur sign is produced by a triangular fragment of iliac bone that remains attached to the sacroiliac joint but is separated from the fractured acetabulum.
  • This spur is exposed when the fractured columns are medially displaced.
  • The presence of the spur sign is suggestive of avulsion fracture or a displaced fracture fragment.
  • It is better observed in the obturator oblique radiographic view of the x-ray and the CT scan.
  • It is seen in both anterior and posterior column acetabular fractures (Bicolumnar fracture).

 

 

 

Pathognomic of both column fracture. Seen in obturator oblique view.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Supracondylar fracture of humerus. If no fracture line can be identified on the radiological images, indirect signs like anterior or posterior fat pad signs can be seen. Since supracondylar fracture is a transverse or oblique fracture, thus is does not involve spur sign on radiography.

 

 

Option B: Radial head fracture. A fracture of the radial head can sometimes result in a spur sign, especially if there is an associated avulsion fracture of the annular ligament or the adjacent soft tissues. The avulsed fragment may appear as a spur on imaging studies. However, not all radial head fractures present with a spur sign.

 

Option C: Fibula fracture. A fibula fracture, particularly at the level of the ankle or distal leg, can sometimes result in a spur sign. This is especially true if the fracture involves the attachment site of the lateral collateral ligament or the biceps femoris tendon, leading to an avulsion-type injury and the formation of a bone spur.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • An acetabular fracture involves the hip socket can occur due to high-energy trauma such as motor vehicle accidents or falls from a height.
  • These fractures can be complex and involve displacement of bone fragments.
  • The avulsion of the bone appears as a spur-like fragment on the radiograph, thus called spur sign.

questions.text: Morel-Lavallee lesion is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acetabular fracture

 

Option A:

 

MOREL-LAVALLEE LESION

 

  • Morel-Lavallee lesion is a localized area of subcutaneous fat necrosis over the lateral aspect of hip caused by same trauma that causes the acetabular fracture.
  • The presence of a significant Morel-Lavallee lesion can be suspected by hypermobility of the skin and subcutaneous tissue in the affected area from the shear type separation of the subcutaneous tissue from the underlying fascia lata.
  • It appears as a closed, degloving soft tissue injury.
  • Diagnosis requires high index of suspicion with presence of an area of ecchymosis, swelling, and skin hypermobility in the polytrauma patient with underlying fractures.
  • Treatment is generally operative irrigation and debridement for most lesions given the proximity to planned surgical incisions and increased risk of infection.
  • Alternatively, some fractures can be treated through ilioinguinal approach, thus avoiding the affected area.
  • Associated orthopaedic conditions:
    • pelvic and acetabular fractures (most commonly)
    • proximal femur fractures
       

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Morel-Lavallee lesions are most commonly seen in acetabular fractures.
  • They can also occur in femoral neck fracture and proximal tibia fracture.
  • They are not typically associated with fractures of lumbar spine.

choices.text: Recurrent dislocation in spite of closed reduction and traction

questions.text: Kocher Langenbeck approach for emergency acetabular fixation is done in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Morel-Lavallee lesion

 

Option D:

 

KOCHER-LANGENBECK APPROACH

 

  • This is a posterior approach used for all posterior wall, posterior column, and posterior column with posterior wall fractures of acetabulum.
  • It is also used for most transverse and transverse plus posterior wall fracture and many T-shaped fractures.

 

 

  • It allows complete exposure of (posterior) retroacetabular surface caudally (distally) as far as the ischial tuberosity.
  • The greater and lesser sciatic notches are visualized.
  • But the anterior and superior exposure is limited.
  • Recurrent (posterior) dislocation and sciatic nerve injury indicate injury of posterior column or posterior wall; so these are approached through (posterior) Kocher-Langenbeck approach.
  • The incidence of sciatic nerve injury due to this approach is 2–6%.
  • Morel levallee lesion are associated lesion with pelvis or acetabular fractures.
  • They are closed degloving soft tissue injury, as a result of abrupt separation of skin and subcutaneous tissue from the underlying fascia.
  • The operative management includes single-incision irrigation and debridement for large lesions, dual incision irrigation and debridement when the lesion overlies the surgical approach for fracture management, and open debridement with resection of fibrous capsule in case of pseudocyst formation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Kocher Langenbeck approach is a posterior approach used in the conditions involving posterior structures.
  • It is commonly used for open fractures, progressive sciatic nerve injuries, and recurrent posterior dislocations despite closed reduction and traction treatment.
  • For Moral-Lavallee lesions, the best surgical treatment method is irrigation and debridement of the lesion.

questions.text: In pelvis fracture, the amount of blood loss is around:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4–8 units

 

Option D:

 

PELVIC FRACTURE

 

  • In pelvis fracture, intrapelvic hemorrhage is by far the most serious complication.
  • Hemorrhage frequently results from fracture surfaces.
  • Amount of blood loss is around 4–8 units.
  • In unstable pelvic ring fractures, a blood loss of approximately 9 to 15 units of blood occurs whereas total blood loss is mainly evaluated retrospectively and indirectly.
  • The acute total blood loss and hemodynamic status of the patient can be assessed by clinical shock signs.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The pelvic fractures have a most common and serious complication of blood loss due to intrapelvic hemorrhage from the fractured surfaces.
  • Around 4-8 units of blood is lost in the pelvic fractures.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male after a fall in bathroom had hip fracture seen in the pelvic X-ray below. What will be the position of the left lower limb?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shortened and externally rotated

 

Option A:

 

HIP FRACTURE

 

  • The given image in the question shows a displaced femoral neck fracture.
  • Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture.
  • Femoral neck fractures are associated with low energy falls in the elderly.
  • In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as fall from a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. 
  • Risk factors for femoral neck fractures include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density.
  • 70% of all hip fractures occur in women. 
  • Symptoms include pain in the groin or pain referred along the medial side of the thigh and knee in an impacted fracture.
  • In a displaced fracture, there will be pain in the entire hip. 
  • In an impacted fracture, there is no obvious clinical deformity on examination. There is mild discomfort in the active/passive hip range of motion, and pain with percussion over the greater trochanter.
  • In displaced fractures, the leg appears in external rotation and abduction deformity with shortening of the limb.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image shows a displaced femoral neck fracture in the elderly patient.
  • Following the fracture, the limb appears shortened with external rotation and abduction deformity at the hip.

questions.text: An 80-year-old female after fall developed inability to walk with external rotation deformity. On examination, SLR is not possible and broadening of trochanter is present. The possible diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fracture intertrochanteric femur

 

Option B:

 

INTERTROCHANTERIC FEMUR FRACTURE

 

  • Intertrochanteric fractures are extracapsular fractures of the proximal femur that occur between the greater and lesser trochanter.
  • They are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism.
  • The patients present with a short and externally rotated lower extremity.
  • Evaluation of a range of motion is not possible due to pain.
  • If the fracture causes split in Greater Trochanter, there is broadening of trochanter.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Fracture neck of femur. In femoral neck fracture, trochanters are normal. The limb presents with shortening, abduction and partial external rotation deformity.

 

Option C: Fracture subtrochanteric femur. This fracture is a risk factor in patients on denosumab or bisphosphonate use since a long time. Such patients will have a history of thigh pain before the trauma. The patients with subtrochanteric fracture presents with hip and thigh pain, inability to bear weight on the affected extremity, pain on movement, limb shortening, varus deformity, and flexion of proximal fragment that may threaten the overlying skin.

 

Option D: Fracture greater trochanter. In the isolated greater trochanter fracture, the patient presents with pain in the abduction and extension of the hip. The pain exacerbates on palpation of the greater trochanter.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Broadening of trochanters is seen in both intertrochantric as well as Greater Trochanter fracture.
  • But inability to do SLR, and an external rotation deformity points towards intertrochantric fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following fractures of the neck of femur are associated with maximal compromise in blood supply?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sub-capital fractures

 

Option D:

 

FEMORAL NECK AVN

 

  • The majority of the blood supply to the head of the femur comes from the medial and lateral circumflex branches of the profunda femoris artery, which is a branch of the femoral artery.
  • The blood supply to the neck of the femur is retrograde i.e., passing from distal to proximal along the femoral neck to the femoral head.

 

 

  • Hence, more proximal and more displaced fractures lead to compromise of blood supply.
  • Causes of non-union in femoral neck fractures are posterior comminution, inadequate immobilization, inadequate vascularity, inhibition by synovial fluid, vertical fracture line and absence of cambium layer of periosteum.
  • Chances of AVN and non-union in femoral neck fractures in decreasing order is: Subcapital > transcervical > basi-cervical > intertrochanteric

 

 

Risk of AVN according to location of fracture upper end femur

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The order of chances of AVN in femoral neck fracture is: Subcapital > Transcervical > Basicervical > Intertrochanteric

questions.text: Non-union is common in fracture:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neck of femur

 

Option C:

 

NON-UNION FRACTURE

 

  • FDA defines non-union as fracture that persists for a minimum of 9 months without signs of healing for 3 months.
  • Common fractures which are prone to non-union include:
    1. Neck of femur
    2. Scaphoid
    3. Talus
    4. Lower third tibia
    5. Lower 3rd ulna
    6. Lateral condyle humerus
       

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Scapula. Scapula fractures most commonly undergoes post-traumatic glenohumeral arthritis, malunion, recurrent glenohumeral instability, and neurovascular injuries.

 

Option B: Supracondylar humerus. The main complications of supracondylar humerus fractures are malunion, Volkmann ischemic contracture, and damage to ulnar/median/radial nerves. Osteonecrosis is a rare complication.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Non-union is most commonly seen in fracture neck of femur among the given options.
  • Scapular and supracondylar humerus fractures can lead to malunion as a complication.

choices.text: Closed reduction and fixation with three cancellous screws
Longitudinal skin traction for 6 weeks

questions.text: An 80-year-old male sustained fracture neck of femur 1 week back. The treatment of choice is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemiarthroplasty

 

Option A:

 

FRACTURE NECK OF FEMUR TREATMENT

 

  • In patients < 65 years of age with fracture sustained < 3 weeks before,
    • Closed reduction and internal fixation with multiple screw is the treatment of choice.
    • In basicervical fracture, dynamic hip screw can be done.
    • If closed reduction is not possible, open reduction and screw fixation is indicated.
  • In patients < 65 years of age with > 3 week old fracture, osteotomy/Bone grafting + fixation is done.
  • In patients ≥ 65 years with no pre-existing arthritis, hemiarthroplasty is preferred.
  • In patients with pre-existing arthritis at any age, total hip replacement is done

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Excision arthroplasty. It is not typically the treatment of choice for a fractured neck of femur, as it does not address the issue of restoring function to the hip joint.

 

Option C: Closed reduction and fixation with three cancellous screws. Closed reduction is preferred in cases of patients less than 65 years of age with the fracture sustained < 3 weeks ago. It is not preferred in older patients due to concerns about bone quality and healing capacity.

 

Option D: Longitudinal skin traction for 6 weeks. While traction can be used as a temporary measure to relieve pain and align the fracture, it is not a definitive treatment for a fractured neck of femur, especially in an elderly patient. Long-term traction can lead to complications such as pressure ulcers and muscle atrophy.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The treatment of choice for fracture of femoral neck in an 80-year-old patient is hemiarthroplasty.

questions.text: Patient with femur head fracture with associated fracture of acetabulum will fall into Pipkin type:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV

 

Option D:

 

PIPKIN CLASSIFICATION

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Fracture of femoral head along with fracture of the acetabulum falls into type IV of the Pipkin classification of hip dislocation.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: True about proximal fragment in subtrochanteric fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D)

 

SUBTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE

 

  • Subtrochanteric fractures are proximal femur fractures located within 5 cm of the lesser trochanter that may occur in low energy (elderly) or high energy (young patients) mechanisms.
  • The strong gluteal and thigh muscles create a classic deformity.
  • The proximal fragment is held in abduction, flexion, and external rotation.
  • The gluteus medius and minimus attach at the greater trochanter and provide an abduction force.
  • The short external rotators also attach along the greater trochanter and intertrochanteric crest and provide an external rotation force.
  • The iliopsoas attaches at the lesser trochanter and provides a flexion force.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In subtrochanteric femoral fractures, the proximal fragment is held in flexion, abduction and external rotation.

questions.text: Posterior dislocation of hip can damage which nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sciatic nerve

 

Option B:

 

POSTERIOR DISLOCATION OF HIP

 

  • The most common complication of the posterior dislocation of hip is the injury to the sciatic nerve, leading to foot drop and altered sensation in the nerve route.
  • Approximately 10% cases with posterior hip dislocation have sciatic nerve injury but cases as high as 35% in posterior acetabular fracture have sciatic nerve injury.
  • Iatrogenic injury to the nerve may be the result of laceration, penetration by drill bits, excessive traction by retractors, or prolonged extension of the ipsilateral knee.
  • Injury of peroneal division of sciatic nerve have a worse prognosis than injury of the tibial division because peroneal division have less fascicles, is larger in size, and is protected by less connective tissue.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Superior gluteal nerve. Superior gluteal nerve neuropathy is uncommon and often associated with iatrogenic injury like due to intramuscular injections.

 

Option C: Inferior gluteal nerve. Injury to the inferior gluteal nerve is most commonly iatrogenic in origin. Total hip arthroplasty is the most common surgical procedure in which the inferior gluteal nerve can be injured.

 

Option D: Femoral nerve. One risk of damage to the femoral nerve is pelvic fracture.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Posterior dislocation of the hip is likely to damage the sciatic nerve.

choices.text: Superior tibiofibular joint
Inferior tibiofibular joint

questions.text: Which of the following is a syndesmosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inferior tibiofibular joint

 

Option B)

 

SYNDESMOSIS

 

  • A syndesmosis is a complex fibrous joint between two bones and connected by ligaments and a strong membrane with slight movement allowed.
  • The distal tibiofibular syndesmosis/inferior tibiofibular joint is a syndesmotic joint.
  • It is formed between the distal tibia (concave surface) and fibula (convex surface), with no articular capsule or synovial membrane as a fibrous joint, and attached by the interosseous ligament (IOL), the anterior-inferior tibiofibular ligament (AITFL), the posterior-inferior tibiofibular ligament (PITFL), and the transverse tibiofibular ligament (TTFL).
  • The articulating surfaces are the rough medial convex surface of the distal fibula and a triangular notch on the lateral surface of the distal tibia.
  • The direct contact between the two bones at this site is very limited, and this forms a mortise for the trochlea of the Talus.  

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Superior tibiofibular joint. The superior tibiofibular joint is a plane type of synovial joint, which allows the involved bones to glide over one another to create movement. This joint is located between the flat articular facet on the fibular head and a similar articular facet situated posterolaterally on the lateral tibial condyle.

 

Option C. Talocalcaneal joint. The subtalar (ST) joint is an articulation between two of the tarsal bones in the foot: the talus and calcaneus. The joint is classed structurally as a synovial joint, and functionally as a plane synovial joint.

 

Option D. Calcaneocuboid joint. The calcaneocuboid joint involves the anterior surface of the calcaneus and the posterior surface of the cuboid. Its joint capsule is thickened superiorly and also inferiorly. It is a modified saddle-type joint.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The inferior tibiofibular joint is a syndesmotic joint consisting of a complex fibrous joint between the distal tibia and the fibula, allowing slight movement.

choices.text: Anterior talofibular ligament
Posterior talofibular ligament

questions.text: Which ligament is commonly involved in ankle sprain?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior talofibular ligament

 

Option A)

 

ANKLE SPRAIN

 

  • Around 90% of ankle sprains involve an inversion injury to the anterior talofibular (ATFL) and calcaneofibular (CFL) ligaments — the lateral ligaments of the ankle.
  • The less common medial ankle sprain is caused by an eversion injury to the deltoid ligament on the inside of the ankle.
  • Ankle Ligaments:
    • Medial Collateral Ligament:
      • It is also called as deltoid ligament.
      • It is strong ligament and major stabilizer of ankle joint.
      • It has two components: superficial and deep.
    • Lateral Collateral Ligament:
      • It is a weak ligament, involved in over 90% of ankle ligament injuries.
      • It has three parts:
  1. Anterior talofibular: Most commonly injured
  2. Middle calcaneofibular: 2nd most common injured
  3. Posterior talofibular: Torn in most severe injuries

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Posterior talofibular ligament. This ligament is torn in the most severe injuries. Its injury is less common and almost always occur with other injuries. An injured posterior talofibular ligament (PTFL) is one of the reasons for chronic lateral ankle instability.

 

Option C. Calcaneofibular ligament. Isolated calcaneofibular ligament (CFL) injuries are rare. CFL injuries are often associated with the anterior talofibular ligaments (ATFL); however, the CFL injuries can impact long term functions, such as mobility and strength.

 

Option D. Spring ligament. Spring ligament injuries have a high association with posterior tibial tendon tears. Disruption of the spring ligament destabilizes the longitudinal arch, allowing plantar and medial rotation of the head of the talus and valgus alignment of the calcaneus (pes planovalgus). The clinical result is an acquired flatfoot deformity.

 

Educational objective:

 

The ankle sprain involves most commonly anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL).

questions.text: In per rectal examination, femoral head is palpable in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Central dislocation of hip

 

Option C:

 

CENTRAL DISLOCATION OF HIP

 

  • Central hip dislocation refers to the dislocation of femoral head medially within the acetabulum.
  • It may also involve impacted fracture of the acetabulum.
  • It is relatively rare and occurs following a high-velocity trauma.
  • It may lead to avascular necrosis of femoral head and recurrent dislocations.
  • It is an orthopedic emergency and may require surgical intervention.
  • The limb may appear shortened and internally rotated.
  • On per rectal examination, Femoral head is palpable.
     

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Anterior dislocation of hip. Patients with anterior dislocations may have a palpable femoral head in the femoral triangle.

 

Option B: Posterior dislocation of hip. Patients with posterior dislocation have a palpable femoral head in the gluteal region.

 

Option D: Lateral dislocation of hip. In this dislocation, the femoral head is palpable near the ASIS or the obturator foramen.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the central dislocation of the hip, the femoral head is palpable in the rectal area while doing a per rectal examination.

choices.text: Flexor hallucis brevis

questions.text: Which muscle is attached to the tuberosity of navicular bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tibialis posterior

 

Option D)

 

MUSCLE ATTACHMENT

 

  • The only muscular attachment on the navicular bone is tibialis posterior.
  • The muscle is located within the deep compartment of the posterior aspect of the tibia and the tendon extends inferiorly around the medial malleolus to insert on the navicular tuberosity.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Adductor hallucis. It has 2 heads, oblique head and transverse head. The oblique head originates from the base of 2nd-4th metatarsals. The transverse head originates from the head of 3rd-5th metatarsals. Both the heads are inserted at the base of proximal phalanx of hallux on lateral side.

 

 

Option B. Flexor hallucis brevis. It originates from the cuboid and lateral cuneiform on plantar side. The medial belly inserts on the medial side of proximal phalanx of hallux while the lateral belly inserts on the lateral side of proximal phalanx.

 

 

Option C. Tibialis anterior. It originates from the lateral condyle of tibia between the proximal ½ and 2/3rd area. It inserts on the medial and plantar surfaces of 1st cuneiform and on base of first metatarsal.

 


 

Educational objective:

 

  • The only muscle that attaches to the navicular tuberosity is the tibialis posterior muscle.

choices.text: Pipkin’s type 4 fracture of femoral head

questions.text: A 33-year-old male has history of RTA, now complaints of pain in the left hip. On examination, there is Flexion and External Rotation of left lower limb. There is 7 cm shortening of left lower limb, and a gluteal mass is felt which moves with the movement of femoral shaft. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pipkin’s type 4 fracture of femoral head

 

Option D:

 

HIP FRACTURE

 

  • Anterior dislocation is ruled out because it will have Flexion, Abduction, External Rotation with lengthening and anterior placement of femoral head (Mass that moves with femur shaft movement is femur head).
  • Central dislocation is ruled out because it will have shortening and femur head is palpable on per rectal examination.
  • Posterior dislocation will have Flexion, Adduction and internal rotation with shortening and gluteal palpation of the femoral head.
  • Associated fracture with dislocations does not have the classical deformities.
  • Posterior dislocation with fracture of head of femur is characterised by:
    • Shortening
    • Classical deformities of posterior dislocation not present
    • Head displaced posteriorly (Gluteal)
  • Pipkins type IV: limb shortening and presence of gluteal mass with atypical features

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the given case scenario, the flexion and external rotation of the lower limb indicates anterior dislocation of the hip but the shortening suggests central or posterior dislocation of the hip.
  • The presence of the gluteal mass that moves with movement of the femoral shaft suggests Pipkin type IV of the femoral head dislocation where in there is an associated acetabular fracture present.
  • Thus the given case is a Pipkin type IV fracture of the femoral head.

questions.text: Injury to calcaneum is associated most commonly with which fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fracture vertebrae

 

Option B)

 

CALCANEUM FRACTURE

 

  • Calcaneum is the most commonly fractured tarsal bone and in most cases, the mode of injury is fall from height.
  • Over 20% of these patients suffer associated injury of dorso-lumbar spine (most common), pelvis or hip, base of skull, tibia and talus.

 

 

Injuries sustained from fall from height

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Fracture rib. Most rib fractures are due to direct penetrating or blunt trauma to the chest. Solid organ injuries associated with rib fractures include liver injuries and splenic injuries.

 

Option C. Fracture skull. Fractures of the skull usually occur due to direct trauma to the head. They are often associated with the injury to the brain.

 

Option D. Fracture fibula. They are typically the result of a direct injury to the leg, usually a fall or direct blow or blunt trauma like a sports injury or motor vehicle accident. Gunshot wounds are another mechanism from which an isolated fibula fracture can be sustained. Fibula fractures can be associated with superficial peroneal nerve injury, arterial damage and compartment syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Calcaneum fractures are most commonly associated with dorso-lumbar spine fractures due to fall from a significant height.

choices.text: Chronic ankle instability

questions.text: Watson-Jones procedure is done for:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic ankle instability

 

Option D)

 

WATSON-JONES PROCEDURE FOR ANKLE

 

  • Watson-Jones procedure is used to treat the chronic instability of the ankle.
  • In this procedure, the peroneus brevis tendon is used to reconstruct the ATFL.
  • The tendon is passed through a tunnel in the fibula into the neck of the tendon length for transfer.
  • This procedure prevents inversion of the foot and restricts subtalar motion.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Polio. Management of polio-related complications involves physical therapy, bracing, orthopedic surgeries tailored to specific deformities or functional impairments, and sometimes nerve surgeries.

 

Option B. Muscle paralysis. Muscle paralysis might be addressed through various interventions such as physical therapy, bracing, nerve surgery, or other orthopedic procedures depending on the cause and severity of paralysis.

 

Option C. Neglected club foot. Neglected club foot usually involves a combination of soft tissue releases, osteotomies, and sometimes external fixation devices to correct the deformity.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Watson-Jones procedure is used for the treatment of chronic ankle instability.

 

Note:

 

  • Watson jones approach – used for hip replacement (anterolateral approach)
  • Watson jones procedure – for chronic ankle instability
  • Watson jones classification – for tibia tuberosity avulsion fracture

choices.text: Fracture shaft of femur
Fracture neck of femur
Fracture intertrochanteric femur
Transcervical fracture neck of femur

questions.text: Maximum shortening of lower limb is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture shaft of femur

 

Option A)

 

FEMUR FRACTURE

 

  • Lower limb injures associated with maximum shortening are posterior dislocation of hip > fracture shaft of femur > Fracture subtrochanteric femur > Intertrochanteric fracture > Fracture Neck of Femur.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Among the given options, fracture of shaft of femur leads to maximum shortening of the limb.
  • If seen overall, the posterior dislocation causes the maximum shortening, followed by the fracture shaft of femur.

questions.text: A person with multiple injuries develops fever restlessness, tachycardia, tachypnea and subconjunctival rash after 48 hours of injury. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fat embolism

 

Option B)

 

FAT EMBOLISM

 

  • Based on the clinical presentation of increased heart rate and respiratory rate along with rash and history of multiple trauma, the most likely diagnosis is Fat Embolism.
  • It is more commonly seen in patients with multiple fractures and in fractures involving lower limbs especially femur.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Early warning signs are a slight rise in temperature and pulse rate (tachycardia).
    • The classical triad of fat embolism syndrome is:
      • Respiratory symptoms: Dyspnea or tachypnea
      • Neurological symptoms: Confusion or disorientation
      • Petechial rash: In axilla, neck, periumbilical area, conjunctiva of lower lid, front and back of chest, shoulder
  • For the diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome, at least one major and four minor criteria must be present (Gurd’s Criteria).

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Air embolism. For air embolism to occur, there should be history of sitting craniotomy (Head and Neck surgery), Scuba diving, Central venous catheterization, childbirth or Decompression sickness. The clinical vignette and the presence of fever are pointing against the diagnosis.

 

Option C. Pulmonary embolism. For pulmonary embolism to occur, the patient should have hypercoagulable state, DVT, a tight cast which is suddenly removed or prolonged immobilization. Clinical presentation is not going along with this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Bacterial pneumonitis. A patient with bacterial pneumonitis presents with fever, tachycardia &/or chills and sweats, cough with mucoid/purulent/blood-tinged sputum, pleuritic chest pain, shortness of breath with normal daily routine, fatigue, headache, myalgia and arthralgia.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the given case scenario, there is a history of multiple injuries to the patient.
  • The patient develops fever, restlessness, tachycardia, tachypnea, and subconjunctival rash after 48 hours.
  • The presence of symptoms after 48 hours is clearly diagnostic of presence of fat embolism in the patient by following the Gurd’s criteria.

choices.text: Tension Band Wiring

questions.text: What is method of fixation of this fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tension Band Wiring

 

Option D)

 

PATELLA FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • Tension Band Wiring (TBW) is a surgical method to secure the bones in place which are subjected to tension forces.
  • Wires and Screws or Pins are used to create this tension band effect.
  • In two-part fracture of Patella, the pull of Quadriceps on the proximal fragment keeps them apart.
  • In the operation, first the fractured fragments are reduced, fixed with TBW and then the extensor retinacula are repaired.
  • TBW converts distractive forces into compressive forces.

 

 

  • In case if there is comminuted fracture where accurate reduction is not possible, patellectomy is done.
  • Tension band wiring is done using:
  • Cancellous screws for fracture of Olecranon process
  • K-wires and stainless steel wires for fracture of Patella

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tension band wiring is the gold standard treatment for the two-part patella fracture.

questions.text: Bulge sign in knee joint is seen after how much fluid accumulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) <30 mL

 

Option D)

 

BULGE SIGN

 

  • Knee Effusion is tested by:
    • Patella Tap
    • Bulge sign (10–15 mL fluid)
    • Balloon sign
    • Ballottement of patella
  • Bulge sign is seen when the fluid in the knee is assessed.
  • This is done by gently pressing the medial side of the patella and moving the hand in an ascending motion, and then firmly pressing on the lateral aspect of the knee.
  • In normal conditions, no fluid is appreciated.
  • When the medial aspect bugles out of after the pressure on the lateral aspect, this is called as positive bulge sign.
  • A positive bulge sign is consistent with moderate amount of fluid (around 10-15ml).
  • When the medial aspect does not bulge out but tensely reflects the lateral pressure, then there is a large amount of fluid present in the knee.

 

Educational objective:

 

The positive bulge sign in the knee is seen after the accumulation of about 10-15ml of fluid in the knee.

questions.text: Popliteal artery injury is commonly seen in which type of traumatic knee dislocation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior

 

Option A)

 

KNEE DISLOCATION

 

  • Knee dislocation requires careful evaluation of Vascular Injury.
  • Anterior knee dislocation has highest incidence of Popliteal artery damage.
  • The incidence being 5% to 60%.
  • Due to high energy trauma, the popliteal artery running behind the knee joint gets compressed, stretched or torn.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the anterior knee dislocation, popliteal artery is most commonly injured.

choices.text: 1st and 2nd metatarsal
2nd and 3rd metatarsal
3rd and 4th metatarsal
4th and 5th metatarsal

questions.text: March fracture involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2nd and 3rd metatarsal

 

Option B)

 

MARCH FRACTURE

 

  • March fractures are the metatarsal stress fractures caused by overuse injuries.
  • They are most commonly seen in second and third metatarsal neck.
  • The second metatarsal is more prone to injury due to its limited motion from strong ligamentous attachment to the first and second cuneiforms and length compared to the other foot metatarsals.
  • They result from a sudden increase in the intensity, duration, and frequency of activity without sufficient rest.
  • The repetitive impact on the metatarsals with weight-bearing exercises causes microfractures, which consolidate into stress fractures and are not the result of a single traumatic event.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 1st and 2nd metatarsal. The first metatarsal is thicker and stronger than the others and is less prone to stress fractures compared to the other metatarsals.

 

Option C. 3rd and 4th metatarsal. While stress fractures can occur in the third and fourth metatarsals, they are less common compared to the second and third metatarsals.

 

Educational objective:

 

March fracture involves stress fracture of the 2nd and 3rd metatarsal neck (2nd MT > 3rd MT).

questions.text: Fracture involving both the malleoli is called:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pott's fracture

 

Option B)

 

POTT’S FRACTURE

 

  • A Pott’s fracture is a fracture affecting one or both of the malleoli.
  • During activities such as landing from a jump (volleyball, basketball) or when rolling an ankle, a certain amount of stress is placed on the tibia and fibula and the ankle joint.
  • When this stress is traumatic, a break in the medial, lateral, or posterior malleolus may occur.
  • A Pott's fracture often occurs in combination with other injuries such as an inversion injury, a dislocation of the ankle, or other fractures of the foot, ankle, or lower leg.
  • Pott's fractures can vary in location, severity, and type including displaced fractures, un-displaced fractures, bi-malleolar fractures, or compound fractures.

 

 

Bimalleolar fracture (Pott’s fracture)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Cotton’s fracture. Cotton’s fracture is tri-malleolar fracture involving the media malleolus, posterior aspect of tibial plafond (referred to as posterior malleolus) and lateral malleolus. This is a more unstable fracture and may be associated with ligamentous injury.

 

 

Option C. Pirogoff’s fracture. A Pirogoff fracture is a type of injury involving the hindfoot, specifically the calcaneus bone. In a Pirogoff fracture, the calcaneus bone is fractured along with the articulating portion of the talus bone. This type of fracture occurs as a result of high-energy trauma, such as a severe impact or crush injury to the foot. The fracture pattern involves the separation of the calcaneus from the rest of the foot, along with a portion of the talus bone.

 

Option D. Dupuytren’s fracture. Dupuytren fracture is an eponymous for an injury of mid-distal fibular fracture occurring above the syndesmosis with diastasis. It involves medial malleolus avulsion fracture, tibiofibular ligament rupture (i.e. syndesmotic injury), and posterior malleolus fracture.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Fracture involving both the lateral and medial malleoli is called pott’s fracture.

questions.text:
Fracture of talus without displacement in X-ray would lead to: 

 

  1. Osteoarthritis of ankle
  2. Osteonecrosis of head of talus
  3. Avascular necrosis of body of talus
  4. Avascular necrosis of neck of talus
  5. Non-union
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3

 

Option B)

 

TALUS FRACTURE

 

  • Talus is the major weight bearing structure (the superior articular surface carries a greater load per unit area than any other bone in body) and it has a vulnerable blood supply and is a common site for post-traumatic ischemic necrosis.
  • The body of talus is supplied mainly by vessels which enter the talar neck from the tarsal canal.

 

 

  • In fractures of the talar neck, these vessels are divided.
  • If the fracture is displaced, the extraosseous plexus too may be damaged and body of talus becomes ischemic.
  • Complications of talus fracture:
    • Secondary Osteoarthritis of Subtalar > ankle joint occurs years after injury in over 50% patients. There are several causes like articular damage because of initial trauma, malunion, distortion of articular surface and AVN. This is the most common complication of fracture talus.
    • Avascular necrosis of body is a common complication. The incidence varies with the severity of displacement.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The osseous vessels enter the talus through its neck and run postero-laterally to supply the body of talus.
  • Therefore, in displaced fracture of talus neck, the blood supply of body is cut off which results in avascular necrosis of the body of the talus.
  • Even a non-displaced fracture of the talus can disrupt the normal mechanics of the ankle joint.
  • This disruption can lead to post-traumatic osteoarthritis over time, as the altered joint mechanics can cause wear and tear on the articular surfaces of the ankle bones.

questions.text: Bohler’s angle is decreased in the fracture of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcaneum

 

Option B)

 

BOHLER’S ANGLE

 

  • It is used in the assessment of intra-articular calcaneal fractures.
  • The Böhler angle is the angle on a lateral foot radiograph between a line joining the highest point of the anterior process of the calcaneus and the highest point of the posterior articular facet, and a line joining the highest point of the posterior articular facet with the highest point of the calcaneal tuberosity.
  • The normal value for the Böhler angle is 25-40°. 
  • A reduced Böhler angle can be seen in displaced intra-articular calcaneal fractures.
  • The degree of reduction in the Böhler angle is an indicator of the severity of calcaneal injury.

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Bohler’s angle is used to assess for the intra-articular calcaneal fractures.
  • It is decreased in case of a calcaneum fracture.
  • This angle is specific to the calcaneus fractures and is not used for other foot bone fractures.

choices.text: Type of fracture
Subtalar joint dislocation
Duration of presentation
All of the above

questions.text: For fracture of calcaneum, the management depends upon:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D)

 

CALCANEUM FRACTURE MANAGEMENT INDICATIONS

 

  • Treatment is non-operative versus operative based on fracture displacement and alignment, associated soft tissue injury, and patient risk factors.
  • Indications for non-operative immobilization:
    • Small extra-articular fracture (<1 cm) with intact Achilles tendon and <2 mm displacement
    • Non-displaced
    • Near normal Böhler's angles
    • Anterior process fracture involving <25% of calcaneocuboid joint
    • Comorbidities that preclude good surgical outcome (smoker, diabetes, PVD)
    • Minimally displaced tuberosity fractures (<1 cm of displacement) without threatened soft-tissue envelope in elderly patients with reduced function or physical capacity
  • Indications for operative treatment:
    • Closed reduction with percutaneous pinning:
      • Minimally displaced or those with mild shortening
      • Large extra-articular fractures (>1 cm)
      • Severe peripheral vascular disease or soft-tissue compromise
    • ORIF:
      • Displaced fractures (>1 cm displacement)
      • Threatened soft tissue
      • Open fractures
      • Large extra-articular with > 2 mm displacement
      • Anterior process fracture with >25% involvement of calcaneocuboid joint
      • Displaced sustentaculum fractures

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The management of the fracture of the calcaneus depends upon the type of fracture present, dislocation of the subtalar joint, duration of presentation of the patient, and the degree of displacement of the fracture.

 

Note: Sander’s classification of calcaneus fracture is commonly used to classify these fractures based on the number of articular fragments seen on the coronal CT scan image at the widest point of the posterior facet. Increasing number of fragments is associated with increased fracture severity.

questions.text: Neutral triangle is seen radiologically in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Calcaneum

 

Option C)

 

NEUTRAL TRIANGLE OF CALCANEUM

 

  • Within the trabeculae of calcaneus lies the neutral triangle, an area directly below the distal edge of posterior facet.
  • Base of the triangle is the weakest, most vulnerable portion of the calcaneum.
  • Axial impaction of the talus into the calcaneum results in a vertical fracture through the neutral triangle, and it represents the primary fracture line.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The neutral triangle is specifically seen in the radiographs of the calcaneum.
  • It is an area below the posterior facet within the trabeculae of the calcaneus.

choices.text: Fracture base of skull
Fracture 12th thoracic vertebra

questions.text: Least common complication of fall from height is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fracture fibula

 

Option C)

 

INJURY FROM FALL FROM HEIGHT

 

  • Calcaneum is the most commonly fractured tarsal bone and in most cases, the mode of injury is fall from height.
  • Over 20% of these patients suffer associated injury of dorso-lumbar spine (most common), pelvis or hip, base of skull, tibia and talus.

 

 

Injuries sustained from fall from height

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Fracture base of skull. Fractures of the base of the skull are serious injuries that can result from high-impact trauma, such as a fall from height. These fractures can lead to severe complications, including brain injury, cranial nerve damage, and cerebrospinal fluid leakage. While fractures of the base of the skull are relatively less common than some other injuries, they are typically considered the common complication of a fall from height.

 

Option B. Fracture calcaneum. The calcaneum can fracture during a fall from height if the individual lands on their feet with significant force. Calcaneal fractures can cause considerable pain and difficulty walking. Thus, fractures of the calcaneum are most common complication of a fall from height.

 

Option D. Fracture 12th thoracic vertebra. Fractures of the thoracic vertebrae, including the 12th thoracic vertebra, can occur in falls from height, particularly if there is compression of the spine upon impact. These fractures can lead to serious complications, including spinal cord injury and neurological deficits. The fractures of the thoracic vertebrae are sometimes associated with the fractures of the calcaneum after a fall from a significant height.

 

Educational objective:        

 

  • The least common complication of fall from height is the fracture of the fibula.
  • Fibula is fractures from a direct blow or trauma to the bone or from a gunshot injury, or in association with ankle injury.

questions.text: Most commonly injured tarsal bone is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Calcaneum

 

Option D)

 

TARSAL BONE FRACTURE

 

  • The tarsal bones are the bones of the midfoot and hindfoot regions of the foot.
  • The calcaneus, or heel bone, is the largest tarsal bone and bears a significant amount of weight during walking and running.
  • Fractures of the calcaneus are most common, particularly in high-energy injuries such as falls from height or motor vehicle accidents.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Talus. Talus fractures are less common as compared to other tarsal bones.

 

Option B. Navicular. Navicular fractures can occur with high-energy trauma or repetitive stress injuries, but they are less common compared to other tarsal bones.

 

Option C. Cuneiform. Fractures of the cuneiform bones are relatively rare compared to fractures of other tarsal bones.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Fractures of the calcaneus are frequent due to its exposed position and its role in absorbing and distributing forces during weight-bearing activities.
  • Thus, calcaneus is the most common bone to fracture among the tarsal bones.

choices.text: Posterior sacroiliac complex displacement by > 1 cm
Avulsion fracture of sacral or ischial end of the sacrospinous ligament
Avulsion fractures of the L5 transverse process
Isolated disruption of pubic symphysis with pubic diastasis of 2 cm

questions.text: Radiological factors indicating an unstable pelvis are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Isolated disruption of pubic symphysis with pubic diastasis of 2 cm

 

Option D:

 

RADIOGRAPHIC SIGNS OF PELVIC INSTABILITY

 

  • Posterior sacroiliac complex displacement >1cm or > 5mm
  • Avulsion fracture of sacral or ischial end of the sacrospinous ligament
  • Avulsion fractures of the L5 transverse process, ischial spine, ischial tuberosity, sacrum
  • Disruption of pubic symphysis with pubic diastasis of 2 cm with posterior pelvic injury or injury to anterior/posterior sacroiliac ligament or sacrospinous ligaments
  • Presence of gap rather than impaction in the posterior pelvic ring

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Isolated disruption of pubic symphysis and pubic diastasis do not lead to unstable pelvis.
  • The pubic symphysis disruption with pubic diastasis, posterior pelvic injury or injury to anterior/posterior sacroiliac ligament or sacrospinous ligament causes pelvic instability.

choices.text: Flexion, adduction and external rotation
Flexion, abduction and external rotation
Flexion, abduction and internal rotation
Flexion, adduction and internal rotation

questions.text: In upper one-third femoral shaft fracture, the displacement of proximal segment is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Flexion, abduction and external rotation

 

Option B)

 

FEMORAL SHAFT FRACTURE

 

  • In the proximal 1/3rd fracture shaft of femur, the proximal fragment undergoes flexion, abduction and external rotation due to the pull of the gluteus medius and iliopsoas muscles attached to it.
  • While, the distal fragment sags down due to gravitational pull and gets adducted due to the pull of Adductor Muscles (adductor longus, gluteus minimus, adductor magnus and pectineus).
  • There is no marked displacement in children.
  • The patient classically presents with the history of severe violence or high energy trauma like an RTA, and painful swelling and deformity in the thigh region.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the upper 1/3rd fracture of the femoral shaft, the proximal fragment undergoes flexion, abduction and external rotation due to gluteus medius and iliopsoas muscle pull, while the distal fragment undergoes adduction due to adductor muscle group pull.

choices.text: Stress at fracture site due to muscle spasm

questions.text: Non-union is a very common complication of intracapsular fractures of the neck of femur. Which of the following is not a very important cause for the same?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stress at fracture site due to muscle spasm

 

Option D:

 

NON-UNION INTRACAPSULAR FRACTURE

 

  • Femoral neck fracture nonunion represents a failure of bony healing after fixation of an intracapsular femoral neck fracture.
  • Nonunion occurs after fracture displacement and/or hardware failure before bony consolidation.
  • Femoral neck fractures are intracapsular, thus they are at higher risk for nonunion than other hip fractures.
  • This is because they
    • lack periosteal or extraosseous blood supply
    • bathe in synovial fluid which deters fracture healing
    • healing is intra-osseous only (no callus formation)
    • have posterior comminution, inadequate immobilization, inadequate vascularity, vertical fracture line and absence of cambium layer of periosteum

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Non-union is a common complication of intracapsular fracture of neck of femur.
  • Non-union occurs due to inadequate immobilization, and blood supply.
  • The synovial fluid around also interferes with the fracture healing.
  • Stress at the fracture site due to muscle spasm do not interfere with fracture healing, instead it helps in fracture union.

questions.text: Pipkin’s classification system is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture femur head

 

Option A:

 

PIPKIN CLASSIFICATION
