  • Pipkin classification is the most commonly used classification for femoral head fractures, which are uncommon but are associated with hip dislocations.


 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Fracture femur shaft. Winquist Classification is used to classify the femoral shaft fractures.

 

Option C: Fracture proximal tibia. Shatzker Classification is used to classify the fractures of proximal tibia.

 

Option D: Fracture calcaneum. Sander’s CT Classification is used to classify the fractures of calcaneum.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Pipkin classification is used to classify the fractures of the femoral head.

choices.text: Jefferson’s fracture is the most common of atlas
Quadriplegia is seen in 80% cases
Atlanto-occipital fusion may sometimes be needed
CT scans should be done for diagnosis

questions.text: All of the following are true about fracture of the atlas vertebra, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Quadriplegia is seen in 80% cases

 

Option B.

 

ATLAS FRACTURE

 

  • Atlas Fractures are traumatic injuries caused by high-energy trauma with axial loading in young patients (Jefferson Fracture) or low-energy falls in elderly.
  • Due to the capacious (large canal) nature of the spinal canal at this level, these injuries usually present with neck pain without neurological deficits.
  • The patient may present with neck pain, cervical spine muscle spasm, limited neck motion, occipital neuralgia/numbness, loss of consciousness, double vision, vertigo.
  • Diagnosis is often missed with plain radiographs so a CT scan may be required to make the diagnosis.

 

 

  • Neurological deficits are usually uncommon with atlas injuries.
  • If the fracture is associated with C2 fractures, then there are higher chances of neurological deficits.
  • Stable injuries can be treated with immobilization in a cervical collar.
  • Unstable injuries require either halo-vest immobilization or surgical stabilization with a fusion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Jefferson’s fracture is the most common of atlas. True. Atlas Fractures caused by high-energy trauma with axial loading in young patients is called Jefferson Fracture. 

 

Option C. Atlanto-occipital fusion may sometimes be needed. True. Stable injuries can be treated with immobilization in a cervical collar. Unstable injuries require either halo-vest immobilization or surgical stabilization with a fusion of the atlanto-occipital joint.

 

Option D. CT scans should be done for diagnosis. True. Diagnosis is often missed with plain radiographs so a CT scan may be required to make the diagnosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Fracture of the atlas is not associated with neurological deficits unless it is associated with C2 fractures. The patient may present with neck pain and associated neck muscle spasm.

choices.text: Closed reduction and Internal fixation by cancellous screws
Closed reduction and Internal fixation by Austin Moore pins

questions.text: Treatment of choice in fracture neck of femur in a 40-year-old male presenting after 2 days is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed reduction and Internal fixation by cancellous screws

 

Option B:

 

TREATMENT OF FRACTURE NECK OF FEMUR

 

  • In patients < 65 years of age with fracture sustained < 3 weeks before,
    • Closed reduction and internal fixation with multiple screw is the treatment of choice.
    • In basicervical fracture, dynamic hip screw can be done.
    • If closed reduction is not possible, open reduction and screw fixation is indicated.
  • In patients < 65 years of age with > 3 week old fracture, osteotomy/Bone grafting + fixation is done.
  • In patients ≥ 65 years with no pre-existing arthritis, hemiarthroplasty is preferred.
  • In patients with pre-existing arthritis at any age, total hip replacement is done.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hemiarthroplasty. This is preferred in patients > 65 years of age with no pre-existing arthritis.

 

Option C: Closed reduction and internal fixation by Austin Moore pins. Austin Moore pins are commonly used for internal fixation of hip fractures, especially in older adults. They are long, metallic pins inserted into the femoral neck to stabilize the fracture. However, in a 40-year-old male with a fracture neck of femur presenting after only 2 days, internal fixation with Austin Moore pins might not be the treatment of choice. This option is more commonly considered in older patients or in certain fracture patterns where hemiarthroplasty or other methods are not feasible.

 

Option D: Plaster and rest. Plaster immobilization is not typically indicated for a fracture neck of femur, especially in a 40-year-old male. Fractures in this region usually require surgical intervention for proper alignment and stabilization to prevent complications like avascular necrosis of the femoral head or nonunion. Plaster immobilization alone does not provide adequate stabilization and may lead to poor outcomes.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In patients < 65 years of age with fracture < 3 weeks old, the preferred treatment option is closed reduction and internal fixation with multiple cancellous screws.

choices.text: Fracture of distal fibula with posterior dislocation of proximal fragment
Fracture of distal fibula with dislocation of distal fragment
Fracture of distal end tibia
Fracture of distal end femur

questions.text: BosWorth fracture involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture of distal fibula with posterior dislocation of proximal fragment

 

Option A)

 

BOSWORTH FRACTURE

 

  • The Bosworth fracture-dislocation is a rare fracture-dislocation of the ankle where the proximal fibular fragment lodges behind the tibia i.e., it dislocates posteriorly, rendering it irreducible by routine closed manipulations.
  • Clinically the patient's foot is in severe external rotation.
  • This external rotation makes the initial roentgenograms difficult to interpret.
  • Consequently, the diagnosis is often overlooked, resulting in inappropriate treatment and a disastrous outcome.
  • If properly recognized, these injuries can be successfully treated by closed or open techniques with return of near-normal ankle function.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option C. Fracture of distal end tibia. It is called the tibial pilon fracture or tibial plafond fracture if there is involvement of the articular surface.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Bosworth fracture is the fracture-dislocation of the distal fibula wherein the proximal fragment of the fibula dislocated posteriorly behind the tibia.

questions.text: Toddler fracture involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tibia

 

Option B)

 

TODDLER FRACTURE

 

  • A toddler fracture is a minimally displaced or an undisplaced fracture of tibia.
  • It occurs in children of 9 months till 3 years of age due to newly developed stress on the bones as a result of increased locomotion.
  • Children typically with vague symptoms, not clearly related to the tibia. 
  • Usually, they refuse to weight-bear and are irritable.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Toddler’s fracture involves fracture of the tibia due to stress on the bone from increased locomotion.

choices.text: Diagnose rupture of Achilles tendon
Decide on treatment for CTEV
Decide on need of X-rays for possible fracture
Decide on immediate vs delayed treatment of ankle dislocation

questions.text: Ottawa ankle rules are used to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decide on need of X-rays for possible fracture

 

Option C)

 

OTTAWA ANKLE RULES

 

  • Ottawa ankle rules are specific clinical criteria which guide a clinician to identify individuals at higher risks of having fracture and require immediate X-ray.
  • These are as follows:
  1. Pain in the malleolar region.
  2. Bony tenderness along the distal 6 cm of the posterior edge of the lateral malleolus.
  3. Bony tenderness along the distal 6 cm of the posterior edge of the medial malleolus.
  4. Inability to bear weight on the ankle immediately after the injury.
  5. Inability to take 4 steps in emergency department.
  • Any one of these positive recommends immediate X-ray of the patient.
  • If X-ray examination is considered necessary, anteroposterior, lateral and mortise (30-degree oblique) views of the ankle should be obtained.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Diagnose rupture of Achilles tendon. This can be done by physical examination. If any 2 of the 4 tests are positive, the Achilles tendon is ruptured. These tests include positive Thompson test, decreased plantar flexion strength, presence of a palpable defect, and increased passive ankle dorsiflexion with gentle manipulation.

 

Option B. Decide on treatment for CTEV. The treatment for CTEV typically involves a combination of stretching, casting, bracing, and in some cases, surgery.

 

Option D. Decide on immediate vs delayed treatment of ankle dislocation. Ankle dislocation requires prompt medical attention, typically involving reduction and immobilization through casting or splinting. The decision regarding immediate or delayed treatment is made based on the severity of the dislocation, the presence of associated injuries, and the patient's overall condition.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ottawa ankle rules are used to decide the need of immediate x-rays for the possible fracture of the ankle.
  • If any of the 5 criterias are fulfilled, the patient requires an immediate x-ray investigation to take further treatment actions without any delay.
  • The criterias are:
  1. Pain around the malleolus
  2. Inability to take weight on the ankle immediately after the injury
  3. Inability to take four steps in Emergency Department
  4. Bony tenderness at the posterior edge or tip of the medial or lateral malleolus.

choices.text: Talonavicular and calcaneocuboid
Subtalar and calcaneocuboid
Subtalar and navicular
Subtalar and lisfranc’s

questions.text: In pronation of foot, the joints that become parallel are:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Talonavicular and calcaneocuboid

 

Option A)

 

FOOT PRONATION

 

  • Talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints are involved in the pronation of the foot.
  • During pronation, the foot undergoes a complex series of movements, including eversion of the subtalar joint and abduction of the forefoot.
  • As a result, the talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints align and become more parallel to each other.
  • This alignment facilitates the necessary flexibility and shock absorption required for the foot to adapt to uneven surfaces and absorb impact during walking or running.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Subtalar and calcaneocuboid. The Subtalar Joint is primarily responsible for the inversion and eversion of the foot. During pronation, the subtalar joint everts. Calcaneocuboid Joint is involved in the side-to-side movement of the foot. During pronation, the calcaneocuboid joint also facilitates the abduction of the forefoot. Both the subtalar and calcaneocuboid joints play significant roles in pronation. However, they do not necessarily become parallel during pronation.

 

Option C. Subtalar and navicular. The subtalar joint everts during pronation. The Navicular bone contributes to the flexibility and stability of the foot. During pronation, it moves downward and inward, allowing the foot to adapt to uneven surfaces. While both joints are involved in pronation, they also do not necessarily become parallel during the movement.

 

Option D. Subtalar and lisfranc’s. The subtalar joint undergoes eversion during pronation. Lisfranc's Joint is a complex joint located in the midfoot region, between the tarsal bones and the metatarsal bones. It plays a crucial role in maintaining the arch of the foot and transferring weight during walking and running. However, it is not considered a primary joint involved in pronation.

 

Educational objective:

 

While all other joints are involved in foot pronation to some extent, only talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints become parallel during the pronation movement.

choices.text: Intra-articular fracture distal tibia
Intra-articular fracture proximal tibia

questions.text: Pilon fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intra-articular fracture distal tibia

 

Option A)

 

PILON FRACTURE

 

  • The terms tibial plafond fracture, pilon fracture, and distal tibial explosion fracture all have been used to describe intra-articular fractures of the distal tibia.
  • It is the high energy axial compression force of the tibia as it acts as a pestle, driving vertically into the talus.
  • These fractures are often associated with severe bone comminution and soft tissue compromise.
  • Pilon fractures may also involve metaphyseal extension and can have associated fibular fractures.

 

 

Note: All fractures of the tibia involving the distal articular surface should be classified as pilon fractures, except for medial or lateral malleolar fractures and trimalleolar fractures, where the posterior malleolar fracture involves < 1/3rd of the articular surface.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Pilon fracture refers to the fractures of distal tibia which are intra-articular fractures.

questions.text: Unna boot is used for treatment of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Varicose ulcers

 

Option B)

 

UNNA BOOT

 

  • Unna Boot was made by Dr. Unna (dermatologist).
  • This was designed to prevent ulcers due to varicose veins and static dermatitis.

 

 

  • The Unna boot is a compressive dressing used in the treatment of venous stasis ulcers.
  • The gauze is applied wet, similar to a cast, and dries to form a semi rigid mould against the skin.
  • Unlike a cast, it allows unrestricted motion of the ankle joint.
  • The Unna boot provides high-pressure compression during muscle contraction (i.e., with activity) and low-pressure compression at rest, making it more comfortable for patients.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Diabetic foot ulcers. The total contact cast is a specific casting technique that is used to heal diabetic foot ulcers and to protect the foot during the early vulnerable phases of Charcot fracture dislocations. The cast heal diabetic foot ulcers by distributing weight along the entire sole of the foot.

 

Option C. Ankle instability. Treatment for ankle instability begins with a regimen of exercises intended to strengthen the muscles of the outer ankle, in an attempt to compensate for the loss of stability formerly provided by the ligament. While this treatment is helpful for many patients, it may be less successful in individuals whose muscles are already quite strong, such as dancers or other athletes. If instability is primarily a problem when participating in specific recreational activities, it may be addressed by taping the ankle and/or with the use of a brace, either one that is worn in an athletic shoe, or one that laces around the ankle.

 

Option D. Calcaneum fracture. Immobilization with splinting, Bulky Jones type splints are commonly applied. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The Unna boot is used for the prevention of ulcers from the varicose veins and static dermatitis.
  • This cast provides free ankle movement.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for fracture shaft femur in a child less than 2 years of age is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gallows traction

 

Option A)

 

PEDIATRIC FEMORAL SHAFT FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • For children under 2 years of age with a fracture of the femoral shaft, the treatment of choice is Gallows traction (also called Bryant's traction) because:

    • It is a non-operative and safe option for very young children.

    • It uses skin traction on both legs, with hips flexed to 90 and legs are suspended vertically.

    • It is effective for children <1012 kg and <2 years old, as their bones heal rapidly and remodeling is excellent.

 

 

  • For most proximal femoral fractures in children, treatment consists of closed reduction followed by a spica cast or open or closed reduction followed by internal fixation and a spica cast.
  • Non-operative treatment involves Pavlik harness in children < 6 months old with any fracture pattern, hip spica casting in children 0-5 years old (contraindicated with polytrauma, open fractures and shortening > 2-3 cm), and traction + delayed spica casting in younger patients with significant shortening.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hip spica. It is commonly used for children of age 26 years, but is less preferred in children <2 years of age due to practical and fitting issues. 

 

Option C. Russell traction. It is used for fracture shaft of femur in children of 2-10 years of age. It is more suitable for older children.

 

Option D. Intramedullary nail. It is used in children > 11 years of age. It is not suitable for infants due to open growth plates and small bone size.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • For the treatment of femoral shaft fracture in children < 2 years of age is Gallows traction.

questions.text: Hangman’s fracture is the fracture involving which cervical vertebra?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C2

 

Option B.

 

HANGMAN’S FRACTURE

 

  • It occurs when a fracture line passes through the neural arch of the axis (C2) vertebrae
  • It is the traumatic spondylolisthesis of axis (C2) vertebrae on C3 – H2 (Hangman’s involves 2nd Cervical Vertebra).
  • It is the bilateral fracture traversing the pars interarticularis of C2 with associated traumatic subluxation of C2 on C3.
  • It is the 2nd most common fracture of C2 following odontoid process fracture.
  • Common mechanism of injury is hyperextension and axial loading.

 

 

 

 

  • Classification of cervical spine injuries:

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hangman’s fracture is the fracture of the C2 vertebra pars interarticularis, associated with traumatic subluxation of C2 vertebra on C3.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Which of the following is an intra-articular fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D)

 

INTRA-ARTICULAR FRACTURES

 

  • An intra-articular fracture is a fracture that crosses a joint surface.
  • Such fractures also involve cartilage damage.
  • Also, the fractures might range from displaced to hairline fractures. 
  • Fractures to joints are more complicated to treat and heal than simple fractures, as multiple bones are involved.
  • Bone fragments inside the damaged joint may impede healing time and efficacy.
  • Intra-articular fractures commonly occur in the following areas:
    • Shoulder: Might affect the glenoid and articular cartilage, and also the humerus, scapula, acromion, and coracoid processes.
    • Hip: It could also affect the articular cartilage of the hip and a piece of the pelvis, as well as the head, upper neck, or head of the femur.
    • Elbow: It can affect the lower end of the humerus, the upper end of the radial and ulnar collateral ligaments, and the cartilage between the bones.
    • Wrist: It can affect the lower ends of the radius and ulna, the carpal bones, and the cartilage between the smaller carpal bones.
    • Knee: It can affect the lower edge of the femur, the patella, the upper edge of the tibia and/or fibula, and the articular cartilage and collateral ligaments.
    • Ankle: It may involve the lower edge of the tibia or fibula, the subtalar joint and articular cartilage, the anterior tibiofibular ligament, and the lateral collateral ligament.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Barton’s fracture. It is the intra-articular fracture of distal radius with dislocation of radiocarpal joint.

 

 

Option B. Bennett’s fracture. It is the intra-articular fracture of 1st metacarpal.

 

 

Option C. Pilon fracture. It is the intra-articulaar fracture of the distal tibia.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The intra-articular fractures are those whose fracture line crosses the joint surface.
  • Among the given options, all are the intra-articular fractures i.e., the Barton’s fracture, Bennett’s fracture, and Pilon fracture.

choices.text: Base of 5th metacarpal
Fracture neck of talus

questions.text: Chopart fracture involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Midtarsal joint

 

Option A)

 

CHOPART FRACTURE

 

  • Chopart fracture-dislocations occur at the midtarsal (Chopart) joint in the foot, i.e. talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints which separates the hindfoot from the midfoot.
  • The commonly fractured bones are the calcaneus, cuboid and navicular.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Tarsometatarsal joints. The fracture of the tarsometatarsal joint of the foot is called Lisfranc fracture-dislocation.

 

 

Option C. Base of 5th metacarpal. The fracture of the base of 5th metacarpal bone is called boxer’s fracture

 

Option D. Fracture neck of talus. The isolated fracture-dislocation of the talus is called the aviator’s fracture. It involves compression fracture of the talar neck, body and posterior process.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Chopart fracture is the fracture-dislocation of the midtarsal joint of the foot.
  • It is often associated with fracture of calcaneus, cuboid and navicular bones.
  • The midtarsal joint is composed of talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints.
  • The bones forming the chopart joint are the talus and calcaneus proximally, and the navicular and cuboid distally.

choices.text: Fracture-dislocation at the tarsometatarsal region
Avulsion of calcaneal tuberosity
Fracture neck of talus

questions.text: Lisfranc fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture-dislocation at the tarsometatarsal region

 

Option A)

 

LISFRANC FRACTURE

 

  • The Lisfranc joint is formed by the articulation between the metatarsal bones and tarsal bones (cuneiforms and cuboid). 
  • Lisfranc’s fracture-dislocation involves fracture-dislocation of the tarso-metatarsal articulation (lisfranc joint).
  • A Lisfranc injury characterized by traumatic disruption between the articulation of the medial cuneiform and base of the second metatarsal.
  • The usual mechanism is a direct blow or an indirect twisting force applied to a foot in plantar flexion 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by radiographs which may show widening of the interval between the 1st and 2nd ray.
  • Treatment is generally operative with either ORIF or arthrodesis.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lisfrance fracture is the fracture-dislocation of the tarsometatarsal joint of the foot i.e., the lisfranc joint.
  • It appears as a gap between the 1st and 2nd ray in the radiograph.

choices.text: Lower end tibia
Upper end tibia
Lower end femur
Upper end femur

questions.text: Tillaux fracture involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lower end tibia

 

Option A)

 

TILLAUX FRACTURE

 

  • Tillaux Fractures are traumatic ankle injuries in the pediatric population characterized by a Salter-Harris type III fracture of the anterolateral distal tibia epiphysis.

 

 

  • It occurs in older children and adolescents when the medial aspect of the distal tibial growth plate has started to fuse.
  • The fracture commonly results from a supination-external rotation mechanism, leading to the avulsion of the inferior anteroinferior tibiofibular ligament from the anterolateral corner of the distal tibial epiphysis.
  • Diagnosis can be made with plain radiographs of the ankle.
  • CT scan may be required to further characterize the fracture pattern and for surgical planning.
  • Treatment is closed reduction and casting if < 2mm displacement or operative management if > 2mm displacement.

 

Note: Salter-Harris Classification of physeal injuries

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tillaux fracture is the fracture of the anterolateral distal tibial epiphysis in children.
  • It is the Salter-Harris type 3 of fracture.

choices.text: Medial part of upper end tibia
Lateral part of upper end tibia
Medial part of lower end femur
Lateral part of lower end femur

questions.text: Bumper fracture involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral part of upper end tibia

 

Option B)

 

BUMPER FRACTURE

 

  • It is the comminuted fracture of the lateral tibial condyle.
  • It occurs when the bumper of the car comes in contact with the lateral side of the knee while the person is standing.
  • Specifically, it is caused by the forced valgus of the knee which causes the lateral part of the distal femur and lateral tibial plateau to come in contact, compressing the tibial plateau and causing its fracture.
  • Fracture of the neck of the fibula may also be found, and associated injury to the medial collateral ligament or cruciate ligaments occurs in about 10% of cases.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The bumper fracture involves the fracture of the lateral part of the upper end tibia i.e., the lateral tibial condyle/plateau.

questions.text: Malgaigne’s fracture involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelvis

 

Option A)

 

MALGAIGNE’S FRACTURE

 

  • Malgaigne fracture is an unstable type of pelvic fracture, which involves one hemipelvis, and results from vertical shear energy vectors.
  • One of the clinical features is shortening of the leg on the affected side.
  • It comprises of two ipsilateral pelvic ring fractures, which are vertically oriented anteriorly and posteriorly to the acetabulum.
  • Most commonly, there is disruption of the ipsilateral superior and inferior pubic rami and sacroiliac joint.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Malgaigne’s fracture is the unstable fracture of the pelvis that result from the vertical shear force.
  • It causes two ipsilateral pelvic ring fractures, and disruption of the superior/inferior pubic rami and SI joint.

questions.text: Occult fracture of neck of femur are best diagnosed by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRI

 

Option B:

 

OCCULT FRACTURE OF NECK OF FEMUR

 

  • Occult means hidden.
  • An occult fracture does not appear on an X-ray.
  • They cannot be detected by radiographic standard examination until several weeks after injury.
  • In the context of persistent hip pain, where plain radiographs and CT reveal no abnormality, consideration should be given to the use of MRI as it can be more accurate at detecting occult hip fractures.
  • Thus, MRI is indicated (investigation of choice) to evaluate for occult hip fractures.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Occult femoral neck fractures may not be easily diagnosed on a radiograph.
  • If occult femoral neck fracture is misdiagnosed, the non-displaced fracture may become displaced.
  • In this case, a patient may require treatment with hip arthroplasty.
  • MRI is one of the best tools for diagnosing occult fractures.
  • Other imaging modalities like bone scan, x-ray, and CT scan will not reveal the fracture until several weeks of injury.

questions.text: Site for 1st order bone grafting is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelvis

 

Option A:

 

1ST ORDER BONE GRAFTING

 

  • Bone grafting is a surgical procedure done in order to fill the defects in cortical and cancellous bones formed secondary to trauma, infection and other conditions.
  • This helps to fasten bone healing. 
  • Iliac crest is the site for 1st order bone grafting.
  • This is an ideal source of primary 1st order bone graft because it is relatively subcutaneous, has natural curvatures that are useful in fashioning grafts, has ample cancellous bone and has cortical bone of varying thickness.
  • Removal of bone carries minimal risk and usually has no significant residual disability.
  • Posterior superior iliac spine is the best source of cancellous bone graft.
  • Anterior iliac crest is the best source of bicortical and cortico-cancellous graft.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Iliac bone is the ideal source of 1st order primary bone grafting.

choices.text: Hypertrophy of abductor pollicis brevis

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of cervical syringomyelia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypertrophy of abductor pollicis brevis

 

Option A.

 

SYRINGOMYELIA

 

  • It is a fluid-filled cyst or cavity within the spinal cord.
  • This cyst, called a syrinx, can expand and elongate over time, destroying the spinal cord.
  • It can be congenital or acquired.
  • Congenital syringomyelia is associated with Arnold-Chiari malformation type-1, which involves herniation of cerebellar tonsils into the spinal canal.
  • Features:
    • Asymmetric weakness
    • Burning pain-like sensation in the shoulder and arm – cape-like/suspended distribution
    • Loss of biceps jerk
    • Increased tone and hyperreflexia of lower limb
    • Wasting of hand (not hypertrophy)

 

 

Syringomyelia involving the cervicothoracic portion of the spinal cord

 

  • It acts as LMN lesion for upper limb (weakness, absent DTRs, atrophy of hands) and UMN lesion for lower limb (spasticity, extensor plantar response).
  • Diagnostic modality is MRI

 

 

  • Management:
    • Treatment is surgical.
    • 17-50 % of patient have no progression of syrinx or symptoms over a 10-year follow up period.
    • Chiari-related syrinx has 90% effective outcome with surgical management.

 

Note: All treatment strategies are directed towards improving CSF dynamics.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Burning sensation in arm; Option C. Biceps reflex absent; and Option D. Extensor plantar response are present in cervical syringomyelia.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In cervical syringomyelia, there is no hypertrophy of the hand muscles, instead there is wasting of the hand muscles especially the abductor pollicis brevis.

choices.text: Anterior cord syndrome
Posterior cord syndrome
Complete spinal cord injury

questions.text: A 40-year-old male after RTA, attains spinal injury. His lower limb power is greater than that of upper limb and sacral sensations are present. Type of spinal cord lesion is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Central cord syndrome

 

Option A.

 

CENTRAL CORD SYNDROME

 

  • Most common form of incomplete spinal cord injury.
  • It leads to motor deficits that are more pronounced in the upper extremities compared to the lower extremities, as well as bladder dysfunction with sacral sparing.
  • Results following a hyperextension injury of the cervical spine leading to spinal cord impingement by bony spurs or intervertebral disc and posteriorly by the ligamentum flavum.
  • On examination, patients will have more strength impairments in the upper extremities (especially the hands) compared to the lower extremities.
  • Patients may complain of sensory deficits below the level of injury.
  • Pain and temperature sensations are affected, but the sensation of light touch can also be impaired.
  • The most common sensory deficits are in a "cape-like" distribution across upper back and down the posterior upper extremities.
  • There is neck pain at the site of spinal cord impingement.
  • Bladder dysfunction (most commonly urinary retention) and priapism can also be signs of upper motor neuron dysfunction.
  • The sacral sensation is usually preserved, but the clinician should assess the rectal tone to evaluate the severity of the compression.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C. Posterior cord syndrome. Posterior cord syndrome is a condition caused by lesion of the posterior portion of the spinal cord, responsible for proprioceptive sensibility. Main signs and symptoms are loss of proprioception and vibration sensation, ataxic gait, positive Romberg sign, hypotonia, and abolition of deep tendon reflexes.

 

Option D. Complete spinal cord injury. These injuries typically demonstrate complete bilateral loss of motor function, pain sensation, temperature sensation, proprioception, vibratory sensation, and tactile sensation below the level of injury. Lumbosacral injuries will present with paralysis and loss of sensation in the lower extremities. These injuries may also result in loss of bowel control, loss of bladder control, and sexual dysfunction. Thoracic injuries lead to the same deficits as lumbosacral injuries and, in addition, may result in loss of function of the muscles of the torso, leading to difficulty maintaining posture. Cervical injuries lead to the same deficits as thoracic injuries and, also, may result in loss of function of the upper extremities leading to tetraplegia. Injuries above C5 may also cause respiratory compromise due to loss of innervation of the diaphragm.

 

Difference between various spinal cord injury syndromes:

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lower limb muscle power > upper limb muscle power, and sparing of sacral sensation are the main characteristic features of central cord syndrome.

choices.text: Anesthesia below the level of the lesion
Areflexia below the level of the lesion

questions.text: Complete transection of the spinal cord at the C7 level produces all of the following effects except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Areflexia below the level of the lesion

 

Option D.

 

  • The diaphragm is innervated by two phrenic nerves that originate as branches of the cervical plexus in neck. This motor nerve to diaphragm arises from the anterior rami of cervical nerves C3, C4, C5, with major contribution coming from C4.
  • So, transection of spinal cord at C7 level is not going to stop respiration but due to involvement of thoracic intercostal muscles and abdominal muscles, there will be some weakness of respiratory effort (i.e., limited respiratory effort).
  • Deep tendon reflexes above the level of complete spinal cord injury will be spared; at the level of injury will be absent and below the level of injury will be exaggerated.
  • Superficial reflexes above the level of injury are spared and at the level of injury and below the level of injury are absent.

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Complete transection of the spinal cord at C7 level produces hypotension, limited respiratory effort, and anesthesia below the level of lesion.
  • Reflexes below the level of lesion will be exaggerated and not absent.

questions.text: Left-Right movement of skull occurs at:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atlanto-axial joint

 

Option B.

 

CERVICAL SPINE MOVEMENTS

 

  • The cervical spine's range of motion is approximately 80° to 90° of flexion, 70° of extension, 20° to 45° of lateral flexion, and up to 90° of rotation to both sides.
  • Yes or No movement primarily occurs at atlanto-occipital joint.

 

 

  • Right and left rotatory movements occurs at atlanto-axial joint.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atlanto-occipital joint. At this joint, the yes/no nodding movements occurs.

 

Option C. C2-C3 and Option D. C6-C7 shows flexion-extension movements wherein, C2-C3 movement is less than the C6-C7 movement.

 

Educational objective:

 

The left-right movement of the neck occurs at the atlanto-axial joint.

questions.text:
True about fractures of vertebrae is/are: 

 

  1. Wedge compression causes flexion injury
  2. Anterior longitudinal ligament runs along the posterior surface of the vertebral bodies
  3. Vertical compression force does not extend to cervical spine
  4. Chance fracture occurs due to flexion distraction injury
  5. Fracture dislocation is common in flexion rotation injury
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4, 5

 

Option D.

 

VERTEBRAL FRACTURES

 

  • Mechanism of spinal injury:
  1. Flexion injury: leads to anterior wedge fracture of vertebral body and disruption of posterior longitudinal ligament/interspinous ligament
  2. Extension injury: posterior element fracture and anterior longitudinal ligament rupture and subluxation
  3. Axial loading: leads to burst fracture and lateral element fracture
  4. Rotation injury: leads to lateral mass fracture and facet subluxation

 

Explanation:

 

1. Wedge compression fracture of the vertebra is caused by flexion injury of the spine, due to axial/compressive loading. 

 

2. Anterior longitudinal ligament runs along the anterior surface of body and posterior longitudinal ligament over the posterior surface. Interspinous ligament runs along between spinous process.

 

 

3. Vertical compression forces extends down the cervical spine leading to compressive injuries.

 

 

4. Chance fracture is a horizontal fracture of the thoracolumbar junction, extending posterior to anterior through the spinous process, pedicle, and vertebral body. It is a flexion-distraction injury of the spine.

 

 

5. Fracture-dislocation is common in flexion-rotation injury due to high energy trauma.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Compressive wedge fracture of the vertebrae are caused by flexion injury to the spine.
  • Chance fracture or the horizontal splitting of the vertebra is caused by flexion-distraction forces.
  • Flexion-rotation injury of the spine commonly causes fracture-dislocation of the vertebra.

choices.text: A fall from a height
Acute hyperextension of the spine
A blow on top to head
Acute hyperflexion of the spine

questions.text: ‘Whiplash’ injury is caused due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute hyperextension of the spine

 

Option B.

 

WHIPLASH INJURY

 

  • Whiplash injury is caused by sudden unexpected hyperextension of cervical spine followed immediately by flexion.
  • Most cases of whiplash are caused by car accidents where the person has been rear-ended.
  • Other potential whiplash causes (rare), can include assault, bungee jumping, rollercoaster, football, falls while skiing or during equestrian events.
  • Whiplash is medically known as cervical acceleration-deceleration (CAD) syndrome.
  • The most common symptom of whiplash is neck pain, which can be mild or feels like pins-and-needles tingling or can be excruciating.
  • Other symptoms can include neck stiffness or reduced range of motion, neck instability, shoulder and/or upper back pain, or headache.
  • There could also be tingling, weakness, or numbness that radiates into the shoulder and/or down the arm.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A fall from a height. High falls were more likely to be work-related and result in thoracic and complete injury, while low falls were more commonly associated with cervical and motor functionally incomplete injury.

 

Option D. Acute hyperflexion of the spine. Hyperflexion sprain or anterior subluxation of the cervical spine is characterized by a localized ligamentous disruption of the cervical spine, cau- sed by a distractive flexion force. In addition, the cranial vertebra may be displaced. The lesion is sometimes associated with a minor wedge-like compression of one or two vertebral bodies. The hyperflexion sprain is a relatively rare injury.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Whiplash injury is the acute hyperextension injury of the spine caused by sudden hyperextension of the neck followed by immediate hyperflexion.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statement about lordosis:

 

  1. Lordosis means excessive inward curvature of the spine
  2. Can be seen in Osteoporotic females
  3. Mostly seen in lumbar region and manifests as persistent back pain
  4. Poor posture is a common cause of lordosis
  5. Obesity protects against developing lordosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Option D.

 

LORDOSIS

 

  • Lordosis is inward curvature of spine seen at cervical and lumbar spine.
  • Causes of increased lordosis are SOAP.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lordosis is the excessive inward curvature of the spine.
  • It is most commonly seen in osteoporotic females and poor posture.
  • The most commonly affected segment of the spine is the lumbar spine, which manifests as persistent back pain.
  • Obesity is also one of the cause of development of lordosis.

questions.text: Bryant’s triangle is useful in diagnosis of all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Infra-trochanteric shortening

 

Option B:

 

Explanation:

 

BRYANT’S TRIANGLE

 

  • Measures Supra-trochanteric area
  • The patient lies supine and tips of trochanter and ASIS are marked on both sides.
  • A perpendicular is dropped from each ASIS on to the bed.
  • From tip of greater trochanter, another perpendicular is dropped on to the first one (base of the triangle).
  • Now, join the tips of greater trochanter to ASIS on respective side.
  • Each side of this right-angled triangle is compared with its counterpart on the normal side.
  • Any shortening of the base (i.e., femoral axis continuation), which may be because of shortening in the neck, head, joint or dislocation of joint can be measured.

 

 

  • Bryant’s triangle is on no value in: (Mnemonic: ABC)
    • ASIS absent
    • Bilateral disease
    • Chopped hip (hip disarticulated)

       
  • Reversed Bryant’s triangle:
    • When the proximal migration of the tip of greater trochanter is beyond the ASIS, then reversed Bryant’s triangle is drawn.
    • Total supratrochanteric shortening will be the summation of base of triangle on normal side and the base of triangle in abnormal side.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Bry ant’s triangle is mainly used to measure supratrochanteric shortening in anterior and posterior hip dislocation cases.

questions.text: A patient came with complaint of difficulty in climbing upstairs. When he is made to stand on his right leg, left side of pelvis fell to a lower level. When he stands on left leg, then right side of pelvis can be drawn up. Which of the following nerve of him has got affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right superior gluteal nerve

 

Option B:

 

  • The described information is about the Trendelenburg sign.

 

Explanation:

 

TRENDELENBURG SIGN

 

  • Normally when the body weight is supported on one limb, the glutei (medius and minimus) of the supported side contract and raise the opposite and unsupported side of pelvis, if the abductor mechanism is defective the unsupported side of pelvis drops and this is known as positive Trendelenburg's test.
  • Trendelenburg's test is done to assess the integrity of abductor mechanism.
  • It is positive in the conditions in which any of the three—fulcrum (Femoral Head), lever arm (neck length) or power (muscles/nerve) is affected.

 

 

 

  • The hip abductors become weak due to damage to the superior gluteal nerve.
  • On standing on the affected leg, the pelvis drops towards the unaffected side. This indicates that the superior gluteal nerve of the affected side has been damaged.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the given question, the pelvic drop to the left side while standing on the right leg is indicative of the right superior gluteal nerve damage.

choices.text: Fixed flexion deformity of the hip
Apparent shortening at the hip Joint

questions.text: Thomas test helps to detect:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fixed flexion deformity of the hip

 

Option C:

 

THOMAS TEST

 

  • It is done to measure fixed flexion deformity of hip by neutralizing lumbar lordosis.
  • Up to 30 degree flexion deformity of hip can be compensated by lumbar lordosis.
  • Steps:
    • Ask the patient to lie down with their legs hanging off the edge.
    • Look for exaggerated lumbar lordosis.
    • Bring one knee towards the chest of the patient, keeping the other leg flat on the table.
    • Pelvis' stabilization by placing one hand on the ASIS of the leg being tested.
    • Observe the opposite leg for any lifting of the lower back (over correction of the normal side.) Avoid it by ensuring that ischial tuberosity touches the flat surface.
    • Slowly extend the opposite hip by lowering the patient's leg towards the table while maintaining the knee-to-chest posture.
    • Look for any compensatory movements.
       

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Adduction deformity of hip. To check the adductor muscle shortening or strength, adductor squeeze test or Phelp’s test are done.

 

Option B: Integrity of abductor mechanism. This is tested by the Trendelenburg test.

 

Option D: Apparent shortening at the hip joint. This is tested by measuring the leg length in the patient.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Thomas test is used to assess the fixed flexion deformity of the hip flexor muscles.

questions.text: Trendelenburg test would be positive in the following conditions:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L4-L5 PIVD

 

Option A:

 

Explanation:

 

TRENDELENBURG TEST

 

  • Trendelenburg's test is done to assess the integrity of abductor mechanism.
  • It is positive in the conditions in which any of the three—fulcrum (Femoral Head), lever arm (neck length) or power (muscles/nerve) is affected.
  • Disc prolapse at L4–L5 compresses L5 nerve root which supplies gluteus medius and minimus.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Trendelenburg test is positive in case of L4-L5 PIVD because the L5 nerve root supplies the gluteus muscles that are tested in this test.
  • The other options do not affect the gluteus muscles, hence the test is not relevant in these conditions.

questions.text: Identify the test being performed in the image below.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thomas test

 

Option B:

 

THOMAS TEST

 

  • It is used to measure fixed flexion deformity of hip by neutralizing lumbar lordosis.
  • Up to 30° flexion deformity of hip can be compensated by lumbar lordosis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Trendelenburg test. It is done to check the integrity of the hip abductor mechanism.

 

 

Option C: Smith test. There is no such test for orthopedic testing.

 

Option D: Narath test or Vascular sign of narath is positive in posterior dislocation of hip joint where, due to posterior dislocation, the hip joint falls on the femoral artery, and this causes feeble or absent femoral pulse.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image shows Thomas test, done to evaluate the tightness of the hip flexors.

choices.text: Anterior segment is not visualized adequately
Sciatic nerve injury in 10% in the cases

questions.text: Which is not true about Langen beck Kocher operation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sciatic nerve injury in 10% in the cases

 

Option D:

 

KOCHER-LANGENBECK APPROACH

 

  • This is a posterior approach used for all posterior wall, posterior column, and posterior column plus posterior wall fractures of acetabulum.
  • It is also used for most transverse and transverse plus posterior wall fracture and many T-shaped fractures.
  • It allows complete exposure of (posterior) retro-acetabular surface caudally (distally) as far as the ischial tuberosity.
  • The greater and lesser sciatic notches are visualized.
  • But the anterior and superior exposure is limited.
  • Osteotomy of greater trochanter (digastric osteotomy) allows increased anterior iliac exposure but proximal (superior) access is still largely limited by superior gluteal neurovascular bundle.
     

 

Area of pelvis accessible with Kocher Langenbeck approach

 

  • Incidence of sciatic nerve injury is 2–6% (older studies explain wider range).

 

 

(add image)

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The Kocher Langenbeck operation is a posterior approach for posterior wall and/or posterior column injuries.
  • It provides an adequate exposure to the posterior segments.
  • The exposure to the anterior and superior segments is limited with this approach.
  • The incidence of sciatic nerve injury with this approach is around 2-6%.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female lands up in emergency with history of fall. The attitude of limb is extension and external rotation. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intracapsular fracture neck of femur

 

Option A:

 

INTRACAPSULAR NECK OF FEMUR FRACTURE

 

  • Usually, if it is mentioned that 60–70-Year-old female with fracture proximal femur, the diagnosis is fracture neck of femur and if they ask about an 80-year-old individual, then diagnosis is intertrochanteric fracture.
  • This is subjected to limited features given in question but if they mention partial external rotation of lower limb and limited shortening, then it is intracapsular fracture neck femur and if it mentions complete external rotation i.e., lateral border of foot touches the bed, then intertrochanteric fracture is a possibility.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Posterior dislocation of hip. Patients with a posterior dislocation present with a limb adducted, flexed, internally rotated, and shortened. 

 

Option C: Intertrochanteric fracture. It is seen in patients > 80 years of age. The limb appears shortened and externally rotated with the lateral border of foot touching the couch.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the given case scenario, the patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of fall and limb attitude of extension and external rotation.
  • This is suggestive of intracapsular femoral neck fracture because the age is more than 60 and the limb is in external rotation deformity.

choices.text: Subcapital capsular fracture neck of femur

questions.text: The commonest hip injury in the elderly patients is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Extracapsular fracture

 

Option B:

 

HIP FRACTURE IN ELDERLY

 

  • Hip fractures among the geriatric population are a major cause of morbidity and mortality.
  • One-year mortality rate after hip fractures is estimated to be as high as 30%.
  • The femoral neck is the common site of fracture in the elderly.
  • Moreover, fracture intertrochanteric femur (extracapsular) occurs in elderly patients even more than fractures of femoral neck itself.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Stress fracture. Stress fractures typically result from repetitive stress or overuse rather than acute trauma, and they are more commonly seen in athletes or individuals engaged in high-impact activities.

 

Option C: Impacted fracture neck of femur. This type of fracture, also known as a subcapital fracture, occurs within the neck of the femur but is impacted, i.e., the fractured segments are driven into each other. While impacted fractures are relatively common in elderly patients, they are generally less frequent than extracapsular fractures.

 

Option D: Subcapital capsular fracture neck of femur. This option refers to fractures that occur just below the head of the femur and involve the capsule of the hip joint. These fractures are also relatively common in the elderly population but are less frequent than extracapsular fractures.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most commonly seen hip fracture in the elderly population is the extracapsular fracture which involves intertrochanteric fractures.
  • This is followed by the fracture of the neck of the femur.

choices.text: Intracapsular fracture neck of femur

questions.text: A 60-year-old man fell in bathroom and was unable to stand. On right buttock region, ecchymosis was present with external rotation of the leg in a way that the lateral border of foot is touching the bed. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extracapsular fracture neck of femur

 

Option A:    

 

EXTRACAPSULAR NECK OF FEMUR FRACTURE

 

  • Lateral border of foot touching the bed means that there is extreme external rotation.
  • This occurs in intertrochanteric fractures.
  • Note that external rotation is present in both extracapsular and intracapsular fractures, but foot border touching the bed suggests extreme external rotation, which is suggestive of extracapsular fracture.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Anterior dislocation of hip. Superior anterior dislocations classically present with the hip extended and externally rotated while inferior anterior dislocations generally present with the hip abducted and externally rotated.

 

 

Option C: Intracapsular fracture neck of femur. This presents as shortened limb with abduction and partial external rotation.

 

 

Option D: Posterior dislocation of hip. Patients with a posterior dislocation present with a limb adducted, flexed, internally rotated, and shortened.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The presence of ecchymosis on the hip region after a fall in an elderly patient is seen in the extracapsular fracture of the hip.
  • The extracapsular fracture presents with limb shortening and extreme external rotation deformity of the hip where the lateral border of the foot touches the couch.

questions.text: Most common complication of intertrochanteric fracture femur is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malunion

 

Option A:

 

COMPLICATIONS OF INTERTROCHANTERIC FEMUR FRACTURE

 

  • Most common complications of intracapsular fracture → AVN followed by non-union.
  • Most common complication of extracapsular fracture → Malunion.

 

 

  • Early complications include:
    • DVT
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Pressure sores
    • Hemorrhage if the fracture occurs at a site of ample blood supply
       
  • Late complications include:
    • Fixation failure if the bone is osteoporotic
    • Malunion leading to varus and external rotation deformities
    • Non-union

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common complication of the extracapsular fractures (e.g., intertrochanteric femoral fracture) is malunion.
  • Non-union can also be a complication but malunion is most commonly seen.

choices.text: Plaster in abduction and internal rotation

questions.text: Trochanteric fracture of femur is best treated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dynamic hip screw

 

Option A:

 

FEMUR TROCHANTERIC FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • Dynamic hip screw (DHS) plate is the implant of choice for trochanteric fracture fixation.

 

 

 

(add image)

 

  • These days, proximal femoral nail (PFN) is preferred. It is a variety of cephalon-medullary fixation.

 

 

 

(add image)

 

  • DHS is preferred in undisplaced fractures while PFN is preferred in displaced fractures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Inlay plates. Inlay plates are not used in the treatment of trochanteric fractures of the femur. These fractures usually involve the proximal portion of the femur, such as the greater or lesser trochanter, and are commonly treated with devices specifically designed for stabilization, such as dynamic hip screws or intramedullary nails.

 

Option C: Plaster in abduction. Plaster immobilization in abduction is not the standard treatment for trochanteric fractures. Trochanteric fractures often require surgical intervention for proper alignment and stabilization, as immobilization in plaster alone may not provide adequate support and could lead to malunion or nonunion.

 

Option D: Plaster in abduction and internal rotation. While immobilizing the limb in abduction might theoretically reduce tension on the fracture site, adding internal rotation is not typically recommended for trochanteric fractures. Internal rotation could potentially worsen the displacement of the fracture fragments or lead to malalignment during the healing process.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Trochanteric fractures of the femur are best treated by the dynamic hip screw or proximal femoral nailing as it provides greater stability to the fracture fragments.

choices.text: Upper third of shaft
Middle third of shaft
Lower third of shaft

questions.text: The femur is fractured in children from:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper third of shaft

 

Option A)

 

FEMUR FRACTURE IN CHILDREN

 

  • In children, the most common location of fracture is the upper 1/3rd of femur.
  • The most common mechanism of injury is the direct trauma or a twisting injury.
  • During birth through breech delivery, the fracture can occur and often missed. But this is an uncommon cause of fracture in children.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Middle third of shaft. Birth fractures from obstetric trauma occur in the middle 1/3rd shaft of the femur.

 

Option C. Lower third of shaft. Greenstick fractures are more common in the distal 1/3rd of the shaft of femur.

 

Option D. Neck region. Proximal femur fracture in children are rarely seen.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common location of fracture in children is the upper 1/3rd of the shaft of the femur.

questions.text: Tube (Cylinder) cast is applied for the fracture of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Knee

 

Option D)

 

TUBE CAST

 

  • Cylinder cast in full extension is given for undisplaced patella fractures or knee injuries.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Shoulder. For shoulder fractures, shoulder spicas are used that fit around the torso to support the shoulder and the arm.

 

Option B. Hip. A hip spica cast that extends from the mid-chest down to the ankle is used for hip fractures.

 

Option C. Pelvis. A spica cast may be a useful adjunctive method for decreasing blood loss in the immediate post-injury period.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A tube or cylinder cast is used for the treatment of the undisplaced patella fractures or knee injuries.

choices.text: Closed reduction with cylinder cast
Open reduction with screw fixation of the fragments
Blind fixation of the two fragments with Kirschner-wire
Open reduction with Kirschner-wire fixation of the fragment with tension band wiring

questions.text: Transverse fracture of the patella with separation of fragments is best treated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Open reduction with Kirschner-wire fixation of the fragment with tension band wiring

 

Option D)

 

TRANSVERSE FRACTURE PATELLA TREATMENT

 

  • 2-part fracture patella are best fixed with tension band principle where the distraction force is converted to compression force.
  • This fixation requires open reduction.
  • Tension band wiring is done with the use of Kirschner wire (K-wire) or stainless steel wire.
  • The quadriceps produces significant forces on patellar fractures which cause early fixation failure.
  • For this reason, screw fixation alone usually fails.
  • In addition to fracture stability, tension band wiring allows early range of motion of the knee which is advantageous.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Closed reduction with cylinder cast. This could be attempted if fragments are undisplaced. In the above question, it clearly states separated fragments, thus a cylinder cast will not help with fracture fixation. 

 

Option B. Open reduction with screw fixation of the fragments. This is one of the method of fixation but not the best treatment method.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A transverse fracture of the patella should be treated by open reduction with K-wire fixation with the tension band wiring method.

choices.text: Strain of valgus knee
Strain of varus knee
Strain of valgus knee with axial loading

questions.text: Mechanism of injury in lateral condylar fracture of proximal tibia is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strain of valgus knee with axial loading

 

Option C)

 

LATERAL CONDYLAR FRACTURE OF PROXIMAL TIBIA

 

  • A valgus force is the force which pushes the knee outward, away from the midline.
  • It leads to buckling of the knee in a valgus direction.
  • Axial loading is the application of the vertical compressive forces along the long axis of the bone.
  • It acts to compress the bone.
  • Combined together, these two forces cause excessive stress on the lateral condyle of the tibia which gets fractured.
  • Classification of various forces causing injuries to the knee are:

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Strain on valgus knee. Strain on a valgus knee causes depression of the lateral condyle of the proximal tibia and fracture/subluxation of the medial condyle.

 

Option B. Strain on varus knee. Strain on the varus knee causes medial condyle fracture with/without coronal split, and lateral condyle fracture/subluxation.

 

Option D. Rotational injury. Rotational injury at the knee causes injury to the cruciate ligaments of the knee, especially the ACL.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The mechanism of lateral tibial condylar fracture is the strain on the valgus knee with axial loading.
  • Along the lateral condylar fracture, there is medial condylar subluxation also present.

questions.text:
Regarding cast application, choose the correct statement. 

 

1. In the process of applying the cast, the casting material is first dried and then applied

2. Compartment syndrome is a major complication caused by a tight or rigid cast that constricts a limb

3. Help in immobilizing the injured limb to keep the bone in place until it fully heals

4. Casts are circumferential immobilization, whereas splints are non-circumferential immobilizers

5. Plaster of Paris is CaSO4 ½ H2O
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 4, 5

 

Option D)

 

CAST APPLICATION

 

  • Plaster of Paris is CaSO4. 1/2 H2O.
  • Average setting time is 7–10 minutes.
  • Drying time (time taken for the POP to convert from crystalline form to anhydrous from):
    • Arm cast: 24–36 hours
    • Leg cast: 48–60 hours
  • Dip the POP vertically.
  • Cold water will maximize the moulding time.
  • Complications:
    • Due to tight cast:
      • Pain
      • Pressure sores
      • Compartment syndrome
      • Peripheral nerve injury
    • Due to improper application:
      • Plaster blisters
      • Breakage
      • Loose cast
    • Due to allergy:
      • Allergic dermatitis
    • Others:
      • Muscle wasting
      • Skin abrasion/laceration

 

Other options:

 

1. In the process of applying the cast, the casting material is first dried and then applied. This statement is incorrect. In the process of applying a cast, the casting material, typically fiberglass or plaster, is not dried before application. Instead, it is usually soaked in water to activate its adhesive properties and make it pliable. Once it is sufficiently wetted, it is applied to the affected limb, where it gradually hardens as it dries. The drying process occurs after the cast has been applied to the patient.

 

2. Compartment syndrome is a major complication caused by a tight or rigid cast that constricts the limb. This statement is correct. Compartment syndrome can occur when there's excessive pressure within the muscles compartments of the limb, often due to tight or rigid casts that restrict blood flow.

 

3. Help in immobilizing the injured limb to keep the bone in place until it fully heals. This statement is correct. One of the primary purposes of applying a cast is to immobilize the injured limb, which helps in keeping the bone in place during the healing process.

 

4. Casts are circumferential immobilization, whereas splints are non-circumferential immobilizers. This statement is correct. Casts typically encircle the limb completely, providing a circumferential immobilization, while splints are often non-circumferential, offering support to the injured area without completely encircling it.

 

5. Plaster of Paris is CaSO4 ½ H2O. This statement is correct. Plaster of Paris is indeed a form of calcium sulfate hemihydrate (CaSO4 · 1/2 H2O).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Before the application of cast, the cast is soaked in water and once it is sufficiently wet, it is applied to the limb.
  • When a tight or rigid cast is applied, compartment syndrome is the major complication.
  • The casts help in immobilizing the limb by keeping the bone at its place until it fully heals.
  • Casts encircles the limb providing a circumferential immobilization while the splints offer support only to the injured area and thus, are non-circumferential immobilizers.
  • Plaster of Paris in the cast is a form of calcium sulfate hemihydrate i.e., CaSO4 1/2H2O.

questions.text: In Intra-articular fracture of calcaneum, Gissane’s angle is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased

 

Option B)

 

CRUCIAL ANGLE OF GISSANE

 

  • It is a measurement on lateral foot radiographs used to evaluate the severity of calcaneal fractures.
  • Formed by two cortical struts extending laterally, one along the lateral margin of posterior facet and other extending to the beak of the calcaneus.
  • Normally, it is an obtuse angle of 95–105 degree.
  • It increases in intra-articular fractures.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The Gissane angle is used for the assessment of severity of the calcaneal fractures along with the Bohler’s angle.
  • In calcaneum fractures, Gissane’s angle is increased while the Bohler’s angle is decreased.

questions.text: Spinal injury with no radiological finding is commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Children

 

Option A.

 

SCIWORA

 

  • Spinal Cord Injury Without Obvious Radiological Abnormality is seen in children due to flexibility of spine.
  • SCIWORA is used to describe a spinal cord injury that does not show any radiographic abnormalities on imaging studies like X-ray or CT scans.
  • Mechanism: It mainly occurs due to hyperflexion or hyperextension of the spinal cord without any accompanying fractures or dislocations of the vertebrae.
  • Age group: It mainly occurs in children (particularly in less than 8 years of age).
  • Best Investigation to pick up SCIWORA – MRI.

 

Education objective:

 

  • Spinal cord injuries without any radiological finding are commonly seen in children < 8 years of age.
  • Clinical symptoms of traumatic myelopathy with no radiographic or computed tomographic features of spinal fracture or instability.
  • Such injury requires high suspicion and should be evaluated with MRI with associated clinical symptoms.

choices.text: Fractures of both bones of the forearm

questions.text: Functional bracing is now the gold standard in non-operative management of which fractures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture shaft humerus

 

Option A)

 

FUNCTIONAL BRACING

 

  • Also called as sarmiento brace, it is a type of bracing where the limb is allowed to do restricted function with the brace in.
  • Principle:
    • Continuing function while a fracture is uniting
    • Encourages osteogenesis
    • Promotes the healing of tissues
    • Prevents the development of joint stiffness
    • Accelerates rehabilitation
  • Functional bracing has become the preferred approach in the non-operative management of certain fractures due to its advantages in promoting early mobility and reducing the risk of complications.
  • Functional bracing is an effective therapeutic modality in the management of selected fractures of the tibia, humerus, and ulna, particularly low-energy injuries.
  • In the case of tibial fractures, it is applicable only to reduced transverse fractures and to axially unstable fractures with an acceptable degree of shortening.
  • Functional bracing for the treatment of fractures of the humeral diaphysis is associated with a high rate of union, particularly when used for closed fractures.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Functional bracing is useful for the fractures of diaphysis of the humerus i.e., the humeral shaft fractures.

questions.text: Traction not used in lower limb is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dunlop traction

 

Option C)

 

COMMON TRACTIONS

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Out of the given options, Dunlop traction is an upper limb traction used for the management of supracondylar humerus fracture.
  • Other tractions are used in the management of femoral shaft fractures.
  • Gallow’s and Bryant’s are used in children while the Perkin’s is used in adults.

questions.text: All of the following are used for giving skeletal traction, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rush pin

 

Option D)

 

RUSH PIN

 

  • Rush pin is used for fixation of fracture shaft femur in children.
  • Rush Nails are intended for fractures of Diaphyseal or Metaphyseal fractures of long bones like Femur, Tibia, Fibula, Humerus, Radius, and Ulna.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Rush pins are used for the intramedullary fixation of the long bone fractures, especially the femoral shaft fractures in children.
  • They are not used for skeletal traction.
  • Fir skeletal traction, steinmann’s pins, K-wires and Bohler’s stirrup are used.

questions.text: Which is not a deep heat therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Infrared therapy

 

Option C:

 

HEAT THERAPY

 

  • Superficial: Only superficial structures, i.e. skin and subcutaneous tissues are heated by:
  • Hot bath/packs (kenny packs)/soaks/compresses/water bottle
  • Chemical packs
  • Paraffin wax bath
  • Infrared lamp
  • Moist air cabinet
  • Deep Therapy: Deeper structures, i.e. muscles are heated by:
  • Shortwave diathermy: Heat generated by high frequency alternating current using a short-wave diathermy emitter.
  • Microwave diathermy: This uses electromagnetic radiation energy to heat the deep tissues.
  • Ultrasound therapy or ultrasonic therapy: Uses high frequency sound energy
  • Electrotherapy:
  • Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation: low frequency therapy
  • Interferential therapy: high frequency therapy

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Infrared therapy is a superficial heating modality which causes local cutaneous vasodilation and leads to pain relief.
  • The other modalities mentioned i.e., shortwave diathermy, ultrasound therapy and microwave therapy are deep heating modalities.

questions.text:
Which of the following condition should be given most priority in case of fracture?

 

  1. Open fracture
  2. Dislocated fracture
  3. Vascular injury
  4. Malunited fracture
  5. Compartment syndrome
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 5

 

Option D:

 

TIMING OF SURGERY

 

  • Emergency: Emergency surgery is done for life and limb threatening problems. Examples are:
  • Fracture or dislocation with vascular injury (most important knee dislocation)
  • Fractures with compartment syndrome
  • Irreducible dislocation or fracture dislocation of major joint.
  • Compound (open) fractures
  • Septic arthritis
  • Spinal injuries with deteriorating neurological deficit.
  • Urgency: Urgent surgery is the surgery which should be done early (within 12–36 hours). Examples are:
    • Intra-articular fractures
    • Fracture neck femur
    • Fracture lateral condyle humerus in children
    • Displaced supracondylar fracture humerus in children
  • Elective: Elective surgery is planned properly and can be done even after some delay (3–4 days to 3–4 weeks). Most of the surgeries in orthopedics are elective. Example are:
  • Closed fracture long bone
  • Joint replacement
  • Most of the arthroscopic procedures

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In case of a fracture presenting following a trauma, the priority is given to the management of the open fracture, a dislocation of the fragments, vascular injuries and compartment syndrome in the extremity.
  • Malunion fractures may or may not require surgical intervention.

questions.text:
True about Locking compression plate are: 

 

  1. In osteoporotic patients, it should not be used
  2. Can be used as buttress plate
  3. Usually cause periosteal injury
  4. Mechanically superior to a conventional plate
  5. Cannot be used as compression plate
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 4

 

Option D:

 

LOCKING COMPRESSION PLATE

 

  • Avoid “compression” in osteoporotic bone but “locking” is beneficial.
  • Newer diagnosis – no periosteal injury.
  • The Locking Compression Plate (LCP) system is part of a stainless steel or titanium plate and screw system that merges locking screw technology with conventional plating techniques.

 

 

  • Indications for use of locking compression plate:
  • Fractures associated with higher risk of loss of reduction
  • Comminuted intraarticular fracture
  • Short segment periarticular fracture
  • Osteopenic bone fracture
  • According to mode of application, the plate can be used as:
  • Compression Plating
  • Neutralisation Plating
  • Bridging Plating
  • Combination Plating
  • Key Features and Benefits:
  • Combi hole allows the surgeon to choose between conventional plating techniques, locked plating techniques, or a combination of both.

 

 

Combi hole

 

  • Threaded hole section for locking screws provides ability to create fixed-angle constructs.

 

 

Locking screw (the threads in the head of the screw locks with the threads of the hole in plate)

 

  • Smooth dynamic compression unit (DCU) hole section for conventional screws allows utilization of familiar AO plating techniques.
  • Limited-contact plate design reduces plate-to-bone contact, thus limiting vascular trauma and periosteal damage.
  • Indications are for fixation of fractures, osteotomies, nonunions, malunions, replantations particularly in osteopenic bone.
  • They are also for use in fixation of periprosthetic fractures.

 

Other options:

 

1. In osteoporotic patients, it should not be used. This statement is incorrect. Locking compression plates (LCPs) are often preferred in osteoporotic patients because they provide more stability compared to conventional plates due to their locking mechanism, which engages the screws with the plate, creating a fixed-angle construct. This can help overcome the poor bone quality associated with osteoporosis.

 

2. Can be used as buttress plate. This statement is correct. Locking compression plates can be used as buttress plates to provide support and stability to fractured bone segments, especially in comminuted fractures or fractures involving articular surfaces.

 

3. Usually cause periosteal injury. This statement is incorrect. Locking compression plates are designed to minimize periosteal injury because they do not rely on friction between the plate and bone for stability, as traditional plates do. Instead, they rely on the fixed-angle construct achieved by locking screws, which reduces the need for extensive periosteal stripping.

 

4. Mechanically superior to a conventional plate. This statement is correct. Locking compression plates are generally considered mechanically superior to conventional plates because they create a fixed-angle construct, which reduces the risk of screw loosening and failure. This construct allows for more stable fixation, particularly in osteoporotic bone or in fractures with poor bone quality.

 

5. Cannot be used as a compression plate. This statement is incorrect. While locking compression plates are primarily designed to create a fixed-angle construct, they can still be used for compression fixation when necessary. Compression can be achieved by using lag screws in combination with locking screws or by applying compression across the fracture site during plate fixation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Locking compression plate can be used as a buttress plate to provide support and stability to the fracture fragments.
  • They are mechanically superior to the conventional plate because they create a fixed-angle construct that reduces the risk of screw loosening/failure.

questions.text: Most common bone for which nailing is done is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tibia

 

Option C:

 

  • The most common bone for which nailing is done is the tibia.
  • Tibial nailing is a common surgical procedure used to stabilize fractures of the tibia, particularly in cases of long bone fractures or when there is significant displacement or comminution.
  • Nailing can also be done for the tibia, femur, humerus as well.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The bone that most commonly requires fixation by nailing is the tibia.

choices.text: Fracture lateral condyle of humerus

questions.text: Open reduction and internal fixation is done for all of the following fractures except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Volar Barton’s fracture

 

Option C:

 

  • In Volar Barton fracture, an attempt of closed reduction can be carried out.
  • If it fails, open reduction and plating is done.
  • Although recently, it has been shown that operative results yield better results, but for all other fractures, open reduction and internal fixation is carried out.
  • “Fractures of Necessity”, necessitating open reduction and internal fixation to achieve satisfactory outcomes includes: (Mnemonic: Lets Go For OPeration At Medical college)
    • Lateral condyle fracture humerus
    • Galeazzi fracture dislocation
    • Fracture neck femur
    • Displaced fracture olecranon
    • Displaced fracture patella
    • Articular fractures
    • Monteggia fracture in adults

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Open reduction and internal fixation is done for patella fracture, olecranon fracture, and fracture lateral condyle of humerus as they are the fractures of necessity that require immediate ORIF intervention.
  • Volar Barton fractures are managed by closed reduction. If it fails, then ORIF is done.

questions.text: At 60-degree angle of Z-plasty, how much elongation can be achieved?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 75%

 

Option C:

 

Z-PLASTY

 

  • Z-plasty is a common reconstructive surgical technique used for scar revision and contracture release.
  • It involves the transposition of two opposing triangular flaps that changes the direction of a scar so that it is better aligned and less visually apparent or less restrictive to movement. 

 

 

 

  • Relationship Between Angle of Z-Plasty and Elongation:
  • 30 degrees: 25% elongation
  • 45 degrees: 50% elongation
  • 60 degrees: 75% elongation
  • 75 degrees: 100% elongation
  • 90 degrees: 125% elongation

 

Note: Triangle tips may become depressed (or even necrotic) when angles are too acute.

 

Educational objective:

questions.text: Surgical excision is contraindicated in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral condyle humerus

 

Option D:

 

SURGICAL EXCISION

 

  • Lateral condyle of humerus is never excised because of being the physeal region.
  • Surgical excision is done in comminuted fracture patella, olecranon and head radius (outer 1/3rd).
  • Head and neck of femur are excised and replaced by prosthesis in fracture neck femur > 65 years of age.
  • Excision is contraindicated in growth plate injury, e.g. Lateral condyle fracture.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Surgical excision is contraindicated in growth plate injuries like lateral condyle fracture of the humerus or femur.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text:
Which of the following is included in management of intra-articular fracture? 

 

  1. Arthrodesis
  2. Excision
  3. Aspiration
  4. K-wire
  5. Plaster of Paris cast
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

MANAGEMENT OF INTRA-ARTICULAR FRACTURE

 

  • Fractures in general can be classified as:
  • Extra-articular
  • Partial articular
  • Articular

 

 

 

Note: Multiple modalities are present for fracture management according to morphology, duration and age of patient which can include Fixation, Excision of fragments, Aspiration, and Immoblisation by cast or slab.

 

Other options:

 

1. Arthrodesis. Arthrodesis is surgical fusion of joint. Fracture which are not viable for reconstruction or are old, malunited, painful intraarticular fracture, may require fusion of joint to gain painless joint. Such fusions are done at the cost of range of motion.

 

2. Excision. Excision of fragments could be required in comminuted fracture e.g., radial head excision following grossly comminuted fracture of radial head. Complete excision is one of the treatment modality.

 

3. Aspiration. Aspiration may be required in an immediate post traumatic period.

 

4. K-wire. Intraarticular fracture can be fixed with K-wire followed by a period of immoblisation.

 

5. Plaster of Paris cast. Non-surgical management of intraarticular fractures which are undisplaced can be done with cast or slab application.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Intra-articular fractures are managed by the means of arthrodesis, excision, aspiration, K-wire, and POP cast depending on the morphology of injury, duration of injury, and the age of the patient.

questions.text: In Thomas splint, most troubling is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ring

 

Option A)

 

THOMAS SPLINT

 

  • It was originally described by Hugh Owen Thomas as knee appliance for ambulant management of chronic inflammation of knee joint.
  • Thomas’s splint provides excellent support and immobilisation for transporting the patient.
  • Indications:
