    • All Femoral shaft fracture except large wounds in buttock/thigh which would interfere with fitting of the splint
  • Parts of Thomas’s Splint:
    • Proximal padded oval metal ring
    • Inner and outer side bar
  • Padded ring is set at an angle of 120 degrees to the inner side bar.
  • The inner and outer side bars are joined together with a W-piece.
  • The outer side bar protrudes 2 inches below the padded ring to clear the prominent greater trochanter.
  • The most troubling part of the splint is the ring because it impinges against proximal thigh.

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most troubling part of the Thomas splint is the ring because it impinges on the proximal thigh during application.

questions.text: Agnes Hunt traction is used in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexion deformity of hip

 

Option A)

 

AGNES HUNT TRACTION

 

  • Agnes Hunt traction is used for correction of mild flexion deformity of hip joint in poliomyelitis.

 

 

  • Other common skin tractions used are:
    • Buck's Traction: used for femora neck fracture, femoral shaft fracture in adolescents and adults, following hip dislocation reduction

 

 

  • Hamilton Russel Traction: used in femoral shaft fractures and trochanteric fractures in adults. Also used after hip arthroplasty.

 

 

  • Tulloch Brown Traction: used in treatment of pseudoarthrosis and femoral shaft fracture.

 

 

  • Gallow's or Brayant's Traction: used in femoral shaft fracture in children < 2 years of age

 

 

  • Modified Brayan's Traction: used in initial management of CDH in children > 1 year of age.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Intertrochanteric fracture. Traction used for trochanteric fracture is Russell’s traction.

 

Option C. Fracture shaft femur. Traction used for fracture shaft of femur in adults is Perkin’s traction.

 

Option D. Low backache. Traction used for low backache is Buck’s traction.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Agnes Hunt traction is used for treatment of flexion deformity of the hip in poliomyelitis patients.

questions.text: Which splint is used in management of fracture shaft of femur in age group of 2-10 years?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Split Russel traction

 

Option A)

 

SPLIT RUSSEL TRACTION

 

  • It is used in age 2-10 years for splinting of inter-trochanteric fracture of femur.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Gallow’s traction. It is used for fracture shaft of femur in children below 2 years (or 12 kg body weight).

 

Option C. Buck’s traction. It is a conventional skin traction used for low back ache.

 

Option D. Bryant traction. It is used in children below 2 years of age with fracture of femoral shaft.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In children between 2-10 years of age, to manage the fracture of femoral shaft, split Russel traction is used.

choices.text: Transverse of oblique fractures of long bones

questions.text: Locking compression plating is commonly indicated in which of the following fracture types?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Periarticular fractures

 

Option A)

 

LOCKING COMPRESSION PLATING

 

  • For long bone fracture, intramedullary implant is more suitable.
  • Periarticular fractures involve the joints or the areas around them, such as the distal femur or proximal tibia.
  • These fractures often require stable fixation to allow for early mobilization and prevent joint stiffness or instability.
  • Locking compression plates offer advantages in periarticular fractures due to their ability to provide stable fixation even in osteoporotic bone or in cases where there is poor bone stock.
  • The locking screws create a fixed-angle construct, which enhances stability and minimizes the risk of implant failure or loosening.
  • Advantages of locking plates are:
  • Osteopenic bones
  • Metaphyseal areas
  • Periprosthetic fractures
  • Failed fixation (non-union)

 

Closed reduction and internal fixation

 

 

Locking compression plate

 

Other options:

 

Option C. Intertrochanteric fractures. Intertrochanteric fractures occur at the proximal end of the femur, typically between the greater trochanter and the lesser trochanter. Intertrochanteric fractures are often managed with devices like intramedullary nails or dynamic hip screws, which are specifically designed for these types of fractures.

 

Option D. Fracture of long bones. The choice of fixation depends on various factors such as the location and type of fracture, patient's age, bone quality, and surgeon's preference. While locking compression plating may be suitable for certain long bone fractures, other options like intramedullary nails, external fixation, or conventional compression plates may also be considered depending on the specific case.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Locking compression plating is commonly indicated in the periarticular type fractures.

questions.text: Patellar tendon bearing cast is indicated in which of the following fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tibia

 

Option B)

 

PATELLAR TENDON BEARING CAST

 

  • The PTB cast is used to treat the tibial fractures from the middle-third downwards.
  • It is not suitable for proximal tibial fractures.
  • The principle of tibial PTB casting is a well-fitting below knee cast applied and molded between the gastrocnemius heads.
  • The actual weight is born on the patellar tendon anteriorly.
  • A rubber heel is applied and the patient is encouraged to bear weight on the plaster.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Patella. An undisplaced patellar fracture is treated conservatively by applying a tube/cylinder cast.

 

Option C. Medial malleolus. An undisplaced medial malleolus fracture is treated with a short leg cast or a walking boot.

 

Option D. Femur. One and one-half hip spica cast that starts at the chest and extends down to the ankle of the injured leg and to the knee of the other leg. Sometimes a bar is placed between both legs to keep the hips and legs immobilized.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A patellar tendon bearing cast is indicated for the treatment of fracture of the middle-third portion of the tibia.

questions.text: A patient has 2 months POP cast for tibial fracture of left leg. Now he needs mobilisation with a single crutch. You will use this crutch on which side?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right side

 

Option B)

 

  • In a fracture of the both bones of the leg, hip pathology, tibial fracture, a single crutch is used on the opposite side of the affected extremity.
  • Therefore, in the given case scenario, the patient will use the crutch on the right side while the affected left side will be free to move.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A single crutch is used on the opposite side of the affected extremity.
  • Thus, in the given case, the injured side is left, so the patient will use the crutch on the right side.

questions.text: Most common site for trauma of spine is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cervical

 

Option A.

 

FACTORS PREDISPOSING CERVICAL SPINE TO TRAUMA

 

  1. Flexibility and wide range of motion
  2. Ligaments of cervical vertebrae are smaller and more delicate compared to those of Thoracic or Lumbar vertebrae.
  3. High energy trauma and sudden acceleration-deceleration injuries

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Thoracic. Thoracic spine injuries can be severe. These injuries can affect both sides of the body. While the long-term prognosis of spinal cord injuries in the thoracic region is often better than those in the cervical region, the consequences can still be life-altering.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Spinal cord injuries are most common in the cervical region and the thoracic region.

 

IMPORTANT ONE-LINERS:

 

  • Most common site of spine trauma in children – Craniovertebral junction
  • Most common site of spinal cord injury – Lower cervical spine
  • Fixed segment of spinal cord – Dorsal spine
  • Most common site of fracture – Dorso-lumbar spine (due to being Transition Zone)

questions.text: K nail can be used for all of the following fractures except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intertrochanteric fractures

 

Option B:

 

K-NAIL

 

  • K nail doesn’t have an option for cephalic screw.
  • Intertrochantric fractures should be treated with cephalomedullary nail.
  • Kuntscher Cloverleaf Intramedullary Nail (K-nail) is mainly useful for transverse or short oblique fractures around isthmus of femur.

 

 

  • It provides stability by 3-point fixation.
  • To increase the elasticity of nail, it is hollow, has a cloverleaf cross-section and a longitudinal slot.

 

 

  • When a straight nail passes through a curved medullary canal, it is deformed (elastic deformation).
  • Most of the intertrochanteric fractures are treated with either a sliding hip screw or intramedullary hip screw.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • K-nails are used in the treatment of isthmic fractures of shaft of femur, low subtrochanteric femur fractures and distal femur shaft fractures.
  • They are not used in the intertrochanteric fractures, instead they are treated with intramedullary nails and screws.

choices.text: Fracture of base of 5th metatarsal
Fracture of base of 2nd metatarsal
Fracture of base of 1st metacarpal
Fracture of head of 5th metacarpal

questions.text: Jones’ fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture of base of 5th metatarsal

 

Option A)

 

JONE’S FRACTURE

 

  • A Jones fracture is a fracture of the proximal metadiaphyseal junction of the fifth metatarsal bone that involves the 4th-5th metatarsal articulation.
  • It is a transverse fracture at the base of the fifth metatarsal, 1.5 to 3 cm distal to the proximal tuberosity at the metadiaphyseal junction, without distal extension. 
  • 5th Metatarsal Base Fractures are among the most common fractures of the foot and are predisposed to poor healing due to the limited blood supply to the specific areas of the 5th metatarsal base.
  • The fracture occur as a result of significant adduction force to the forefoot with the ankle in plantar flexion.
  • Diagnosis is made with plain radiographs of the foot.
  • Treatment can include protected weight bearing, immobilization or surgery depending on location of fracture, degree of displacement, and athletic level of patient.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Fracture base of 2nd metatarsal. In a Lisfranc fracture-dislocation, the 2nd metatarsal bone is fractured at its base with dislocation of the fragments. Lisfranc fracture-dislocations usually occur when people fall on a flexed foot or when the foot is hit with severe force.

 

Option C. Fracture base of 1st metacarpal. The Bennett fracture is the most common fracture involving the base of the thumb. This fracture refers to an intraarticular fracture that separates the palmar ulnar aspect of the first metacarpal base from the remaining first metacarpal.

 

Option D. Fracture head of 5th metacarpal. A Boxer's fracture is a fracture of the fifth metacarpal neck, named for the classic mechanism of injury in which direct trauma is applied to a clenched fist. This represents 10% of all hand fractures.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Jone’s fracture is the fracture of the base of the 5th metatarsal of the foot.

questions.text: Action of intramedullary ‘K’ nail is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Three-point fixation

 

Option B:

 

K-NAIL

 

  • It is mainly useful for transverse or short oblique fractures around isthmus.
  • It provides stability by 3-point fixation.
  • To increase the elasticity of nail, it is hollow, has a cloverleaf cross-section and a longitudinal slot.
  • When a straight nail passes through a curved medullary canal, it is deformed (elastic deformation).
  • 3 points are 2 ends and isthmus.
  • Each nail is precurved to achieve 3-point fixation where the required precurve should be approximately 3 times the diameter of a long bone at its narrowest point.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Intramedullary K-nail acts as 3-point fixation, providing stability to the fracture fragments.
  • 3 points are the 2 ends of the nail and the isthmus of the femur.

choices.text: Base of 1st Metacarpal

questions.text: Chauffeur’s fracture involves the:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radial styloid

 

Option B)

 

CHAUFFEUR’S FRACTURE

 

  • Chauffeur fractures are intra-articular fractures of the radial styloid process.
  • The radial styloid is within the fracture fragment, although the fragment can vary markedly in size.

 

 

  • These injuries are sustained either from direct trauma like a blow to the back of the wrist or from forced dorsiflexion and abduction.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. Radial head. Radial Head Fractures are common intra-articular elbow fractures that can be associated with an episode of elbow instability, a mechanical block to elbow motion, an injury to the distal radioulnar joint and/or to the interosseous membrane (Essex-Lopresti).

 

Option C. Ulnar styloid. Ulnar styloid fractures occur in association with ~60% of distal radius fractures. 

 

Option D. Base of 1st metacarpal. Bennett fracture is the most common fracture involving the base of the thumb. This fracture is an intraarticular fracture that separates the palmar ulnar aspect of the first metacarpal base from the remaining first metacarpal. The injury is typically caused by axial loading on a partially flexed metacarpal and may be associated with other carpal bone fractures or ligament injuries.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Chauffeur’s fracture is the fracture of the radial styloid process.

questions.text: Aviator’s fracture involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Talus

 

Option A)

 

AVIATOR’S FRACTURE

 

  • Aviator’s fracture is the coronal plane fracture of the neck of the talus due to high-energy forced dorsiflexion of the ankle.
  • The talar neck is the most frequently injured site and talus is the 2nd most commonly injured bone in the foot after calcaneus.
  • Proximal avascular necrosis is a potential complication of neck fractures.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Calcaneum. Fracture of the calcaneum is commonly known as lover’s fracture as it occurs due to fall from a significant height with the foot planted on the ground.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Aviator’s fracture is the fracture of the neck of the talus bone.

questions.text: Dunlop traction is a type of traction used in management of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture humerus

 

Option A)

 

DUNLOP TRACTION

 

  • The main use of Dunlop's traction is in the maintenance of reduction in supracondyar fractures of the humerus in children.
  • It allows the swollen elbow to settle.
  • It is contraindicated in open fractures and skin defects.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Fracture radius. Finger traps are an accepted method of applying traction to reduce fractures of the distal radius.

 

Option C. Fracture femur. Various splints are used for femur fracture management, namely Thomas splint, Bohler-Braun (BB) splint, Gallow’s traction (pediatrics), Bryant’s traction (pediatrics), Russell’s traction, Perkin’s traction, 90-90 degrees traction (pediatrics).

 

Option D. Fracture tibia. Skeletal traction is given for the fractures of the shaft of tibia and fibula.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Dunlop traction is used for the management of the supracondylar fracture of the humerus in children.

questions.text: Tube cast is applied for injuries of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Knee Joint

 

Option A)

 

TUBE CAST

 

  • A tube cast or patellar tendon bearing (PTB) cast is used for fracture of patella.
  • It immobilizes the tibial shaft fractures and allows knee flexion.
  • It is not suitable for proximal tibial fractures but is a good conservative method for treating stable tibial fractures from middle third downwards.
  • The cast is moulded between the gastrocnemius heads.
  • While applying the cast, the knee should be flexed to 90.
  • Anteriorly, the cast is moulded around the patella and an indentation is made over the patellar tendon.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Spine. For spinal scoliosis, Risser’s cast or turn-buckle cast can be used.

 

Option C. Around pelvis. For fractures around pelvis, a hip spica is used.

 

Option D. Proximal humerus. For proximal humerus fractures, a hanging cast is used.

 

Educational objective:

 

Tube cast or patellar tendon bearing cast is used for the fractures around the knee like fracture of patella, fracture of middle third shaft of tibia.

questions.text: The contraindication to internal fixation is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Active infection

 

Option B:

 

CONTRAINDICATIONS OF INTERNAL FIXATION

 

  • Active Infection
  • Osteoporotic bone
  • Burns, Surgical Scar or poor soft tissues overlying the site
  • Medical conditions that contraindicate the surgery or anesthesia (e.g. Recent MI)
  • Severe, high grade open fractures with soft tissue loss and gross contamination

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Active infection is an absolute contraindication for internal fixation.
  • Physeal injury, intraarticular fracture and fracture-dislocation are fixed with internal fixation.

choices.text: Cauda equina syndrome
Conus medullaris syndrome

questions.text: Symmetrical areflexic bladder, bowel and lower limb occur in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conus medullaris syndrome

 

Option B.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cauda equina syndrome. This condition involves asymmetrical areflexic involvement of the bladder & bowel, and the lower limbs. Bladder and bowel involvement occurs late in this condition.

 

Option C. Nerve root damage. Compression of nerve root results in radiculopathy. This results in sharp pain which worsens with activity, radiation to specific dermatome, and may result in neurological weakness.

 

Option D. Brown sequard syndrome. It is a hemisection lesion of the spinal cord. This causes loss of vibratory, light touch and motor functions on the same side while pain and temperature is lost on the other side.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Symmetrical areflexic bladder, bowel, and lower limb are seen in conus medullaris syndrome.

questions.text: Trendelenburg test is positive in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Option D:

 

Explanation:

 

TRENDELENBURG SIGN

 

  • Normally, when the body weight is supported on one limb, the glutei (medius and minimus) of the supported side contract and raise the opposite and unsupported side of pelvis, if the abductor mechanism is defective the unsupported side of pelvis drops and this is known as positive Trendelenburg's test.
  • Trendelenburg's test is done to assess the integrity of abductor mechanism.
  • It is positive in the conditions in which any of the three—fulcrum (Femoral Head), lever arm (neck length) or power (muscles/nerve) is affected.

 

 

  • Causes of Positive Trendelenburg Test:
    • Power-Paralysis of abductor muscles:
      • Abductors of hip are Gluteus medius and minimus,
      • Tensor fascia lata and sartorius (accessory).

Note: Disc prolapse at L4–L5 compresses L5 nerve root which supplies G.medius and minimus.

  • Superior gluteal nerve palsy (supply gluteus medius and minimus)
  • Polio
  • Iliotibial tract palsy
    • Decreased lever arm:
      • Fracture neck femur
    • Absence of stable fulcrum about which the abductor muscles can act.
      • Dislocation of hip
      • Destruction of femoral head in Perthes disease, AVN, late stages of TB hip (stage 4 and 5) and septic arthritis.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Trendelenburg test is positive in hip dislocation, fracture neck of femur and coxa vara

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Cancellous bone graft is taken from:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

BONE GRAFT

 

  • Types of bone graft are:
  • Cancellous: If only small amount of cancellous bone is needed, sites are olecranon, radial styloid, anterior aspect of greater trochanter, distal femoral condyle, proximal tibial metaphysis, Distal tibial metaphysis
  • Cortico-cancellous: iliac crest
  • Cortical: fibula
  • Vascularised fibular graft
  • Ilium (Pelvis) is an ideal source of primary 1st order bone graft because it is relatively subcutaneous, has natural curvatures that are useful in fashioning grafts, has ample cancellous bone and has cortical bone of varying thickness. Removal of bone carries minimal risk and usually no significant residual disability.
  • Posterior superior iliac spine is the best source of cancellous bone graft.
  • Anterior iliac crest is the best source of bicortical and cortico-cancellous graft.
  • For metaphyseal bone grafting, greater trochanter, distal femur, calcaneum, olecrenon, distal radius, proximal humerus are used. 
  • Sites for cortical autogaft are Iliac crest, Fibula and Ribs.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Cancellous bone graft is taken from the femoral condyles, pelvis (ilium), greater trochanter, and the tibial metaphysis.

questions.text: Most common type of hip dislocation is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior

 

Option B:

 

HIP DISLOCATION

 

  • Hip dislocations are traumatic hip injuries that result in femoral head dislocation from the acetabular socket.
  • Hip dislocation can be classified as:
    • Posterior dislocation (most common ~85%) caused by combined forces of hip flexion, adduction, and internal rotation.
    • Anterior dislocation (~10%) caused by combined forces of hyper-abduction with the extension.
    • Central dislocation (always occurring with Acetabulum Fracture)
  • The most commonly seen hip dislocation is the posterior dislocation in about 90% cases.
  • Diagnosis can be made with hip radiographs to determine the direction of dislocation and CT scan studies to assess for associated injuries. 

 

 

 

  • Treatment is urgent reduction to minimize risk of avascular necrosis followed by CT scan to assess for associated injuries that may require surgical treatment (loose bodies, femoral head fractures, acetabular fractures).

Note:

  • Most common type of shoulder dislocation – Anterior
  • Most common type of Hip dislocation – Posterior

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common hip dislocations are Posterior > Anterior > Central dislocations.

questions.text: Denis gave how many columns theory to define stability of spine?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

Option C.

 

DENIS’ THREE-COLUMN THEORY

 

  • Proposed by Francis Denis, three-column concept divides a spinal segment into three parts: Anterior, middle, and posterior columns.

 

 

  • The anterior column comprises the anterior longitudinal ligament and the anterior half of the vertebral body.
  • The middle column comprises the posterior half of the vertebral body and the posterior longitudinal ligament.
  • The posterior column comprises the pedicles, the facet joints and the supraspinous ligaments.
  • Significance: If 2 out of 3 contiguous columns are involved suggest as unstable spinal injury.

 

 

  • It is widely used in routine clinical practice and can be used to report and communicate.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • To define spinal stability, Denis gave a 3-column theory which divided the spinal segment into anterior, middle and posterior columns.

choices.text: Knee jerk is the first reflex to return
High thoracic lesions are commonly associated with more severe neurological deficits
Failure of return of cord activity within 48 hours is a very poor prognostic sign
Both B and C

questions.text: In spinal shock:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both B and C

 

Option D.

 

SPINAL SHOCK

 

  • Sometimes physical energy of the injury mechanism causes immediate depolarization of axonal membranes in the neural tissue.
  • This results in functional neurological deficit that exceeds the actual tissue disruption. This condition is referred to as spinal shock.
  • Thus, Spinal Shock is a temporary and reversible state of physiological disruption of the spinal cord functions immediately following a severe spinal cord injury.
  • It is the loss of sensorimotor functions below the level of injury.
  • The presence of spinal shock causes the absence of all reflexes.
  • It typically lasts up to 24–48 hours after the injury.
  • The bulbocavernosus reflex is the reflex that returns first, thus marking the end of spinal shock.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Knee jerk is the first reflex to return. False. The first reflex to return is bulbocavernosus reflex (S2, S3, S4) – contraction of the anal sphincter in response to the stimulation of glans or clitoris. Its reappearance is the sign of recovery from the spinal shock.
 

Option B. High thoracic lesions are commonly associated with more severe neurological deficits. True. Higher the level of lesion, greater the number of spinal segments involved and more extensive the neurological deficits. Higher thoracic lesions may cause paraplegia, quadriplegia and may also cause autonomic dysfunction such as impaired BP regulation etc. due to involvement of sympathetic nerves.
 

Option C. Failure of return of cord activity within 48 hours is a very poor prognostic sign. True.  The absence of any signs of neurological improvement during first 48 hours is suggestive of severe spinal cord injury and implies a lower chances of significant recovery.

 

Educative objective:

 

  • Spinal injury in first acute phase include neurogenic shock and spinal shock.
  • Neurogenic shock: Hypotension and relative bradycardia
  • Spinal shock: Temporary loss of spinal cord function and reflex activity below the level of spinal cord injury characterized by:
    • Flaccid areflexic paralysis
    • Bradycardia & hypotension (due to loss of sympathetic tone)
    • Absent bulbocavernosus reflex
  • Important to know because one cannot evaluate neurologic deficit until spinal shock phase has resolved.
  • End of spinal shock is indicated by return of the bulbocavernous reflex.
  • Conus medullaris or cauda equina injuries may also lead to permanent loss of the bulbocavernous reflex.

choices.text: Type I – immobilization in rigid collar
Type II – screw fixation
Type III – halo vest immobilization
Type IV – open reduction internal fixation

questions.text: Most dangerous type of odontoid fracture as per Anderson-D’ Alonzo classification and its respective management is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type II – screw fixation

 

Option B.

 

ANDERSON-D’ALONZO CLASSIFICATION OF ODONTOID FRACTURES

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Type 2 odontoid fractures are unstable fracture.
  • They are considered to be the most dangerous type because the bone is more likely to move out of its normal position and alignment.
  • This makes them the most likely to require surgery with screw fixation.

questions.text: Chance fracture is fracture of vertebra of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thoracolumbar

 

Option A.

 

CHANCE FRACTURE

 

  • A Chance fracture is an unstable, flexion-distraction injury of the spine, typically at the thoracolumbar junction, with a horizontal fracture through the spinous process, pedicles, and vertebral body.
  • Also known as a “seatbelt fracture,” the most common mechanism of injury is a rapid deceleration in a motor vehicle collision, with flexion of the spine over the lap seat belt.

 

 

Chance fracture

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The fracture of thoracolumbar junction of the spine is called chance fracture, caused by the seat belt injury on rapid deceleration of the motor vehicle.

choices.text: Stellate fracture across base of skull
Transverse fracture across base of skull
Lamina fracture of C7 vertebra
Spinous process fracture of C7 vertebra

questions.text: Motorcyclist’s fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transverse fracture across base of skull

 

Option B.

 

MOTORCYCLIST’S FRACTURE

 

  • It is the transverse fracture across the base of skull leading to separation into anterior-posterior.
  • It is common in people riding motorcycles. 
  • It is known as fracture of the base of the skull.
  • In this, the force is on the skull that comes from one side to another, mostly in the temporal area.
  • It can be classified into Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3. 
    • Type 1 is a hinge fracture. Type 1 can have a nodding face sign
    • Type 2 starts from the front area of one side and then to Sella tursica and then to the contralateral side. 
    • Type 3 is a fracture in the anterior part.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option C. Lamina fracture of C7 vertebra. C7 laminar fracture can occur after C7 dome-like laminectomy when a substantial amount of lamina is resected. Although C7 fractures may not cause deleterious clinical outcomes, they can lead to an unharmonized cervical curvature.

 

 

Option D. Spinous process fracture of C7 vertebra. This type of injury occurs after sudden flexion of the head. It can also occur after repeated stress caused by the pulling of the trapezius and rhomboid muscles on the spinous processes. This injury is known as a “clay shoveler’s fracture”. There is an acute avulsion fracture. The lower cervical or upper thoracic spinous processes are general affected as they have longer and more vulnerable spinous processes. It is usually a very stable fracture and does not produce any neurologic deficits. It typically heals with 6-8 weeks of relative rest with no further treatment being needed in most cases.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Motorcyclist’s fracture is the transverse fracture across the base of the skull.

choices.text: Spinal cord injury with radiological abnormality
Spinal cord injury without radiological abnormality
Spinal cord involvement with radiological abnormality
Spinal cord involvement without radiological abnormality

questions.text: Full form of SCIWORA is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spinal cord injury without radiological abnormality

 

Option B.

 

SCIWORA  

 

  • SCIWORA is Spinal Cord Injury Without Radiological Abnormality.
  • SCIWORA is used to describe a spinal cord injury that does not show any radiographic abnormalities on imaging studies like X-ray or CT scans.
  • Mechanism: It mainly occurs due to hyperflexion or hyperextension of the spinal cord without any accompanying fractures or dislocations of the vertebrae.
  • Age group: It mainly occurs in children (particularly in less than 8 years of age).
  • Best Investigation to pick up SCIWORA – MRI.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • SCIWORA is Spinal Cord Injury Without Radiological Abnormality.

questions.text: Block vertebrae are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Klippel-Feil syndrome

 

Option D.

 

BLOCK VERTEBRA

 

  • Block vertebrae are formed due to failure of two or more adjacent vertebrae to separate during their development, resulting in their fusion.

 

 

  • It is seen in Klippel Feil syndrome which is a disorder of complete or partial fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae.
  • Other syndromes associated with block vertebrae are anatomical variant, Wildervanck syndrome, VACTERL association, and Aicardi syndrome.

 

 

Klippel Feil Syndrome – Note the short neck, low posterior hair line and high riding scapula

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Paget’s disease. In paget’s, the vertebral body increases in anteroposterior and lateral dimensions but the height remains unchanged. Early radiographic appearance is thickening and hypertrophy of trabecular bone parallel to the end plate. The combination of trabecular bone hypertrophy and thickening at the end-plates with absorption on the periosteal surfaces at the anterior and posterior vertebral borders leads to the “picture frame” sign.

 

 

Option B. Leukemia. The radiographic changes noted in the vertebrae included diffuse demineralization of the bodies, the neural arches, and the transverse processes. The loss of bone density appeared is more pronounced in the thoracic and the upper lumbar spine. In some cases, demineralization is greater in the centers of the vertebrae than at peripheries. There can be compression of the vertebral bodies, the most common structural change being anterior wedging.

 

 

Option C. TB. In spinal tuberculosis, characteristically, there is destruction of the intervertebral disk space and the adjacent vertebral bodies, collapse of the spinal elements, and anterior wedging leading to the characteristic angulation and gibbus (palpable deformity because of involvement of multiple vertebrae) formation.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Block vertebrae is seen commonly in Klippel-Feil syndrome in children.

questions.text: Ring fracture of C1 is called as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Jefferson’s fracture

 

Option B.

 

JEFFERSON’S FRACTURE

 

  • Jefferson’s fracture is burst fracture of ring of atlas (C1) vertebrae.
  • Burst fracture is a vertical compression fracture.
  • It is most common fracture of Atlas.
  • There is 50% association of concomitant injury in cervical spine elsewhere.

 

 

 

  • Note: Neurological deficits are rare.
  • Mechanism: Axial Loading

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hangman’ fracture. Hangman’s fracture, also known as Traumatic Spondylolisthesis of Axis, is defined as bilateral fracture traversing the pars interarticularis of C2 with an associated traumatic subluxation of C2 on C3. 

 

 

  • Option C. Clay Shoveller’s fracture. Clay-shoveler Fractures are an avulsion-type spinous process fracture in the lower cervical or upper thoracic spine.

 

 

Option D. Chance fracture. A Chance fracture is an unstable, flexion-distraction injury of the spine, typically at the thoracolumbar junction, with a horizontal fracture through the spinous process, pedicles, and vertebral body.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ring fracture of C1 is called as Jefferson’s fracture.

questions.text: Seat belt injury is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chance fracture

 

Option C.

 

CHANCE FRACTURE

 

  • A Chance fracture is an unstable, flexion-distraction injury of the spine at the thoracolumbar junction, with a horizontal fracture through the spinous process, pedicles, and vertebral body.
  • Also known as a “seatbelt fracture,” the most common mechanism of injury is a rapid deceleration in a motor vehicle collision, with flexion of the spine over the lap seat belt.
  • The incidence of concurrent intra-abdominal injuries is as high as 50%, with bowel perforation and mesenteric laceration being the most common types of injuries.
  • A “seatbelt sign,” or bruising/abrasion on the abdomen in the distribution of a seat belt may also be present.

 

 

  • Injuries associated with Seat-belt related trauma:
    • Hollow viscus injury
    • Mesenteric tears
    • Aortic tear at Ligamentum arteriosum

 

 

Seat belt syndrome – Note the stranding of mesentery

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tear drop fracture. Tear drop fracture is a fracture pattern occurring in severe axial/flexion injury of the cervical spine. They indicate extensive underlying ligamentous injury and spinal instability. Associated spinal cord injury is common, especially anterior cervical cord syndrome and quadriplegia.

 

 

Option B. Wedge fracture. Spinal wedge (compression) fractures are hyperflexion injuries to the vertebral body resulting from axial loading. Most commonly affecting the anterior aspect of the vertebral body, wedge fractures are considered a stable fracture. Most common type (~50%) of thoracolumbar spine fractures. Typically, these fractures are insufficiency fractures secondary to osteoporosis, although some are pathological secondary to a focal bone lesion.

 

 

Option D. Whiplash injury. These are the acceleration-deceleration injuries occurring to the cervical spine. It is caused by neck bending forcibly forward and then backward, or vice versa. The injury, which is poorly understood, usually involves the muscles, discs, nerves, and tendons in neck.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Seat belt injury is chance fracture of the thoracolumbar junction.

choices.text: Flexion-rotation injury with failure of anterior body
Flexion compression failure of body

questions.text: Tear drop fracture of lower cervical spine implies:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Flexion compression failure of body

 

Option D.

 

TEAR DROP FRACTURE

 

  • Tear drop fracture is caused by combined axial compression and flexion injury.

 

 

  • Tear drop fracture is a fracture pattern occurring in severe axial/flexion injury of the cervical spine.
  • They indicate extensive underlying ligamentous injury and spinal instability.
  • Associated spinal cord injury is common, especially anterior cervical cord syndrome and quadriplegia.
  • Classification of cervical spine injuries:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Wedge compression fracture. Spinal wedge compression fractures are hyperflexion injuries to the vertebral body resulting from axial loading. Most commonly affecting the anterior aspect of the vertebral body, wedge fractures are considered a stable fracture. Most common type (~50%) of thoracolumbar spine fractures. Typically, these fractures are insufficiency fractures secondary to osteoporosis, although some are pathological secondary to a focal bone lesion.

 

 

Option B. Axial compression fractures. Compression wedge fractures are caused by axial compression alone or flexion forces, when the spine is bent forward or in side flexion at the moment of trauma. It is a stable fracture and patients rarely accompany neurological deficits. The most common causes in younger patients are falls and motor vehicle accidents.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A tear drop fracture of the lower cervical spine is the flexion-compression fracture of the vertebral body.

questions.text: Line joining anterior superior iliac spine to ischial tuberosity and passing above greater trochanter is called:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nelaton's line

 

Option A:

 

NELATON’S LINE
 

  • Patient lies on the normal/opposite side of the limb with preferably 90-degree flexion at hip.
  • It is a line drawn from ischial tuberosity to ASIS that should pass through the tip of greater trochanter.
  • In case of supra-trochanteric shortening, the trochanter will be above this line.

 

 

 

  • It is positive when the greater trochanter of the femur is palpated well above the line. This is seen in dislocation of hip and coxa vara.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Shoemaker’s line. The line from the tip of Greater Trochanter to the anterior superior iliac spine is prolonged anteriorly to meet in the central line at or above the umbilicus of the patient. If the GT is elevated/proximally migrated, the line will cross the mid line below the umbilicus.

 

 

 

Option C: Chiene’s line. 2 lines joining the GT on both sides and ASIS on both sides must be parallel. Supratrochanteric shortening at 1 side leads to convergence of line. This forms a parallelogram called as Chiene’s parallelogram. It is used to detect the femoral head fracture based on the changes in the bony landmark relation. Normally both the lines should be parallel. If GT of one side migrates proximally, as in femoral fracture, the line converges. This test is ineffective in bilateral hip affections.

 

 

 

Option D: Perkin’s line. Perkin line is a line drawn perpendicular to Hilgenreiner line, intersecting the lateral most aspect of the acetabular roof. The upper femoral epiphysis should be seen in the inferomedial quadrant. It should lie below Hilgenreiner line, and medial to Perkin line. If the nucleus of the femoral head is not visible because it is not ossified yet, the femoral metaphysis should be used. Lateral displacement of the femoral head occurs in developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH).

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The line joining the ASIS to ischial tuberosity and passes above the greater trochanter is called the Nelaton’s line.

questions.text: Trendelenburg’s sign is negative in an Inter-Trochanteric fracture because of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tensor fascia lata

 

Option D:

 

NEGATIVE TRENDELENBURG SIGN

 

  • Trendelenburg's test is done to assess the integrity of abductor mechanism.
  • The primary hip abductor muscles include the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae.
  • Piriformis, sartorius, and superior fibers of the gluteus maximus are considered secondary hip abductors.
  • Normally, when the body weight is supported on one limb, the abductors of hip of the supported side contract and raise the opposite and unsupported side of pelvis, if the abductor mechanism is defective the unsupported side of pelvis drops and this is known as positive Trendelenburg's test.
  • In cases of fracture intertrochanteric femur, both gluteus muscles become ineffective as these are inserted in the greater trochanter.
  • Tensor fascia lata (TFL) which is inserted through the iliotibial tract onto the lateral condyle of the proximal tibia will still be in a position to affect some abduction, thereby causing a negative Trendelenburg test.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Gluteus medius. The gluteus medius is one of the primary abductor muscles of the hip. If it is weak or dysfunctional, it can lead to a positive Trendelenburg sign.

 

Option B: Gluteus maximus. The gluteus maximus is primarily involved in hip extension and external rotation. While it is an important muscle around the hip joint, weakness or dysfunction in the gluteus maximus is not typically associated with Trendelenburg's sign.

 

Option C: Gluteus minimus. The gluteus minimus, along with the gluteus medius, is also involved in hip abduction. Dysfunction or weakness in the gluteus minimus can contribute to a positive Trendelenburg sign, not a negative one.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The tensor fascia lata is a muscle that assists in hip flexion and stabilization of the pelvis during walking.
  • Dysfunction in the tensor fascia lata can lead to a negative Trendelenburg sign.
  • This is because if the tensor fascia lata is unable to stabilize the pelvis on the unsupported side during single-leg stance, the pelvis may tilt upward rather than dropping, resulting in a negative Trendelenburg sign.

questions.text: Trendelenburg’s test is positive in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tuberculosis of hip joint

 

Option D:

 

TRENDELENBURG SIGN

 

  • Normally, when the body weight is supported on one limb, the glutei (medius and minimus) of the supported side contract and raise the opposite and unsupported side of pelvis, if the abductor mechanism is defective the unsupported side of pelvis drops and this is known as positive Trendelenburg's test.
  • Trendelenburg's test is done to assess the integrity of abductor mechanism.
  • It is positive in the conditions in which any of the three—fulcrum (Femoral Head), lever arm (neck length) or power (muscles/nerve) is affected.

 



 

  • Causes of Positive Trendelenburg Test:
    • Power-Paralysis of abductor muscles:
      • Abductors of hip are Gluteus medius and minimus,
      • Tensor fascia lata and sartorius (accessory).
    • Note: Disc prolapse at L4–L5 compresses L5 nerve root which supplies G.medius and minimus.
      • Superior gluteal nerve palsy (supply gluteus medius and minimus)
      • Polio
      • Iliotibial tract palsy
  • Decreased lever arm:
    • Fracture neck femur
  • Absence of stable fulcrum about which the abductor muscles can act.
    • Dislocation of hip
    • Destruction of femoral head in Perthes disease, AVN, late stages of TB hip (stage 4 and 5) and septic arthritis.

 

 

  • Trendelenburg’s test may be positive in TB hip only in late stages (stage 4 and 5) when the head of femur is destroyed.
  • Normally, it is negative in TB hip.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Trendelenburg’s test is positive in posterior dislocation of hip, poliomyelitis and fracture of neck of femur.
  • It is negative in tuberculosis of hip joint.
  • It appears to be positive in hip joint tuberculosis in the late stages of the disease when the femoral head is destroyed.

choices.text: Intracapsular fracture neck of femur

questions.text: Telescopic test is useful to diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intracapsular fracture neck of femur

 

Option B:

 

TELESCOPY TEST

 

  • Telescopy Test is a provocative test used to evaluate the stability of the hip joint.
  • It also indicates the congenital hip dislocation in pediatric patients.
  • Method:
    • Telescopy test is done in supine position with hip and knee flexed to 90, and hip adducted.
    • The examiner places the fingers of one hand over the Greater Trochanter to feel the unstable movements while the other hand holds the distal thigh, and push and pull forces are applied.


 

  • Even in normal condition, a slight excursion of trochanter can be felt by other hand.
  • If excursion is more, then this indicates conditions with instability of hip joint such as old and unreduced posterior dislocation, loss of neck and/or head in old neck of femur fractures, dislocated total hip replacement, and paralytic hip.
  • If the hip is unstable, an up and down trochanteric excursion can be felt with the other hand i.e., the Telescopy Test is positive.
  • In the intracapsular neck fracture, the telescopy test is positive because the hip joint is unstable in this fracture.

 

Explanation:

 

  • In Perthe’s disease (option A), ankylosis of hip joint (Option D) and malunited trochanteric fracture (Option C), the hip joint is stable and will not lead to positive telescopy test.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The telescopy test is positive in intracapsular neck of femur fractures while in the other conditions, it is negative because of the stability of the hip joint.

questions.text: “Judet” view of X-ray is for:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelvis

 

Option A:

 

JUDET VIEW

 

  • The oblique internal and external pelvis views, otherwise known as the Judet view, are additional projections to the pelvic series when there is suspicion of an acetabular fracture.
  • The Judet views are comprised of two projections:
    • First, the iliac oblique projection for assessment of the ilio-ischial line of the posterior column, the roof of the acetabulum, and iliac crest.
    • Second, the obturator oblique view demonstrating the iliopectineal line of the anterior column of the pelvis, the posterior acetabular wall and the obturator foramen.
       

 

Columns of acetabulum

 

 

 

Judet view (for pelvis/acetabulum, obturator and iliac views are taken)

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Calcaneum. To rule out calcaneal pathologies, lateral and axial (Harris) views are used. To rule out further foot and ankle pathologies in calcaneal injuries, Broden’s view and Canale/Kelly views are used.

 

 

 

 

A) Broden’s view; B) Canale view

 

Option C: Scaphoid. For scaphoid, the posteroanterior ulnar deviation scaphoid view is used. It is performed with the wrist in ulnar deviation to free the scaphoid from bony superimposition.

 

 

Option D: Shoulder. Standard projections used are AP view and lateral/scapular Y view. Modified trauma projections include modified trauma axial view, Garth projection for Hill-Sachs defects, supine lateral view, modified transthoracic supine lateral view, and supine axial view etc.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The Judet’s view is used for the evaluation of the pelvis radiographically.

choices.text: Adequate exposal of posterior segment
Anterior segment is not visualized adequately
Superior exposure is very well exposed
Sciatic nerve injury in 10% in cases

questions.text: Which is not true about Langenbeck Kocher operation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superior exposure is very well exposed

 

Option C:

 

Kocher-Langenbeck Approach

 

This is a posterior approach used for all posterior wall, posterior column, posterior column with posterior wall fractures of acetabulum.

 

It is also used for most transverse and transverse plus posterior wall fracture and many T-shaped fractures.

 

  • Please observe this question is not the same as previous as Kocher-Langenbeck approach is not a good approach for superior segment as its visualization is limited hence D option will be considered acceptable as nerve injuries in earlier studies were more than 6% as compared to now.

choices.text: Displacement is less common than extracapsular fractures
Contour of greater trochanter is normal
Tenderness is mainly present over the anterior joint line

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about intracapsular fracture of femur neck?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malunion is common complication

 

Option B:

 

INTRACAPSULAR FRACTURE NECK OF FEMUR

 

  • Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture.
  • Femoral neck fractures are associated with low energy falls in the elderly.
  • In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as fall from a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. 
  • Risk factors for femoral neck fractures include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density.
  • 70% of all hip fractures occur in women. 
  • Symptoms include pain in the groin or pain referred along the medial side of the thigh and knee in an impacted fracture.
  • In a displaced fracture, there will be pain in the entire hip. 
  • In an impacted fracture, there is no obvious clinical deformity on examination. There is mild discomfort in the active/passive hip range of motion, and pain with percussion over the greater trochanter.
  • In displaced fractures, the leg appears in external rotation and abduction deformity with shortening of the limb.
  • The displacement in the intracapsular femoral neck fracture is less as compared to the extracapsular fractures. This is due to the attachment of the capsule to the distal fracture fragment.
  • There is no disturbance of the trochanteric contour.
  • Complications are Osteonecrosis > Non-union > arthritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Displacement is less common than extracapsular fractures: This occurs due to the intact capsule in intracapsular fractures. The capsular displacement is more apparent in extracapsular fracture than intracapsular fractures.

 

Option C: Contour of greater trochanter is normal: Intertrochantric line is maintained, hence the contour of the trochanter is normal.

 

Option D: Tenderness is mainly present over the anterior joint line: Upon clinical examination, tenderness of anterior joint line is positive. The Scarpa’s triangle appears to be tender.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common complication of fracture neck of femur is the non-union of the fracture.
  • There is absence of cambium layer of periostium in the femoral neck within the joint capsule.
  • Thus, the fracture neck of femur heals without external callus.
  • Blood supply is precarious in this region which is further jeopardized by displacement of fragments and a tamponade effect adds to the insult by occluding the veins at lower pressure and arteries at higher pressure.
  • Being intracapsular, the fracture is bathed by synovial fluid which interferes with the healing process.

 

NOTE: Difference between intracapsular and extracapsular femoral neck fractures are:

questions.text: The most common type of hip fracture in childhood is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transcervical fracture

 

Option B:

 

PEDIATRIC HIP FRACTURE

 

  • In children, the order of prevalence of types of hip fracture is: transcervical > cervicotrochanteric > intertrochanteric > transphyseal
  • Pediatric hip fractures are classified with Delbet classification.
  • The Delbet classification helps predict the risk of avascular necrosis of the femoral head in neck of femur fractures, as well as determine operative vs non-operative management.
  • Type I: trans-epiphyseal separation:
    • fracture through proximal femoral physis, representing Salter-Harris type I fractures of the proximal femur (<10%)
      • Type IA: without dislocation
      • Type IB: with dislocation 
  • Type II: transcervical fracture:
    • fracture extending through mid-portion of the femoral neck
    • most common type of pediatric hip fracture (40-50%)
  • Type III: basicervical/cervicotrochanteric fracture:
    • fracture though base of the femoral neck (25-35%)
  • Type IV: intertrochanteric fracture:
    • between the greater and lesser trochanters (6-15%)
    • this type of fracture has the best surgical outcome

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In children, the most common type of hip fracture is transcervical fracture.

choices.text: Complete fracture with full displacement

questions.text: Garden type I fractures are also known as:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Valgus impaction fractures

 

Option D:

 

GARDEN’S CLASSIFICATION FOR FRACTURE NECK OF FEMUR

 

  • Stage 1: The fracture is incomplete, with head tilted in posterolateral direction, i.e. into valgus, therefore is known as valgus (abduction) impacted fracture.
  • Stage 2: Complete fracture but undisplaced.
  • Stage 3: Complete fracture with partial displacement.
  • Stage 4: Complete fracture with total displacement.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Complete fracture without displacement. This is Garden’s type II fracture.

 

Option B: Complete fracture with minimal (partial) displacement. This is Garden’s type III fracture.

 

Option C: Complete fracture with full displacement. This is Garden’s type IV fracture.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Valgus impaction fractures are the type I fracture of the femoral neck according to Garden’s classification.
  • This type of fracture is incomplete with the femoral head tilted in posterolateral direction i.e., into valgus.

questions.text: Increase in Pauwel’s angle indicate:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) More chances of displacement

 

Option C:

 

PAUWEL’S ANGLE

 

  • Pauwel's angle is the angle between the line of a fracture of the neck of the femur and the horizontal imaginary line.
  • The classification is based on the biomechanical principle of shear stress and varus force.
  • More vertically oriented fractures have higher risk of fracture displacement and ultimately, non-union.
  • Pauwel’s Classification:
     

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Good prognosis. This can be seen in cases of type I fracture with less angle of inclination as the chances of non-union are very low.

 

Option B: Impaction. Impaction is seen in type I fracture due to compressive forces but the angle of inclination is still less in this type.

 

Option D: Trabecular alignment disrupted. While an increase in Pauwel's angle indicates a more vertically oriented fracture line, it doesn't directly imply disruption of trabecular alignment.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • An increase in Pauwel's angle indicates a more vertically oriented fracture line, which is associated with increased shear forces acting on the fracture site, leading to a higher likelihood of displacement.

choices.text: The difference between neck-shaft angle between two femurs of a patient
Formed by joining a line extended from fracture line of femur neck to an arbitrary line depicting the horizontal plane

questions.text: Pauwel’s angle is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Formed by joining a line extended from fracture line of femur neck to an arbitrary line depicting the horizontal plane

 

Option C:

 

PAUWEL’S ANGLE

 

Pauwel's angle is the angle between the line of a fracture of the neck of the femur and the horizontal as seen on an anterio-posterior radiograph.

 

 

  • An increasing angle leads to a more unstable fracture and an increase in the shear stress at the fracture site.
  • This shear leads to higher rates of non-union.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Neck-shaft angle of femur. The angle of the femoral neck relative to the shaft is known as neck-shaft angle. Normal value of neck-shaft angle in an adult is 120-135. Angle < 120 is called coxa vara, angle > 135 is called coxa valga.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The Pauwel’s angle is defined as the angle formed by the line joining the fracture line of neck of femur to an arbitrary horizontal line.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a history of fall, complaints of pain in right hip and inability to walk.  On examination, tenderness is present in Scarpa’s triangle. The X-ray is normal. Next investigation is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MRI

 

Option C:

 

HIP FRACTURE INVESTIGATIONS

 

  • The given case scenario describes complaints of pain in the hip and an inability to walk, suggesting a diagnosis of fracture around the hip.
  • Since the x-ray in this case appears normal, this means that the fracture is an occult type.
  • Occult means hidden.
  • An occult fracture does not appear on an X-ray.
  • In this context, use of MRI can be more accurate at detecting occult hip fractures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Aspiration. Aspiration involves the removal of fluid from a joint or tissue for diagnostic purposes. While it may be indicated in suspected joint effusion or infection, it's not the most appropriate next step in this case, where the primary concern seems to be related to the hip and surrounding structures.

 

Option B: CT scan. CT scan provides detailed images of bones and can reveal fractures or bone abnormalities that may not be apparent on X-ray. However, in this case, where soft tissue involvement is suspected (tenderness in Scarpa's triangle), CT scan might not be the most informative initial investigation for assessing soft tissue pathology.

 

Option D: Bone scan. Bone scan is primarily used to detect abnormalities in bone metabolism and is helpful in diagnosing fractures, infections, or tumors that may not be visible on conventional X-rays. However, given the clinical presentation with tenderness in Scarpa's triangle and normal X-ray, the concern seems to be more focused on soft tissue involvement rather than purely bone pathology, making MRI a more appropriate choice for further investigation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the given case scenario, the injury is around the hip involving soft tissues and bone.
  • The presenting complaints and examination suggests the presence of occult fracture around the hip.
  • The occult fractures are not visible on x-rays and CT scans.
  • They can be only viewed on MRI.
  • Thus, in this case, the next investigation will be an MRI.

choices.text: Supracondylar fracture is treated by closed reduction
Lateral condyle humerus fracture is treated by open reduction
Forearm fracture in children is treated by closed reduction and cast is applied
Neck femur fracture in geriatrics is treated with open reduction and screw fixation

questions.text: All the following are True except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neck femur fracture in geriatrics is treated with open reduction and screw fixation

 

Option D:

 

FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • In patients < 65 years of age with fracture sustained < 3 weeks before,
    • Closed reduction and internal fixation with multiple screw is the treatment of choice.
    • In basicervical fracture, dynamic hip screw can be done.
    • If closed reduction is not possible, open reduction and screw fixation is indicated.
  • In patients < 65 years of age with > 3 week old fracture, osteotomy/Bone grafting + fixation is done.
  • In patients ≥ 65 years with no pre-existing arthritis, hemiarthroplasty is preferred.
  • In patients with pre-existing arthritis at any age, total hip replacement is done.
  • “Fractures of Necessity”, necessitating open reduction and internal fixation to achieve satisfactory outcomes includes: (Mnemonic: Lets Go For OPeration At Medical college)
    1. Lateral condyle fracture humerus
    2. Galeazzi fracture dislocation
    3. Fracture neck femur
    4. Displaced fracture olecranon
    5. Displaced fracture patella
    6. Articular fractures
    7. Monteggia fracture in adults

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In geriatric population, the neck of femur fracture is treated with hemiarthroplasty preferably if the patient is > 65 years of age.
  • Closed reduction and internal fixation with screws is preferred in patients < 65 years of age.
  • If closed reduction is not possible, then open reduction and screw fixation is done.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with fracture neck of femur 3 days after injury. Treatment of choice is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemiarthroplasty

 

Option C:

 

TREATMENT OF FRACTURE NECK OF FEMUR

 

  • Preferred treatment in a geriatric patient that is ≥ 65 years is hemiarthroplasty.
  • In patients < 65 years of age with fracture sustained < 3 weeks before,
    • Closed reduction and internal fixation with multiple screw is the treatment of choice.
    • In basicervical fracture, dynamic hip screw can be done.
    • If closed reduction is not possible, open reduction and screw fixation is indicated.
  • In patients < 65 years of age with > 3 week old fracture, osteotomy/Bone grafting + fixation is done.
  • In patients with pre-existing arthritis at any age, total hip replacement is done.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Multiple screw fixation. This is preferred in patients < 65 years of age and fracture occurred < 3 weeks before. Closed reduction and internal fixation with multiple screws is done in such patients.

 

Option B: McMurray osteotomy. This is done in cases of non-union of fracture of femur.

 

Option D: Total hip replacement. This is preferred in patients with pre-existing hip osteoarthritis. The patient can be of any age.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In patients > 65 years of age with neck of femur fracture, the preferred treatment option is hemiarthroplasty.

questions.text: McMurray’s osteotomy is based on which of the following principle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biomechanical

 

Option B:

 

McMURRAY’S OSTEOTOMY

 

  • McMurray's Osteotomy is a biomechanical procedure of subtrochanteric abduction (valgus impaction) osteotomy used in young (< 65 years’ age) with viable femoral head (no AVN) and minimal collapse of neck.
  • McMurray's osteotomy is a bifurcation osteotomy of the proximal femur where the shaft of the femur is directly transferred under the lower margin of the femoral head and acetabulum.
  • In femoral neck fractures, it makes the fracture line more horizontal.
  • It, therefore, converts the shearing forces to compressive forces, which helps in promoting the union of the fracture and provides an “armchair effect,” which helps in painless weight-bearing even if the fracture fails to unite after this osteotomy.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The McMurray’s osteotomy works on biomechanical principle.
  • It converts the shear force into compressive force which provides an arm chair effect that promotes fracture union and painless weight bearing.

questions.text: Vascular sign of Narath is positive in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior hip dislocation

 

Option B:

 

VASCULAR SIGN OF NARATH

 

  • Vascular sign of Narath is positive, i.e. due to posterior dislocation of hip joint, the vessels fall back unsupported so femoral arterial pulsation, which is felt against the head of the femur will be feeble or even may not be palpable.
  • This is a test to elicit the presence of head of the femur.
  • Procedure:
    • Patient lies supine.
    • Examiner palpates the femoral artery pulse bilaterally for volume, intensity and position.
  • Findings:
    • Normally, volume, intensity, and position of the femoral artery pulse are palpable bilaterally.
    • In case of Hip Dislocation, Head of the femur is displaced from its position and femoral artery had lost its bony support.
    • So, there will be great difficulty in feeling the femoral artery.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Anterior hip dislocation. The vascular sign of Narath is negative in anterior hip dislocation as the femoral artery is felt in this dislocation.

 

Option C: Anterior shoulder dislocation and Option D. Posterior shoulder dislocation. Vascular sign of Narath is not related to the arteries of the upper limb, thus it is not applicable in cases of shoulder dislocation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The Vascular sign of Narath is positive in cases of posterior hip dislocation where the femoral artery is not palpable or has feeble pulsations.

questions.text: Maximum shortening of limbs occurs in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior dislocation of hip

 

Option B:

 

POSTERIOR DISLOCATION OF HIP

 

  • Patients with a posterior dislocation of the hip generally present with a shortened, internally rotated, adducted limb in slight flexion.
  • The limb appears shortened because of the displaced femoral head.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Intertrochanteric fracture femur. This fracture also presents with limb shortening but it is not more than that seen in the posterior hip dislocation.

 

Option C: Fracture neck of femur. The impacted and stress fractures of the femoral neck do not present with any limb deformity. The displaced femoral neck fractures present with limb shortening but it is not more than that seen in posterior hip dislocation.

 

Option D: Anterior dislocation of hip. This dislocation presents with lengthening of the limb due to anterior position of the displaced femoral head.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Maximum limb shortening is seen in the posterior dislocation of the hip due to the posterior placement of the femoral head after dislocation.

choices.text: Abduction, external rotation and extension

questions.text: In anterior dislocation of hip, the posture of lower limb will be:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abduction, external rotation and flexion

 

Option B:

 

ANTERIOR DISLOCATION OF HIP

 

  • Anterior dislocations occur with the hip externally rotated and abducted.
  • The degree of flexion at the time of injury determines the eventual position of the femoral head.
  • Anterior dislocations are classified according to the position assumed by the femoral head into pubic, obturator, or perineal types.
  • They are associated with lengthening.

 

 

FABER deformity of the hip

 

 

Anterior dislocation of hip (abducted thigh)

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In anterior dislocation of hip, the limb presents with FABER deformity i.e., hip in flexion, abduction and external rotation.

choices.text: Skeletal traction on Thomas' splint
Smith Petersen nail
Condylar blade plate
Cephalomedullary nail

questions.text: Subtrochanteric fractures of femur can be treated by all of the following methods except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Skeletal traction on Thomas' splint

 

Option A)

 

SUBTROCHANTERIC FEMUR FRACTURE

 

  • Due to deforming forces acting on subtrochantric fracture, it becomes fracture of necessity and requires reduction and fixation with either a cephalomedullary device or blade plate.
  • Skeletal traction is not the preferred treatment option for subtrochantric fracture.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The treatment of choice for subtrochanteric femoral fractures is either the use of intramedullary nailing (usually cephalomedullary) or a fixed angle plate.
  • Skeletal traction does not provide a good stability to the fractured fragments.

choices.text: To prevent blood loss
To prevent ARDS
To prevent Non-union
To prevent Compartment syndrome

questions.text: Why fracture shaft of femur is stabilised early?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To prevent ARDS

 

Option B)

 

FRACTURE SHAFT OF FEMUR

 

  • Early definitive treatment in patients within 24 to 48 hours reduces the incidence of pulmonary complications, infection rates, and mortality.
  • Hemodynamically stable patients with multiple injuries receive the most benefit from early fixation.
  • Delayed treatment increases pulmonary complications in up to 56% of patients compared to only 16% of patients treated early.
  • In fracture shaft femur, early stabilisation of the fracture prevent fat embolism which leads to ARDS.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. To prevent blood loss. Blood loss at fracture site happens at the time of trauma. Internal fixation cannot overcome that.

 

Option C. To prevent non-union. Nonunion is not dependent on the duration of surgery from trauma. It is dependent on the biology and the stability provided by the treatment method used for stabilization.

 

Option D. To prevent compartment syndrome. Compartment syndrome is a very rare entity in fracture shaft femur.

 

Educational objective:

 

The fracture of femoral shaft requires early stabilization within first 24-48 hours to prevent pulmonary complications like fat embolism that can lead to ARDS.

choices.text: 1 unit

questions.text: Blood loss in fracture shaft of femur is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 units

 

Option B)

 

BLOOD LOSS IN FEMORAL SHAFT FRACTURE

 

  • Traumatic femur shaft fractures are considered potentially life-threatening injuries often resulting from high-energy trauma.
  • Femoral Shaft Fracture have been associated with significant blood loss, leading to hemorrhagic shock and potentially death.
  • Early studies have demonstrated that femur shaft fractures can cause blood loss of up to 1000–1500 mL into the thigh compartments.
  • Such volumes of blood loss may give rise to class II shock or worsen preexisting shock from other injuries.
  • Blood loss is considered to be potentially greater in open fractures due to damage to surrounding tissues and the loss of a tamponade effect in the thigh.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In femur fractures, the amount of blood lost from the trauma is around 2 units.
  • This amount is greater in open fractures.

choices.text: Diagnostic criteria for fat embolism syndrome
Pulmonary edema is major criterion
Thrombocytopenia is a major criterion
1 major + 4 minor criteria are required to diagnose as Fat embolism

questions.text: Regarding Gurd’s criteria, all are correct except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thrombocytopenia is a major criterion

 

Option C)

 

GURD’S CRITERIA

 

  • Diagnosis of fat embolism is usually made on the basis of clinical findings but biochemical changes may be of value.
  • The most commonly used set of major and minor diagnostic criteria are those published by Gurd, called the Gurd’s criteria.
  • The major criteria are based on the classic triad and clinical diagnosis is made by the presence of respiratory insufficiency, neurological impairment, and a petechial rash.
  • In the appropriate setting, the rash is considered pathognomonic, although it is present in only 20–50% of cases. 
  • For the diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome, at least one major and four minor criteria must be present.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Gurd’s criteria is a diagnostic criterion for fat embolism syndrome.
  • Pulmonary oedema is major criterion.
  • Thrombocytopenia is a minor criterion.
  • 1 major + 4 minor criteria are required to diagnose as Fat embolism.
  • PaO2 < 60 mmHg is a major criterion

questions.text: Fat embolism syndrome is most commonly seen after:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Femur fracture

 

Option A)

 

FAT EMBOLISM SYNDROME 

 

  • The risk of fat embolism is higher with the fracture of long bones.
  • Most commonly, Fat embolism is seen after fracture of femur.
  • Fat embolism leads to ARDS.
  • Fat embolism occurs due to release of fat globules from the bone marrow into the blood circulation following a severe trauma or orthopedic surgeries or fracture of multiple long bones or liposuction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Acetabular fracture. Post traumatic arthritis, osteonecrosis, infection (5%), iatrogenic nerve injury, DVT (4%) are the common complications of acetabular fractures.

 

Option C. Pelvis fracture. Hemorrhage, either intraperitoneal or retroperitoneal, is the most frequent complication associated with pelvic fractures.

 

Option D. Calcaneal fracture. Osteomyelitis, postoperative wound infection, malunion, and subtalar arthritis are all potential complications of calcaneal fractures.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Fat embolism syndrome is most commonly seen after the fracture of the femur if not stabilized within first 48-72 hours.

questions.text: Insall-Salvati index is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Patella

 

Option B)

 

INSALL-SALVATI INDEX

 

  • Insall–Salvati (IS) ratio is used in measuring the patellar height.
  • It is used to detect patellar height abnormalities such as patella alta and patella baja.

 

 

  • This index is ratio of patellar tendon length to the length of patella.

 

INSALL-SALVATI RATIO = Patellar Tendon length/Length of patella

 

  • It is between 0.8 to 1.2.
  • IS ratio <0.8 – Patella baja (low-lying patella)
  • IS ratio >1.2 – Patella alta (high-lying patella)
  • Clinical significance:
    • Anterior knee pain is the most common problem which can be attributed to patella alta or patella baja.
    • Patella alta or high riding patella leads to increased patellar instability due decreased contact between the patella and the trochlea in knee extension and the first few degrees of knee flexion. It is associated with recurrent patellar subluxation, Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome (PFPS), chondromalacia patella, Osgood–Schlatter’s Disease, Sinding-Larsen-Johansson Disease and patellar tendonitis.
    • Patella baja or low riding patella can be a sign of quadriceps tendon rupture, neuromuscular disorder or achondroplasia.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The Insall-Salvati index is used for the measurement of patellar height to determine the presence of patella alta or patella baja.

choices.text: Fracture of talus
Fracture of medial condyle of femur
Radial head fracture

questions.text: Avascular necrosis is a complication of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture of talus

 

Option A)

 

TALUS FRACTURE COMPLICATIONS

 

  • Talar fractures are infrequent but potentially devastating injuries.
  • Talar neck fractures are the most common, accounting for 50% of these injuries.
  • The vascular supply of the talus is such that fractures to the neck and body have a high likelihood of developing avascular necrosis.
  • Other complications of talar fractures include non-union, malunion and osteoarthritis.
  • Secondary Osteoarthritis of Subtalar > ankle joint occurs years after injury in over 50% patients. There are several causes like articular damage because of initial trauma, malunion, distortion of articular surface and AVN.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Fracture of medial condyle of femur. The common complications after medial condyle fracture of femur include knee pain/stiffness, malunion, non-union, and infections.

 

Option C. Olecranon fracture. Complications of olecranon fracture may involve loss of terminal elbow extension ROM, arthrosis of the elbow, heterotopic ossification, ulnar nerve neuritis, non-union, and malunion.

 

Option D. Radial head fracture. Common complications with severe consequences include radioulnar synostosis, avascular necrosis (rare), posterior interosseous nerve injury, non-union, malunion, heterotopic ossification, and decreased ROM.

 

Educational objective:

  • Among the given options, avascular necrosis is seen commonly in the fracture of the talus.
  • Other common sites of AVN are:
    • Femoral head
    • Scaphoid
    • Capitellum
    • Lateral femoral condyle

questions.text: Runner’s fracture involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibula

 

Option B)

 

RUNNER’S FRACTURE

 

  • A Runner's fracture refers to stress fracture that occurs in the lower leg bones due to repetitive stress from activities like running.
  • Runner's fractures often involve the distal part of the fibula, specifically the lateral malleolus, which is subjected to repetitive stress during running.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Tibia. Stress fractures can occur in the tibia, especially in runners, due to the repetitive impact forces generated during running. However, "Runner's fracture" refers to a fracture of the fibula.

 

Option C. Metatarsal. Stress fractures in the metatarsal bones are commonly referred to as March fractures.

 

Option D. Talus. Fractures involving the talus bone occur due to trauma, such as a fall from height and not from repetitive stress injury.

 

Educational objective:

 

Runner’s fracture involves the stress fracture of the distal fibula.

choices.text: Fracture of distal end of both bones of leg
Fracture of distal fibula
Fracture of talus

questions.text: Which one of the following fracture requires plaster of Paris cast with equines position?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fracture of talus

 

Option D)

 

TALUS FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • Fractures of the talus bone can be complex and challenging to manage due to the bone's critical role in supporting the ankle joint and transmitting weight from the leg to the foot.
  • Depending on the severity and location of the talus fracture, treatment may involve immobilization with a plaster of Paris cast to stabilize the affected area and promote proper healing.
  • The undisplaced fractures of the talus are treated conservatively with a cast application with the foot in the equinus position.
  • The equinus position helps to reduce tension on the Achilles tendon and may aid in maintaining proper alignment of the talus fracture.
  • By positioning the foot in equinus, the talus is often aligned with the rest of the foot and ankle bones, reducing the risk of displacement and promoting optimal healing.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Fracture of distal end of both bones of leg. The fracture of both bones of the leg is treated conservatively by applying a short or long leg cast.

 

Option B. Fracture of distal fibula. A hinged short leg boot is a good option for immobilization of the extremity for the fracture healing. It provides pain relief, increased ROM and early return to ambulation.

 

Option C. Bimalleolar fracture. In a stable bimalleolar fracture, a below knee cast or a total contact cast is used.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Fractures of the talus require immobilization with a plaster of Paris cast in conjunction with the equinus position to ensure proper alignment and stability during the healing process.

choices.text: Putting the plaster roll in warm water hastens setting time
It is anhydrous calcium phosphate
It should be carefully applied in presence of swelling
Gangrene is known complication of a tight plaster cast

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding application of POP cast except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is anhydrous calcium phosphate

 

Option B)

 

POP CAST

 

  • Plaster of Paris is CaSO4. 1/2 H2O.
  • Average setting time is 7–10 minutes.
  • Drying time (time taken for the POP to convert from crystalline form to anhydrous from):
    • Arm cast: 24–36 hours
    • Leg cast: 48–60 hours
  • Dip the POP vertically.
  • Cold water will maximize the moulding time.
  • Plaster of Paris consists of a fine white powder which hardens when moistened and allowed to dry.
  • Complications:
    • Due to tight cast:
      • Pain
      • Pressure sores
      • Compartment syndrome
      • Peripheral nerve injury
    • Due to improper application:
      • Plaster blisters
      • Breakage
      • Loose cast
    • Due to allergy:
      • Allergic dermatitis
    • Others:
      • Muscle wasting
      • Skin abrasion/laceration
      • Gangrene

 

Other options:

 

1. Putting the plaster roll in warm water hastens setting time. This statement is true. Plaster of Paris (POP) casts are typically activated by immersing them in warm water, which accelerates the setting time, allowing the cast to harden more quickly.
