3. It should be carefully applied in presence of swelling. This statement is true. When applying a plaster cast, it is essential to take into account any swelling in the affected limb. If there is significant swelling, it can lead to complications such as constriction of blood flow or discomfort for the patient. Therefore, careful application is necessary.

 

4. Gangrene is known complication of a tight plaster cast. This statement is true. Tight plaster casts can impede blood circulation to the affected limb, leading to tissue damage and potentially causing gangrene in severe cases. It's crucial for healthcare providers to monitor the tightness of the cast and address any signs of compromised circulation promptly.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Plaster of Paris (POP) is not anhydrous calcium phosphate.
  • It is a form of calcium sulfate hemihydrate (CaSO4 1/2H2O).

choices.text: Neglected club foot
Valgus deformity of foot

questions.text: Watson-Jones approach is done for:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hip replacement

 

Option D)

 

WATSON-JONES APPROACH FOR HIP

 

  • Watson-Jones operation is anterolateral approach to the hip joint.
  • There are four commonly used approaches to the hip joint:
    • Anterior or Smith-Peterson- commonly used to access the hip in cases of suspected septic arthritis
    • Anterolateral or Watson-Jones- is used for hemi or total hip arthroplasty
    • Direct lateral or Hardinge
    • Posterior or Southern approach
  • Watson-Jones approach provides exposure to the acetabulum and the proximal femur.
  • It is indicated in total hip replacement, hemiarthroplasty, femoral neck fracture ORIF, synovial biopsy of hip, and femoral neck biopsy.
  • It is beneficial in patients with high risk for dislocation as there is no posterior soft tissue disruption in this approach.
  • Drawbacks:
    • does not improve post-op gait kinematics as compared to trans-gluteal approach
    • can weaken the abductor muscles and cause limping

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Neglected club foot. Neglected club foot usually involves a combination of soft tissue releases, osteotomies, and sometimes external fixation devices to correct the deformity.

 

Option B. Muscle paralysis. Muscle paralysis might be addressed through various interventions such as physical therapy, bracing, nerve surgery, or other orthopedic procedures depending on the cause and severity of paralysis.

 

Option C. Valgus deformity. Valgus deformity usually involves soft tissue releases, osteotomies, or fusion procedures tailored to the specific deformity and its underlying causes.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The Watson-Jones approach is indeed utilized for hip replacement surgery.
  • It is a surgical approach used to access the hip joint for total hip arthroplasty (hip replacement).
  • It involves making an incision along the side of the hip, allowing access to the joint for implantation of prosthetic components.

choices.text: Displaced fracture of calcaneum
Sphenoid Wing Fracture
Coronal Shear pilon Fracture

questions.text: Tripod fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zygomaticomaxillary fracture

 

Option B)

 

TRIPOD FRACTURE

 

  • Trauma to face causes zygomaticomaxillary fractures and its synonymous word are tripod, tetrapod or quadripod fractures.
  • This injury comprises of fracture of the zygomatic arch, inferior orbital rim, posterior maxillary sinus walls, and lateral orbital rim.
  • The fracture complex results from a direct blow to the malar eminence.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tripod fracture is the synonym for the zygomatico-maxillary fracture that occurs from trauma to the face.

questions.text: Lisfranc’s fracture-dislocation involve:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tarso-metatarsal

 

Option C)

 

LISFRANC’S FRACTURE-DISLOCATION

 

  • The Lisfranc joint is formed by the articulation between the metatarsal bones and tarsal bones (cuneiforms and cuboid). 
  • Lisfranc’s fracture-dislocation involves fracture-dislocation of the tarso-metatarsal articulation (lisfranc joint).
  • A Lisfranc injury characterized by traumatic disruption between the articulation of the medial cuneiform and base of the second metatarsal.
  • The usual mechanism is a direct blow or an indirect twisting force applied to a foot in plantar flexion 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by radiographs which may show widening of the interval between the 1st and 2nd ray.
  • Treatment is generally operative with either ORIF or arthrodesis.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lisfranc’s fracture-dislocation involves fracture and dislocation of the articulation between the medial cuneiform and base of the 2nd metatarsal, appearing as a gap between the 1st and 2nd ray on the radiograph.

questions.text: Hanging cast is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Humerus fracture

 

Option C)

 

HANGING CAST

 

  • It is used for displaced fracture of the humeral shaft with shortening, and also for oblique and spiral fractures.
  • Indications: 
    • Comminuted humeral fractures
    • Distal humeral shaft fractures 
  • The cast must be light weight and must extend from at least 1 inch proximal to the fracture site to wrist, with elbow at right angle & forearm in neutral rotation.  
  • The arm must lie in a dependent position to provide a traction force.
  • Correction of Angulation:
    • A sling must be securely fixed at the wrist by a loop made of plaster or other material.
    • To correct lateral angulation, the loop is placed on dorsum of the wrist.
    • Medial angulation is corrected by placing loop on the volar side.
    • Anterior angulation may result from length of collar that is too long.
    • Wrist drops below the horizontal plane, & distal fragment of humerus tilts posteriorly, allowing anterior angulation of the fracture.
    • Conversely, a short collar and cuff will cause posterior bowing.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Femur fracture. For femur fractures, a hip spica is used. A hip spica is a large cast which extends from the mid-chest down to the ankle of the broken leg. It also covers the other leg slightly above the knee. A bar may be placed between the legs to reinforce the cast and prevent breakage. Area around the groin is left open in order to facilitate toileting.

 

 

Option B. Radius fracture. For distal radial fractures that are displaced dorsally, a below elbow cast with moulding in slight wrist flexion should be applied. The cast should not extend too distally. The patient should be able to flex their metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints.

 

 

Option D. Tibia fracture. For tibia fractures, a long leg cast is applied for six weeks followed by a short leg cast and then an Aircast boot.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Hanging cast is used for the fracture of the distal humerus and shaft of the humerus.

questions.text:
Regarding POP cast techniques, which of the following statement is true?

 

1. POP should be just dipped and taken out immediately after immersion into water

2. Leg casts moulds in 48-60 hours

3. Using hot water takes more time to mould

4. POP should be dipped vertically rather than horizontally

5. Compartment syndrome is an immediate complication
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 4, 5

 

Option D)

 

POP CAST

 

  • Plaster of Paris is CaSO4. 1/2 H2O.
  • Average setting time is 7–10 minutes.
  • Drying time (time taken for the POP to convert from crystalline form to anhydrous from):
    • Arm cast: 24–36 hours
    • Leg cast: 48–60 hours
  • Dip the POP vertically.
  • Cold water will maximize the moulding time.
  • Complications:
    • Due to tight cast:
      • Pain
      • Pressure sores
      • Compartment syndrome
      • Peripheral nerve injury
    • Due to improper application:
      • Plaster blisters
      • Breakage
      • Loose cast
    • Due to allergy:
      • Allergic dermatitis
    • Others:
      • Muscle wasting
      • Skin abrasion/laceration

 

Other options:

 

1. POP should be just dipped and taken out immediately after immersion into water. This statement is incorrect. When applying a plaster of Paris (POP) cast, it is essential to ensure that the bandages are fully saturated with water. Simply dipping the bandages quickly and taking them out won't provide enough moisture for the plaster to properly set. Instead, the bandages need to be submerged in water for an adequate amount of time to ensure thorough saturation. This allows the plaster to become pliable and moldable, facilitating the application of the cast.

 

3. Using hot water takes more time to mould. This statement is also incorrect. When preparing the water for dipping the bandages, it is generally recommended to use room temperature or slightly cool water, rather than hot water. Hot water can accelerate the setting time of the plaster, making it more difficult to work with and reducing the molding time. Cooler water allows for a slower setting process, giving more time to apply and mold the cast to the patient's limb before it hardens completely.

 

Educational objective:

  • Leg casts moulds in 48-60 hours to fully harden and set.
  • POP should be dipped vertically rather than horizontally. This allows for better saturation and reduces the risk of air bubbles, ensuring a smoother and more even application of the cast.
  • Compartment syndrome is an immediate complication. It can happen as a result of trauma or injury, including the application of a tight or improperly applied cast. If not promptly treated, compartment syndrome can lead to tissue damage, nerve injury, and even limb loss.

questions.text: Russell’s traction is used in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inter-trochanteric fracture

 

Option A)

 

RUSSELL’S TRACTION

 

  • Russell’s traction is used in treatment of inter-trochanteric fractures in children between 2 to 10 years of age.
  • It is also used after hip arthroplasty.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Fracture shaft of femur. In children, for femoral shaft fractures, Gallow’s traction (< 2 years of age), 90-90° traction (10-15 years) can be used. In adults, perkin’s traction is used.

 

Option C. Low back ache. For low back ache, buck’s traction is used. In cases of lumbar spine injuries, halo-pelvic traction is used.

 

Option D. Flexion deformity of hip. In poliomyelitis, to treat flexion deformity of the hip, agnes hunt traction is used.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Russell’s traction is used for the treatment of inter-trochanteric femur fracture in children aged 2-10 years.

questions.text: Continuous fixed traction is provided by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thomas splint

 

Option A)

 

THOMAS SPLINT

 

  • The Thomas' splint is a long leg splint extending from a ring at the hip/groin area to beyond the foot.
  • It aims to immobilise the limb and consists of a padded metal ring covered with soft leather which is attached to an angled bar that extends down the length and both sides of the leg.
  • The bar is usually angled over the hip at the greater trochanter and the two side bars join in a “W” shape at the foot.

 

 

  • Thomas' splint is most commonly used with either skin or skeletal traction to provide immobilisation for proximal third and mid shaft femoral fractures, especially for children and adults whose injuries cannot be managed by other means. 
  • The splint provides a continuous and fixed traction for the stabilization and healing of the fracture.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. BB splint. The BB splint is a type of splint used primarily for immobilization of the elbow joint. It is not designed for continuous fixed traction.

 

Option C. Hamilton Russel traction. Hamilton Russell traction is a form of skin traction used for femoral fractures. It involves applying a pulling force to the leg using adhesive traction tapes or strips attached to the skin. It is not continuous fixed traction.

 

Educational objective:

 

A continuous and fixed traction is provided by the Thomas splint.

choices.text: It is used to give skeletal traction
It has threads in the center of pin
It is used to give skeletal traction through calcaneum

questions.text: Which of the following statement about Denham pin is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D)

 

DENHAM PIN

 

  • Denham pins are composed of biocompatible materials such as stainless steel.
  • They are smooth and cylindrical, with a sharp tip on one end and a hole or groove on the other.
  • Denham Pin is identical to stienmann pin except for a short threaded length in the center.
  • This threaded portion engages the bony cortex and reduce the risk of the pin sliding.
  • It is used in cancellous bones like calcaneum and osteoporitic bones to provide skeletal traction to the bones.
  • Denham Pin is indicated for use in the fixation of bone fractures, bone reconstruction, and as guide pins for insertion of other implant.
  • Indications:
    • Bone trauma requiring internal fixation for healing.
    • Fixation of soft tissue to bone where Pins are able to so do safely.
    • Bone lengthening and shortening procedures.
    • Osteotomies and other realignment procedures.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Denham pin is used to provide skeletal traction to the calcaneum and osteoporotic bones.
  • It consists of threads in the center to reduce the risk of pin sliding, and it attaches to the bony cortex.

choices.text: Comminuted shaft of femur fracture
Avascular necrosis of femoral head

questions.text: Bone transport can be used in the management:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gap non-union

 

Option A:

 

BONE TRANSPORT

 

  • Bone transport is the method of growing new bone in the region of non-union.
  • It is also called distraction osteogenesis.
  • In Gap Non-Union, there is the failure of healing of the fracture.
  • This technique helps in growing the ends of the long bones, gradually stimulating new bone formation to bridge the Gap.
  • Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis i.e., an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently, lengthening can be done.
  • It can be used for the correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap nonunion, and also for CTEV.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Deformity correction. Bone transport can also be used in the management of deformity correction, particularly in cases of limb length inequality or angular deformities but the most common indication for bone transport is generally gap non-union of fractures.

 

Option C. Comminuted shaft of femur fracture. Comminuted shaft femur fractures involve multiple fragments of bone in the shaft of the femur. Bone transport may not be the primary treatment for these fractures. It can be considered in cases where there is significant bone loss or when other methods such as intramedullary nailing or plating are not feasible.

 

Option D. Avascular necrosis of femoral head. Bone transport is not used in the management of avascular necrosis of the femoral head. Its treatment usually involves preserving the femoral head and preventing further damage by core decompression, bone grafting, osteotomy, or total hip replacement, depending on the stage and severity of the condition.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Bone transport or distraction osteogenesis is done in the management of the gap non-union of the fractures of the long bones.
  • It is done with the help ilizarov fixator.

choices.text: Fracture humerus shaft with vascular involvement

questions.text: Which of the following requires surgical correction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

1. Pathological fracture: This refers to a fracture that occurs in a bone weakened by a disease process, such as osteoporosis or cancer. Depending on the severity and cause of the pathological fracture, surgical intervention may be necessary to stabilize the bone and promote healing, especially in the lower limb.

 

2. Fracture humerus shaft with vascular involvement: When a fracture of the humerus shaft occurs with vascular involvement, it implies damage to blood vessels supplying the area. This can lead to compromised blood flow and potential tissue damage or necrosis. Surgical correction may be required to repair the fracture and restore proper blood flow to the affected area. Shaft humerus fracture with vascular insult is an emergency for surgical intervention.

 

3. Polytrauma patient: A polytrauma patient is someone who has sustained multiple traumatic injuries, often involving more than one body system. The management of polytrauma patients typically involves a multidisciplinary approach, and surgical intervention may be necessary to address various injuries, such as fractures, internal organ damage, or traumatic amputations. polytrauma patient should be evaluated. ATLS guidelines are required to be followed.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Pathological fractures, fracture of the humerus shaft with radial nerve palsy, fracture of the humerus shaft with vascular involvement, and polytrauma are the indications for surgical management.
  • Vascular involvement in the humerus shaft fracture is an emergency that needs to be treated surgically.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for fracture lower 1/4th of tibia fracture non-union with multiple scarred wounds and discharging sinuses and about 4 cm shortening of leg is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ilizarov fixator

 

Option A)

 

  • In case of shortening with discharging sinus, ilizarov fixator is the preferred method.
  • In External fixation, the fixation device is external to skin, which is an external fixator or ilizarov fixator.
  • Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis i.e., an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently, lengthening can be done.
  • It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Plate. Plate fixation is contraindicated as discharging sinus is present. Shortening cannot be dealt with plate fixation.

 

Option C. External fixation. External fixator is monoplanar. Limb lengthening of 4 cm is difficult to achieve with external fixator.

 

Option D. Intrameduallary nail. Intramedullary nail is an internal fixation device, hence contraindicated.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In cases of long bone fracture non-union with discharging sinus and shortening of the limb, an external fixator device ilizarov fixator is useful as it provides distraction force for the lengthening of the limb.

questions.text: All of the following are indications for open reduction and internal fixation of fractures except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Compound fracture

 

Option A:

 

INDICATIONS OF ORIF

 

  • Associated vascular injury
  • Nonunion or Unacceptable Malunion
  • Pathological fracture
  • Bilateral humerus fracture
  • Humerus fracture in polytrauma
  • Radial nerve dysfunction after fracture manipulation
  • Failed conservative management
  • Floating elbow

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Open fractures or compound fractures require debridement and external fixation.
  • Multiple surgeries including soft tissue coverage is required before internal fixation.

questions.text: Cobra head plate is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hip arthrodesis

 

Option A:

 

COBRA HEAD PLATE

 

  • Surgical fusion of joint is known as arthrodesis.
  • 4 fundamental principles that must be respected to have a successful arthrodesis are:
    • Adequate cartilage debridement
    • Proper bone alignment
    • Rigid stability and compression
    • Bone graft augmentation
  • To achieve these principles, various implants can be used:
  • Schneider developed Cobra plates for hip arthrodesis

 

 

  • Smith-Peterson Nail for Fracture Neck Femur
  • Gamma Nail for Intertrochanteric fracture of Femur

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Knee arthrodesis. For knee arthrodesis, intramedullary rod, external fixation by ilizarov, or intramedullary nailing is used.

 

Option C. Elbow arthrodesis. For elbow arthrodesis, dorsal locking plate is used.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Cobra head plate is used for the hip arthrodesis.

questions.text: Commonest indication for ankle arthrodesis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Post-traumatic arthritis

 

Option B:

 

ANKLE ARTHRODESIS

  • Indications of ankle arthrodesis are:
  • Painful arthritis following infection, trauma (most common cause), chronic instability, AVN of the talus, inflammatory arthropathy, and primary OA
  • Neuropathic arthropathy
  • Tumor resection
  • Salvage for failed ORIF 
  • Salvage for failed total ankle arthroplasty
  • Ankle arthrodesis most commonly occurs due to Post trauma > post infection > rheumatoid arthritis > failed arthroplasty.
  • Age-related osteoarthritis is rare in ankle.
  • Management option of arthritis include:
  • Arthrodesis: When other measures fail or stable painless joint is required in young active labourer, surgical fusion is carried out.
  • Arthroplasty (joint replacement) also can be carried out for articular fractures. Ankle arthroplasty is not frequently carried out, due to high frequency of failure.
  • Failed arthroplasty will also require arthrodesis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common indication for ankle arthrodesis is post-traumatic arthritis of the ankle.
  • Other indications include post infective arthritis > rheumatoid arthritis > failed total ankle arthroplasty.

choices.text: Osteoarthritis of ankle joint
Osteoarthritis of subtalar joint

questions.text: Most common complication of fracture talus is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteoarthritis of subtalar joint

 

Option D)

 

TALUS FRACTURE COMPLICATIONS

 

  • Complications of talus fractures include:
    • avascular necrosis (AVN): 6%
    • post-traumatic subtalar joint osteoarthritis (OA): 12-15%
    • malunion and non-union: 2%
    • infection: 4%
    • joint stiffness

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common complication of talus fracture is subtalar joint osteoarthritis > AVN > non-union.
